story:
Thanks for dropping by the Access to Justice Technology Fellowship Programs (ATJ Tech Fellows Program) Indigogo campaign! We want you to make an impact investment in order to help achieve our ultimate goal:

Building a national network of law students with the skills and technical ability to innovatively respond to the systemic issues that account for the lack of access to justice in our nation.


Our Vision

The Access to Justice Technology Fellowship Program provides law students a unique opportunity to take part in a 10-week summer experience interning with civil legal aid organizations around the nation that are developing new models of user-friendly, accessible and engaging legal services through the use of technology. 

Program Overview

The ATJ Tech Fellows program has two components: a seminar portion and an experiential portion. Before arriving at their host legal aid organization, fellows will participate in the seminar portion, a two-day training period,hosted virtually in conjunction with the Legal Services National Technology Assistance Project. The fellows will meet virtually to learn from experts in the field about the varied use of technology in the changing landscape of legal service delivery. The seminars will introduce fellows to the nature and extent of the civil legal needs of low-income Americans, in addition to topics covering the changing landscape of service delivery, such as technology assisted review, document automation and design methods, online legal triage systems, legal expert systems and more.

Fellows meet virtually to learn a broad range of topics on legal innovation and service delivery from experts. 

The experiential portion places our fellows at a legal aid organization that is engaged in the development of innovative technology projects, to address the access to justice crisis and enhance service delivery. Fellows will apply what they learned from the seminar portion directly at their host organizations. Fellows will also receive a variety of experiences and assignments, including significant legal research and writing assignments. 

                            

Impact - Inspiring a new generation of legal innovators

The overall objective of the ATJ Tech Fellows program is to provide law students with an experiential understanding of the access to justice issues facing Americans and the knowledge to critically assess how innovation in the justice system can and is being used to address legal accessibility issues. This is something that is currently not widely taught in law school curriculums. A diverse core of fellows will gain the necessary skill set and leadership to leverage innovation and technology in assisting the implementation of legal services addressing access to justice issues in America. These translational skills will, in turn, prepare students with varying career interests, to participate and lead the next wave of innovations to solve the access to justice crisis.



Why ATJ Tech Fellows? Why Now?

Our civil justice system is facing a crisis. Millions of Americans cannot afford the legal help they need when facing life-changing situations such as domestic violence, unlawful evictions, or the loss of veterans health or disability benefits. They’re left to navigate these complex legal situations on their own—and risk losing their families, homes, and livelihoods in the process.

Courts, legal aid organizations and law schools share a commitment to the principle that justice should be accessible to all. However, courts are swamped with millions of self-represented litigants struggling to resolve disputes on their own and legal aid organizations face massive unmet legal needs in their target client communities, often exceeding 80%.



Although there is a growing call in United States to spur innovation in service delivery to address the civil legal access problem, as highlighted in American Bar Association's Commission on The Future of Legal Services 2016 Report, the antiquated legal education system largely ignores access to justice as a discrete issue. Many law schools do not have curriculums that specifically focus on the larger systemic issues that account for the lack of access to justice in the U.S., yet alone train their students with the skills to innovatively respond to this crisis.

The ATJ Tech Fellows program hopes to place 10 fellows at host legal aid sites for the summer of 2017 and provide our fellows with a $5,000 stipend to help defray their living expenses for the 10-week, 400-hour commitment. At our current state, the program has partnered with several legal aid organizations to serve as host sites for our 2017 summer fellows. Some of the legal aid organizations include the Northwest Justice Project, Illinois Legal Aid Online, Alaska Legal Services Corp., and Legal Aid Services Oklahoma. The program has recruited several dedicated law student volunteers from Seattle University School of Law, who are assisting to build the program's infrastructure, partnerships with law schools and legal aid organizations and fundraising efforts. The ATJ Tech Fellows program recently made it through the quarterfinals stage for the Seattle Social Venture Partners Fast Pitch competition, where it hopes to gain a wealth of mentorship and organizational development.


Our Team

When Miguel Willis started law school, not only did he represent the digital generation of students and young people whose lives are intertwined with all things technology, but also he had a penchant for seeing the potential of technology as a tool for justice. When Willis came up with the idea of holding Seattle’s first “Social Justice Hackathon” at Seattle University School of Law, the law school’s Access to Justice Institute put him in touch with the local network of civil legal aid programs. The event brought together technologist, data scientist, designers, law students and legal professionals to create technology-based solutions to address the gap in accessibility of legal services for low-income Americans. Willis spent this summer interning with the Self Represented Litigants Network, where he had the opportunity to follow the latest trends and innovations in access to justice around the world. The culmination of these experiences and lack of structures currently in place to provide law students with this type of training, inspired him to create the ATJ Tech Fellows program.  Willis credits the development of the program to a host mentors around the nation, who helped shape his vision as well as other innovative legal curriculums, both domestic and abroad. Their wisdom and experience laying a foundation to model many parts of the program.


The ATJ Tech Fellows movement is also led by several dedicated law student volunteers from Seattle University School of Law, who are assisting to build the program's infrastructure, partnerships with law schools, and fundraising efforts.


What We Need & What You Get

Our Goal: $15,000

We need your help to launch the inaugural ATJ Tech Fellow cohort starting in the 2017 summer. Your donation will contribute in 2 major ways:

1. Stipends for TWO of our summer fellows- to help defray their living expenses during the 10-week, 400-hour commitment over the summer.

2. Organizational development- to assist with promotional  and marketing materials, cover associated filing fees for our business licences, and travel expenses to promote the program at law school across the county.

All contributions are greatly appreciated, and any supplemental money raised over our goal will go towards the cost to support an additional fellow through the program. Whatever you are able to give: $10, $50, or $200, we promise it will make an impact.

What You Get

For as little as $50, everyone can go home with something! A preview of our perks:

  • ATJ Tech Fellows T-shirt!
  • Tickets to the ATJ Tech Fellows Launch Party!
  • Personalized Thank you Video!
  • Recognition on our website!


Other Ways You Can Help

Beyond Money— We Need Your Help Spreading the Word

At its heart, the ATJ Tech Fellows Program is a grassroots movement driven by law students and legal innovators who believe that it is of paramount importance to prepare future lawyers with the skills required to address the lack of access to justice in US. Whether you donate to our campaign or not, you can still help make history.

Share the campaign! Let's get this campaign viral by sharing this opportunity with your colleagues and friends on Facebook and Twitter.

Spread the word! Tell others about the program using the hashtag #ATJTechFellows on Facebook or Twitter.

Reach out to us! We would love to hear your feedback and suggestions of ways to make the program better!

Partner with us! If you are a legal aid organization, law school, ATJ commission, bar association, legal tech company, law firm, legal professional,  innovative law student, or other allied professional, we would love to here from you and how we can partner!

Stay connected! Follow the ATJ Tech Fellows program on Facebook and on Twitter to stay up-to-date on latest updates of our movement.

Recognizing Your Generosity. Thank You!

Investing in the ATJ Tech Fellows Program will empower future advocates with the ability to envision and affect change in the shifting legal landscape. We greatly appreciate your contributions!

story:
Rhythm Lab

A.I.R. Labs will launch a music production class this fall called Rhythm Lab to allow underserved youth in our community to learn how to create their own musical story. Through the creation process, the students will have a better appreciation of music in the ways that it has inspired them and the memories it has created.

We’re raising funds for a pilot course of Rhythm Lab. One of the major upfront costs of this course is the purchase of the software and hardware package from Native Instruments. Purchasing a classroom set of the materials will allow A.I.R. Labs to continue the course for this first class and future students. Going over our goal will create a fund that will provide scholarships to future students who are in financial need.

Why You Should Care

Music programs can be a game-changer and can help provide a positive outlet for underserved teens.

Your Donation

Your support towards our goal would cover the cost of the hardware and software purchase from Native Instruments for a classroom set of materials and tuition for the students for this pilot program of Rhythm Lab. Rhythm Lab will provide instruction to students for 4 weeks with the addition of Open Lab sessions during the course where students will be able to ask for additional help and also explore more of their music and the Native Instruments system.

The students will learn to make their own music and choose a favorite song of theirs to add to our student soundtrack which is available starting at the $50 donation level.

Ways You Can Help

Help us share this wonderful program and campaign with your family, friends, and colleagues through the various social media platforms below. 

  • Facebook
  • Twitter
  • Instagram

And share the IndieGoGo link with your social network: https://igg.me/at/rhythmlab

story:
Get Artsy's goal is to provide art classes to youth who are otherwise unable to access this type of much-needed education. The program will help youth become aware of career options, open their mindset, create a safe space and a sense of community, and learn to express themselves through the arts.

Through weekly classes led by youth facilitators, including peer learning, guest speakers and mentors, the first round of our 12-week program will take place in Brampton and is open to all youth in need. 


 

Our Impact

The significant impact art has on youth, as well as the unique programming of Get Artsy will ensure your contribution will make a difference. Art is a language that cuts across all borders and allows youth to express themselves and deal with issues in a positive way in a space that is safe and constructive. Art builds self esteem through experiencing the process of creating something from nothing and feeling proud about a finished piece.

Get Arty's program is designed to help youth enhance both independence and cooperation, and builds a sense of community. Through a variety of guest speakers and workshops integrated into the program, youth will also learn a variety of other skills such as portfolio building, which will provide information on how to pursue art as a career option. There has been countless examples of different ways youth benefit from art classes, but these benefits should not be limited, that’s why your contribution will provide access to local youth.

Our first-ever program in the Fall of 2016 will provide an opportunity for up to 20 youth. With your support and grant funding, Get Artsy will continue to hold a 12-week session, 3 times a year!

 

Why Start Get Artsy?

BY VALERIE | Founder of Get Artsy

"Ever since I was young and my dad would set up an easel in our living room to paint with me, I have always turned to art to express myself. I was fortunate enough to have the materials I need to make art at home, as well as attend a variety of art classes growing up. Now, I have planned and taught art classes for youth, and the benefits I've had and the benefits I have seen my students have from art is remarkable. However, being an Interdisciplinary Social Science major at York University, I am very passionate about social justice, and do not believe access to art programs should be limited depending on location, finances, or other circumstances. That is why this campaign is so important to me. Get Artsy’s goal is to provide access to art classes for all youth. The magnitude of what your contribution will help achieve is beyond words because the experiences youth have with the arts now can have limitless impacts on them throughout their lives."

 

What We're is Hoping for from This Campaign

Our aim is to generate $3000 in funding to launch Get Artsy’s series of 12-week art classes. This funding will be distributed to cover a variety of costs for the program. We estimate it will cost approximately $60 for each student to participate, so one option is to sponsor a student to attend the classes. However, additionally funding is also required to cover costs such as facility space, guest speakers, supplies, etc.

The campaign goal is the minimum amount of funds that we are requesting to get this program off the ground. This will cover the the supplies and location cost, but all other expenses will be covered through volunteer participation and in kind donations. Anything over our goal will be applied to additional sessions of the program throughout the year, and to help us better the current program.

In addition to providing youth with this amazing opportunity, some perks to get excited about when donating may include a social media shout, receiving an original piece of art from the students, or being named as a Presenting Sponsor.

 

Our Team and Partners


Valerie Paniccia, Founder​ & Facilitator
With experience planning and teaching a variety of programs (including art) to Brampton youth, Valerie has seen how important art can be in youth development and has a vision to make this opportunity accessible to all. Valerie has a passion for both art and social justice and is in the Concurrent Education program studying Visual Arts and Interdisciplinary Social Science at York University in hopes of making a change in the lives of youth.

Jenna Imbrogno, Assistant Facilitator
A current student at the University of Toronto, Jenna has been an artist for over 11 years. It has been her passion and hobby since she was younger. Jenna won the Herzog Hospital Art competition and her painting was sent to Israel where it is is now in the hospital wing for sick children. Jenna believes that art has the power to inspire and guide people no matter where they come from in life, and cannot wait to see how it will have a positive impact on the students Get Artsy encounters.

ACCESS, Organizational Mentor
As a youth-led organization based in Brampton, ACCESS has been making an impact locally and globally for 10 years. Today, ACCESS supports a number of new youth-led organizations and projects throughout the GTA and will be mentoring the Get Artsy program.

Therese Guidolin, Advisor
With 20 years of event planning, coordination, wedding planning and destination wedding planning experience, Therese is an active community member who has supported numerous non-profits and community projects.

Frequently Asked Questions

Why is Get Artsy different from other art classes?
Since Get Artsy is a non-profit organization, it will provide FREE art classes for youth who may not be able to afford other programming. It will also be located at the schools themselves (or very close by) right after school, which means easy access for participants. Rather than simply focusing on art skills, Get Artsy’s program planning will combine art skills with life skills such as self-confidence, dealing with issues, socializing with peers, and more.

What benefits will the participants receive from this program?
The participants will not only develop their art skills and creativity, but they will learn how to create a portfolio, how to go about pursuing art as a career option, gain confidence in themselves, as well as learn to work well and socialize with others. This program will provide a safe and constructive environment for students to go after school and develop new skills.

What do you hope to achieve at the end of the program?
By the end of the program, we hope each participant will take something away from the class, and even what to come back. What each participant will gain may vary by person. For example, one achievement may be a student getting accepted into an art school with the portfolio they built with us, whereas another achievement could simply be an individual gaining confidence and making friends. It doesn't stop at the end of a 12-week program - we hope to continue impacting more youth by offering the program throughout the year! Future volunteer opportunities will be available for "graduates" of our program.

How do you plan to create income for this program?
In addition to this initial crowdfunding campaign, we plan on fundraising through a variety of initiatives including hosting art show events and auctioning work, and grants. We are also applying for funding from various grants, to help grow the organization. 

Why is art important?
Research has shown that people who are engaged in the arts will see improvement in their overall quality of life. Art is a creative way to express oneself and deal with issues in a constructive way manner. It also establishes an individual’s sense of pride when they have something to show for their hard work.

What experience do you have in the non-profit and youth space?
The program's founder, Valerie, has been involved in countless youth initiatives both as a participant and as a leader. As a very active student, she engaged heavily in social justice initiatives and even travelled overseas to help students in developing countries. Valerie also has experience specifically coordinating, developing curriculum and facilitating similar youth arts programs through the City of Brampton. The non-profit partner, ACCESS, works directly with youth-led non-profit groups in the area, and has organized and facilitated countless workshops and conferences across the region.

Other Ways You Can Help

Other than contributing to this campaign, there are plenty of other ways to help! The more people that are aware of Get Artsy and our cause, the better. So please share our campaign using the Indiegogo share tools. If you are interested in making an in-kind donation (such as supplies or refreshments) or sponsoring the program beyond this campaign, let us know via email! We could also use volunteers to help launch our program so if you out interested in helping please get in touch! getartsy@accesscharity.ca

We are also applying for funding from various grants, to help grow the organization. Why is art important?Research has shown that people who are engaged in the arts will see improvement in their overall quality of life. Art is a creative way to express oneself and deal with issues in a constructive way manner. It also establishes an individual’s sense of pride when they have something to show for their hard work.What experience do you have in the non-profit and youth space?The program's founder, Valerie, has been involved in countless youth initiatives both as a participant and as a leader. As a very active student, she engaged heavily in social justice initiatives and even travelled overseas to help students in developing countries. Valerie also has experience specifically coordinating, developing curriculum and facilitating similar youth arts programs through the City of Brampton. The non-profit partner, ACCESS, works directly with youth-led non-profit groups in the area, and has organized and facilitated countless workshops and conferences across the region.Other Ways You Can HelpOther than contributing to this campaign, there are plenty of other ways to help! The more people that are aware of Get Artsy and our cause, the better. So please share our campaign using the Indiegogo share tools. If you are interested in making an in-kind donation (such as supplies or refreshments) or sponsoring the program beyond this campaign, let us know via email! We could also use volunteers to help launch our program so if you out interested in helping please get in touch! getartsy@accesscharity.ca

story:
Las Juntas del Pizote (Coati Company) is a four-piece band based in Puerto Jiménez in the Osa Peninsula of Costa Rica – a tiny landmass, but one that is home to 2.5% of all of the species on the planet!

Their original folk music tells the story of the people and wildlife of the peninsula, and raises awareness about the need to conserve nature for future generations to enjoy and benefit from. Despite only forming one year ago, the band was selected to play at the 2016 Costa Rican National Festival of Art and the ‘Pizotes’ have become household names in the peninsula. It’s time for them to reach out to more schools and communities and make the biggest impact possible, and for that they need a speaker system of their own.

All four members are educators and conservationists and the band is committed to a not-for-profit agenda to promote environmental and social responsibility, contextualized in the cultural history of the region. Their environmental education program, OsArte, created by singer-songwriter Mauricio Gutiérrez, uses puppets and masks depicting characters such as “Danta Amaranta” (Amaranta the Tapir) and “Jaguar Jorge” (George the Jaguar) – protagonists in plays and songs performed by the band – to engage with schoolchildren and raise awareness of environmental and socioeconomic issues.

Other songs, such as “Historia de los Oreos y Mil Cuentos” (The Story of the Gold Miners and a Thousand Tales) and “Cumbia Campesino” (The Peasants’ Cumbia), champion community leaders past and present, and aim to foment social responsibility, inclusivity, ambition and leadership within local youth.

A long-term objective of the band is to raise money to convert an old school bus into a mobile platform for performances and educational workshops, and to create activity kits containing handmade puppets, games and audiovisual materials for distribution to local schools. Acquiring a reliable, portable speaker system is the first step toward realizing that dream.

The group has already invested in the instruments, mixers, monitors and other hardware, but needs to raise $4,000 to cover the cost of purchasing two Yamaha DSR115 loudspeakers, plus stands and cables. If the campaign is successful, the band will commit to providing workshops and performances at least 15 local schools and 5 regional festivals during 2017!

Every donation counts, no matter how large or small, so please pledge whatever you can. And don't forget to check out the perks on offer, including limited edition t-shirts and fan packs!

If you can’t donate but would like to help, please use the Indiegogo share tools to share this page as much as you can with your friends, family and networks, as somebody you know might be able to help.

The children of the tiny communities of the Osa Peninsula will inherit a huge responsibility to protect one of the world’s last great hotspots of biodiversity. Help them to understand the nature of this irreplaceable gift, and all of the joy, prosperity and opportunity that its preservation will bring to them.

story:
Leon first came to the Sprouts Program when he was 4 years old. At first he was solitary and withdrawn. He hung back when other children engaged, and lived in his own world with no language of his own.

But one morning when I came to him at the SRPOUTS program, Leon was blooming with new energy, excitement and health.  He looked like a new child. A wild child! His face had lit up, he had red cheeks, a wide smile and sparkling eyes.  His language, all but nonexistent a few months before, was bursting forth.

Leon took me by the hand and led me to his favorite fort built out of sticks and saplings. Choosing a story he found set out on a blanket he crawled inside the stick house, invited me in, and asked me to read. Afterwards, he took my hand again and pulled me off on a tour of the woods.

 I watched Leon throughout the morning.  He was curious! He was initiating! Most importantly, he was learning how to play.  He had plenty of time to explore, discover, and investigate without interruption.

The therapeutic benefits of taking children outside for long stretches of time, do not stop with children like Leon. For sure, the gains observed in children labeled with a special need  are often dramatically observable in our SPROUTS Programs. But every child who interacts regularly with the natural world benefits from the sensory balance, the fresh air, the sunlight, the crisp cold wind, and the wide-open space. The difficult behaviors observed in an indoor setting mostly disappear outside. 

To make this possible for Leon and his friends, our SPROUTS  children need good-quality, sturdy outdoor gear to keep them warm and dry. They will be  playing and learning outdoors for at least four hours a day but many of the children we serve are unable to afford this cost  and don't want anyone to be left indoors!

Please help us reach our goal to provide a full complement of appropriate, high quality outdoor gear and equipment for every SPROUTS child. There is no bad weather. Just bad dressing for the weather!

Wild Child Gear Kits each cost around $300 each and include rain gear, boots, mittens,  hats, snow gear, and natural fiber underlayers.

SPROUTS is a Program of Broadbeach Family and community services located on the Maine Coast in Belfast, Maine.  Sprouts is part of a growing national movement offering place-based nature education experiences for young children age 2.5 to 5 years old. Sprouts  uses the High Scope Curriculum and is open to all children,  We offer a strong therapeutic component for children with special needs. There are no residency requirements. For more information visit www.brmaine.org, or call Vicky at 207-338-2200.

story:
Who am I and what is California Institute of the Arts?

I am an Egyptian stage lighting designer; my name is Omar Madkour. I am a graduate of the Theatre Program at the American University in Cairo '11 and currently a freelance stage lighting designer. My designs have been presented locally and internationally in professional venues and festivals. www.omarmadkour.com/lightportfolio 

CalArts is one of the biggest names in the arts academia; A school that was established by Walt Disney in the 60’s and today has less than 29% acceptance rate.

 

Financial Breakdown

Reference to the CalArts link here and the dorms link here, the money raised for year one will be used as follows:

$ 616 – obligatory administration fee

$ 4,500 – Meals/grocery

$ 2,000 – transportation

$ 3,000 – medical insurance

$ 2,000 – books and supplies

$ 8,260 – accommodation in school dorms

$ 1,000 – travel and visa expenses

--------------------

$ 21,170 – Total

 

 

If you are contemplating donating your money to art education, I would like to encourage you because 10% of the sum I collect will be contributed to Artichoke studio in Beirut, Lebanon for their work with Syrian refugee kids through art therapy.  

“Art therapy is a mental health profession that uses the creative process of art making to improve the physical, mental and emotional well‐being of individuals of all ages.” (American Art Therapy Association, 2012)

Art therapy offers the children affected by war a safe space to work through their fears and pain.

Facilitated by a qualified art therapist, the sessions help them in building their resilience. It provides them with time to play, grief, connect with each other and find hope.

For their 10%, Artichoke Studio would offer:

With $1,000 – 12 sessions over 3 months for 2 children in need

With $1,500 – 12 sessions over 3 months for 3 children in need

With $2,000 – 12 sessions over 3 months for one group of 6 children in need

With $2,500 – 12 sessions over 3 months for two groups of 12 children in need

info@artichokestudio.org - www.artichokestudio.org

 

 

Your contributions’ impact

Your kind and generous contributions can help reshape my artistic future and my professional input as a designer.

 

  1. Besides enhancing my artistic and technical skills in designing for the theatre. I would be able to introduce technical extravaganza shows in closed and open spaces.
  2. The Egyptian city of Luxor has 1/3 of the world’s ancient monuments. The rest of Egypt has a lot more museums, temples and sites. One of the dream projects I have is to design a magnificent night tour with lights and visuals in those sites and temples. I believe a school like CalArts is a great place to prep for such project.
  3. Your contributions would allow me follow a dream of revamping the academia of stage design in Egypt; not through private education and workshops, but hopefully through national education that is more accessible to most Egyptian artists.
  4. Unfortunately, lighting design in Egypt is not recognised for it can actually present. Lighting and projection design can be used in civil architectural lighting. A neighbourhood or a street can be something else because of how its lit. A live example is El Moez street in Cairo.

 

If you cannot donate but still want to help

If you want to reach me

You can still be a great help and support by sharing my campaign and/or recommending funders to me. I am reachable via o_madkour@aucegypt.edu

story:
"Every Child has Right for Education"

 

Early Marriage and circumcision for the young Maasai girls.

Imagine a world where every child is educated and can contribute to the development process!!

So many times parents in Maasai  areas tend to give away their young girls for marriage in exchange for just a kilogram of sugar, a goat, a cow , some tea leaves and sometimes for salt. These young girls are then subjected to domestic violence, torture, early child birth and many times girls have died while giving birth because their bodies are never ready to experience child birth.

Many times the parents to these girls need to be empowered with information about the benefits of keeping their children in school until they complete their education. Once these girls have acquired the education, they can provide all the above mentioned items to their parents for the rest of their lives. All that parents need to to practice some bit of patience and sacrifice a little in order to enjoy the fruits of their children.

Circumcision for the women is prohibited but Maasai societies they still circumcise their young girls. We are working hard to educate them so that they can stop this.

Its time to reach out to the parents in the Maasai land settings and sensitize them if we want a better future for girls. A future where they can participate in leadership positions. A future where they can make informed choices and start up families the the men of their choice.

The time is now. Lets teach the Parents because they need this knowledge.

Maasai girls

Young Boys:  Young boys normally are send to keep cows and goats far away from home and come back evening everyday. Others they like to go to school but not allowed to go!!

Young Maasai Kids in the bush keeping cows

Education: Most of Maasai children don't go to school due to the environment they are living. Their parent don't understand the importance of their children to get better education. So we are trying our level best to educate these Maasai societies so that they can allow their children to go to school. Also there are scarcity of nearest school in their areas so we are working hard to build school near them to attract and convince their parent to allow them to attend school.

Our effort made us to start building Pambazuka Naisinyai School http://www.pambazuka.sc.tz  for which this school started under the tree but with our own effort we have managed to build some two classes and bought some desks so we need to work hard to make it happen!!

 

WHY THIS CAMPAIGN IS IMPORTANT

We decided to start a school in Maasai society so as to convince the Maasai on Education. Maasai society is leaving a life with no permanent settlement, thus not getting a chance for schooling. Also the society lives a life of animal husbandry which is difficult for parents to allow their children in distant schools due to they depend of them for rearing animals. Therefore starting a school within Maasai society will convince parents allowing their children to attend school near by them. That is the school I started within Maasai society is purposely to help the Maasai children. It is called PAMBAZUKA NAISINYAI PRE & PRIMARY SCHOOL         http://www.pambazuka.sc.tz   . Already our school has grade one (1) with 65 pupils , grade two with 55 and grade three with 35  pupils and 4 teachers who use most of their time teaching the children for most of them can’t speak neither Swahili nor English, but Maasai language.

Our School Started under the tree

Our school started under the tree as we do not have resources to help us for building classes for the Maasai children. Education should start with their parents to educate them so that they can know the importance of education to their children. Some of the parents are now aware about education to their children so they are allowing them to attend school. We are still talking to the parents so that they can give us a good cooperation.

 

 NEW TWO CLASSES

Through our own efforts we have managed to build two classes where grade one and two are using for studying. We have more 10 acres where we want to build more classes as we have more students coming soon. We want to build more classes up to seven classes, we also need to build kitchen, toilet as the one we have is not enough, computers and computer lab, well for keeping water as there is scarcity of water, desks, books, office for teachers, salaries for teachers.

Our two New Classes

My future plans are to have secondary school up to university among Maasai society in order to have education nearby so as to fight poverty by getting good education.

  The importance of this campaign is to construct a school within Maasai society, also helping Maasai society withdraw from ignorance and illiteracy so a t cope with the changes of the world.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to do the following so that we can get our school off the ground; Seven more classes, computer room, Library, computers, Office for the staff, Kitchen, Good toilet, Reading books, tank for water storage and bin maize and beans storage, lunch for the teachers and students, salaries for teachers, Scholarship and to build fence around the school. The estimation costs is $250,000.  "Every bit will help"

 

Desks: We have managed to buy some desks for one class so class one will not sit on the ground again. Please support us so that we can buy more desks and build more classes!!

THE FOLLOWING ARE THE REASONS AS TO WHY MY PROJECT IS VALUABLE TO DONORS AND THE WORLD

  This project is very important to donors and world at large for it will connect us with Maasai society for they shall be able to communicate with different people of different nations of the world. Also this will give chance for donors to come and visit Maasai society and learn the real life and culture of Maasai. Apart from that it also helps to eradicate the number of illiterates in the world.

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

1. Due to studying environment being of low standard life, it is difficult to get skilled teachers and faithful constructors.

2. Another challenge is teacher's salaries, where by in order to get good trainers you also have to pay them well.

3. Another challenge is that , the pupils are fluently speaking Maasai native language, while their teachers don’t know the language and thus difficult to teach them

4. Due to that parents couldn’t get education, and then they find no importance to take their children to school.

 

 HOW TO OVERCOME THE CHALLENGES

1. Improving the teaching environment so as to encourage trained teachers to come and teach in our school. Also getting enough trusted constructors for constructing the building.

2. Increasing teacher's salaries so as to motivate the coming of more teachers.

3. Educating parents’ house by house on the importance of taking their children to school.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please tell friends and family about our campaign and our socially-good mission!

Please share our campaign page through the IndieGoGo share buttons on our campaign page!

Please share our campaign on your social networks such as facebook, twitter e.t.c

Thank you very much for your support! Every bit is greatly appreciated!

 

 

The Perks!!

T- Shirt (Will send your size and different color with different images)

 

Maasai Children Photo!!

 

Big 5 Photo!! ( We will send you one photo of Big 5)

 

Maasai Shuka ( There are of different types for men and women) will send one pair.

 

Hat with Kilimanjaro word or any other photo of wildlife in Tanzania

 

School website: www.pambazuka.sc.tz

Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/Pambazuka-Naisinyai-Sc...

Twitter:   https://twitter.com/PambazukaSchool

Thank you very much for your support! Every bit is greatly appreciated!

 
 
The Perks!!
T- Shirt (Will send your size and different color with different images)

 
Maasai Children Photo!!

 
Big 5 Photo!! ( We will send you one photo of Big 5)

 
Maasai Shuka ( There are of different types for men and women) will send one pair.

 
Hat with Kilimanjaro word or any other photo of wildlife in Tanzania

 
School website: www.pambazuka.sc.tz
Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/Pambazuka-Naisinyai-Sc...
Twitter:   https://twitter.com/PambazukaSchool

story:
Short Summary

Every 26 seconds, a student drops out of high school.

The Route247 movement wants to stamp out this statistic with a new one: 

Every 26 seconds, a high school student shares a success story.

The old adage “It takes a village to raise a child” could not be truer than it is today. Route247’s virtual village unites students, parents, teachers and the community on a platform that connects students to valuable opportunities in and outside of their school. These opportunities include: volunteering, internships, jobs, scholarships, and challenges, all of which empower students to strengthen themselves, their school community and their greater community.

On paper, the Route247 team consists of duo-Maria and Lisa. Between us, we have worked in education on three different continents at the elementary, middle and high school levels in both the public and private sectors. But the real Route247 team extends to the countless parents, students, teachers, school administrators, business owners, and community members who have provided insight, feedback, enthusiasm and motivation.  Thank you for helping us to construct the blueprint for this vision and for continuing to campaign on behalf of Route247.

With over 15 million high school students in the United States, Route247 can make a considerable change in the lives of many. Join the movement to make our national dropout crisis a thing of the past. Seize this present moment and help change our future!


What We Need & What You Get

Thanks to the generosity of a corporate sponsor as well as a private donor, we were able to construct a functional skeleton of the program and technology. After just a week of promotional videos in a local high school, over 400 students expressed interest in a Route247 leadership position. Having started this program rooted in the confidence that students are willing, capable, and incredible agents of change, we were inspired by this response. A couple of months into the 2015-16 academic year, we had over 700 students and 40 teachers registered within the high school. In a nearby elementary school, we worked with a single classroom of 19 students. Field-testing certain components of the program, we were able to garner feedback from education administrators, teachers, students, parents, businesses, web developers, legal counsel, and countless others. This helped determine the changes to the technology, curriculum and program logistics necessary for Route247 to be more meaningful and impactful.

It will take approximately $60,000 to make the necessary upgrades to this innovative technology, so it is more user-friendly, secure, automated, aesthetically-pleasing, scalable, and adaptable. That certainly seems like a hefty sum until we consider just two (of the many) alternatives: 

Each year’s class of dropouts costs our country $200 billion in lost earnings and lost tax revenue in their lifetimes.

Cutting that number in half nationally would decrease annual Medicaid spending by as much as $7.3 billion.


The Impact

Did you find yourself often bored in class?

Did you ever wish your school experience had better prepared you for life after school?

Did you find out much later in life that you were good at or enjoyed something you didn't previously know about?

Whether as a student, parent, or teacher, have you ever been frustrated with our education system, but unsure how to change it?

Do you want to help increase students’ motivation in school?

Do you want to make schools more positive learning environments?

Do you want to help students connect what they are learning in the classroom to real world experiences?

Do you want to empower students to take charge of their educational journey?

Do you believe students are capable of seizing opportunities now that can help shape this workforce of tomorrow?

Are you looking to expand your markets?

Do you want to test and implement unique challenges?

Do you want to help graduate students who are more responsible and ready?

If you answered yes! to any of these questions, then answer yes! to joining our village, YOUR village. In doing so, you can help empower students to be confident, compassionate adults who have the resources and tools to turn their dreams into a shared reality. 


Risks & Challenges

With the educational technology boom, we did not want to reinvent the wheel. And, of course, there are projects out there doing incredible things with both bigger budgets and bigger spheres of influence.

However, we are carving out a nice niche by several distinguishing features, inlcuding:

1.  We are one of the only student-run programs out there.

2.  When a school licenses the program, every student can create an account. That program equity ensures that each student has access to Route247’s opportunities, perks and benefits.

3.  As a significant indicator of a student’s academic success, parental involvement factors into both the technology design as well as the opportunities.

4.  There is a curriculum component to the program so that these opportunities, although experiential-based, compliment classroom learning.

5.  Web-based platforms invite more collaboration than competition. Integrating with others, we can devise ways to enrich our individual endeavors, expand our reach and affect greater change.

We are proud to say that we have already received endorsements from several parties in the educational community, including the local superintendent’s office. With this forward momentum, we are on track to expand this virtual village across the United States!


Other Ways You Can Help

Wouldn’t it be beautiful to hear the national dialogue on education boast: Every 26 seconds, a high school student shares a success story?

It has a nice ring to it, doesn’t it? Let’s start our success stories here. Of course, no contribution is too small; every dollar counts! But even if you are unable to donate at this time, you can still be an agent of change. Help us to spread the word about Route247’s movement. Use your 26 seconds to like our Facebook page, check out our website, and create and submit opportunities for students.

story:
The goal of this project is to print copies of a children's book titled "The Innovative Engine" and donate them to public libraries and elementary schools from L.A to N.Y.C. 100% of your contributions will go towards printing copies of this book.

The story involves child bloggers traveling aboard the Innovative Engine from N.Y.C to California. Along the way, they meet fairy tale characters  sharing their "true" stories. Themes include kindness, technology, innovation and the environment. 

For example, the children meet Ms. Muffett. It turns out she is interested in capturing spiders, writing observations and releasing them back into the wild. The children also decide to rip out train car seats and create a traveling garden.

What do I know about children's books? I taught elementary school for eight years from London to San Francisco and am currently a Ph.D. candidate in the field of education.  

My brother, the illustrator, is a talented tattoo artist. His work was showcased on BuzzFeed in their Tattoos of 2015 video. He is currently working on coloring in the final illustrations for this project. Help us share this innovative tale and art.

We (and young readers across the U.S.A) thank you for your support!

story:
Hello, I'm Helen from Flourish Partners, my business partner, Justin and I are passionate about Lyme Disease and our company is in the process of developing a diagnostic test that will be available in 3 formats.

1) An over the counter test - bought in the supermarket or pharmacy.

2) A digital test that can be utilized in the doctors office using biomarkers

3) A lab test.

Please see the image gallery to give you an idea as to what the tests will look like.

Imagine being able to go to the store to buy a test or the local pharmacy - you can test yourself or your children.

Initially, we were just going to complete an over the counter test, as the Lyme community are so aware of the tick hazard and would make the decision to buy a test themselves. However, as there is so much competition with Angel, Venture Capital and Grant funding, we took advice from some of the really successful healthcare venture capital groups, who suggested that we introduce a digital element to our test as this makes us much more attractive to the investment association - so we've done this.  The amount of funding that we are requesting in this campaign will get us to the point of the tests being finished - then we have to raise even more funds for clinical trials, quality and regulatory approval and all commercialization activity.

The more financial support we can get from the Lyme community the less money we will have to borrow from the investment community - which in the long run is better for all of us as we will have more funds available to be able to re-invest back into the Lyme community rather than having to give an investor upwards of 40-50% return on their investment. - Please remember we are self funded so far, we believe that we can make a difference and it would be great if you did too.

None of these tests are based on blood - we're using urine as we feel from a scientific perspective this is a better route.

We've spent a very long time looking at Lyme and the impact that it has on families, clinicians and health economics globally. It is apparent that there are great difficulties in diagnosing Lyme Disease and the impact of this is catastrophic.  Yes we are profit making, but our intention is to commercialize these tests and then utilize the money we generate to continue further research into Lyme and also to help fund patients with treatment.  

We feel that the majority of currently funded Lyme Disease research has done little or nothing for the Lyme Patient Community. We want to change that and be as patient-centric as we can. We don't want to be confused with Big Pharma; we are a group of people who want to make a difference in this awful disease.

Developing diagnostics is very expensive; however our test will rule Lyme in or out.

Therefore not only will it be able to diagnose Lyme, it will see if the bacteria are still present after a treatment regime.  From all of the tweets @flourishinfo we get on a daily basis, we know how devastating this disease is, how expensive Lyme diagnosis and treatment is, many people are having to travel internationally to find an LLMD - yet their hands can often be tied too as they can only utilize the tests that are available to them.

Staci Grodin of Global Lyme Alliance states on their corporate video that "there is not a reliable diagnostic tool available first step, do you have the illness, do you not have the illness?" - this is exactly what we are confident that we can and will achieve.

What We Need & What You Get 

We need a huge amount of money.  Ordinarily it can cost up to $5-6m  to develop a diagnostic test and we've been using our own funds to get us to where we are, but we just can't generate enough to be able to get the tests to market.

There are regulatory, clinical trials, screening, sales, marketing, alliances, that all need to be completed. 

  • Ordinarily it can take 3 years to get a diagnostic test to the market - however, with the work that we have already completed, our proprietary know how, skills, expertise, drive and determination we are confident that we can complete our tests by early 2017.

We're very excited to report that people have been offering us their blood and urine to utilise during testing on twitter - lyme sufferers see the need for what we are trying to achieve.

  • funding is competitive - we appreciate that there are other projects out there, but we feel ours is so important we won't stop till we get it. It's risky as are all science projects, but with years of experience, drive and determination, we feel that this is worth a shot - because if it does work it will change the lives of Lyme patients on a global basis for evermore.
  • We want to complete other Lyme Projects and help as many people as we can, whether it's education or funding.
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, all funds will be used towards this project. 

The Impact

It's important to point out that we know that Lyme is not just a US disease, more cases are being reported on a global basis.

Lyme costs $1.3b USD per year to treat in the US - a lot of patients have to travel internationally to get diagnosis and treatment protocols.

Presently there are no figures as to how much Lyme costs in the UK & Europe for example, but we know that cases are on the increase and it is not only the financial costs that are a burden.

There are more cases of Lyme each year diagnosed than some cancers, yet it is treated very differently.  People are dying, they are being treated for many different diseases as we all know that Lyme is the great mimicker. This is just so wrong  Adults & children are accused of faking their illness or diagnosed with having taken a drug overdose  - please see the video I uploaded. I can't imagine how it must feel to feel really ill everyday, yet not be believed and to not be able to get an accurate diagnosis.

I could go on and on about Lyme disease and its impact and our 16k tweets refer to it everyday - by developing our tests this is our effort to try and diagnose Lyme disease and to help, nothing more,  nothing less. 

We know that these tests will make a huge difference and we'll never lose sight of that and what we are trying to achieve.

  • Lyme could end up in your family; all it takes is an infected tick bite and it is happening every day . Help us help you - if it happens, you can take our test and go to the doctors for some treatment straight away. This would minimize the risk of the disease becoming chronic.The tests will be available globally - that's our plan.
  • Also if you already have been diagnosed with Lyme Disease and are having treatment, our test could illustrate whether or not the bacteria are still present - therefore if the treatment protocol is successfully combatting/not effective for the disease in your body, our test would be extremely useful to you and your clinician.
  • We're all extremely successful scientists, commercial, marketing, sales specialists who have managed projects like this before, but the difference with this one is that it isn't for a huge global company, it is for ourselves, a team committed to Lyme Disease and making an impact on global patient health.


Risks & Challenges

 Science is risky, but with the skill, experience and know how we will bring these tests to market. We're confident we can do this and we're compelled to as we know the difference it can and will make to people's lives.

We already have the POCT platform and the digital element complete, so the risk of failure is realtively low.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share as much information about Lyme as you can, there are many Lyme alliance groups that can help and offer advice - the more noise we make about Lyme Disease the better!


THANK YOU FOR READING THIS CAMPAIGN.

story:
**Video made by JustTV in Winnipeg**

Short Summary

Four Directions Cooperative Centre for Trauma Recovery Inc. is a revolutionary cooperative development aimed at reducing suffering and maintaining wellness among trauma affected young people. 

The vision for the program is to create a multi-faceted residential care centre in Teulon, Manitoba, that will service trauma affected youth to proactively help them become healthy, positive members of our communities. There has been a wealth of research done on how to best structure the program and we are happy to get further into that if you want to understand the why's and how's of what the facility will look like.

In the first year we will be servicing the community as an event centre where all profits will go towards the running of the residential care facility. We will be running programs on an outpatient basis. 

Please click on the link in the update section to view a brochure for the centre to get a full view of what it will look like and the research behind the project.

What We Need & What You Get

Through community partnerships and government organizations our dream of opening a facility to transfer youth out of hotel rooms and into caring environments with experienced staff is coming to fruition. However, we need capital to be able to open the facility, which government organizations are not able to provide. 

We are looking for donations, or individuals to buy into the cooperative, to make this a reality. As a co-operative member, you would have the opportunity to participate as a board member, planning committees, interested community member, and voting rights on upcoming decisions. 

The Impact

The need for trauma recovery care for our youth in CFS care is growing. It is observed within the systems to which this population belongs that there are increasing rates of involvement related to maladaptive coping from traumatic experience. Involvement and re-involvement in the criminal justice system, hospitalization due to long wait times into addiction treatment and stabilization services. The growing rates of involvement into gang culture and lateral violence  reflects the increasing need for intensive, safe, flexible and sustainable helping resources for this particular vulnerable population. 

FDCCTR offers a safe and comfortable environment to begin trauma based healing, using sustainable means within one's body, mind, emotions, and spirit. With a team of supports surrounding the individual within and beyond the centre, participants may have opportunity to best utilize an extension of care by adopting sustainable healing and coping techniques, discover untapped skills and develop unique human capacity. 

We have the ability to change the course of an individuals life, to better our communities, and provide opportunities not otherwise provided. What better way to make a difference in our community than to start with our young people, helping them find their way, and make a real difference in the lives of those around us. 

Risks & Challenges

Our major challenges at this point hinge on long term funding. Often, organizations who are willing to fund projects such as this require proof of the program's success. To be able to provide the proof that we know is  possible we need to cover start up costs. 

The facility, land, staffing, and all mandatory arrangements are in order and ready to be rolled out as soon as we have the funds we need. Similar facilities exist in other areas of Canada, and it is time to bring the model to Manitoba. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please pass this on to others who you believe may be interested in joining our co-operative. Share it on facebook, spread the word. It is through individuals that we can make a collective difference.

We will be running programs on an outpatient basis. Please click on the link in the update section to view a brochure for the centre to get a full view of what it will look like and the research behind the project.What We Need & What You GetThrough community partnerships and government organizations our dream of opening a facility to transfer youth out of hotel rooms and into caring environments with experienced staff is coming to fruition. However, we need capital to be able to open the facility, which government organizations are not able to provide. We are looking for donations, or individuals to buy into the cooperative, to make this a reality. As a co-operative member, you would have the opportunity to participate as a board member, planning committees, interested community member, and voting rights on upcoming decisions. The ImpactThe need for trauma recovery care for our youth in CFS care is growing. It is observed within the systems to which this population belongs that there are increasing rates of involvement related to maladaptive coping from traumatic experience. Involvement and re-involvement in the criminal justice system, hospitalization due to long wait times into addiction treatment and stabilization services. The growing rates of involvement into gang culture and lateral violence  reflects the increasing need for intensive, safe, flexible and sustainable helping resources for this particular vulnerable population. FDCCTR offers a safe and comfortable environment to begin trauma based healing, using sustainable means within one's body, mind, emotions, and spirit. With a team of supports surrounding the individual within and beyond the centre, participants may have opportunity to best utilize an extension of care by adopting sustainable healing and coping techniques, discover untapped skills and develop unique human capacity. We have the ability to change the course of an individuals life, to better our communities, and provide opportunities not otherwise provided. What better way to make a difference in our community than to start with our young people, helping them find their way, and make a real difference in the lives of those around us. Risks & ChallengesOur major challenges at this point hinge on long term funding. Often, organizations who are willing to fund projects such as this require proof of the program's success. To be able to provide the proof that we know is  possible we need to cover start up costs. The facility, land, staffing, and all mandatory arrangements are in order and ready to be rolled out as soon as we have the funds we need. Similar facilities exist in other areas of Canada, and it is time to bring the model to Manitoba. Other Ways You Can HelpPlease pass this on to others who you believe may be interested in joining our co-operative. Share it on facebook, spread the word. It is through individuals that we can make a collective difference.

story:
Youko video link - http://v.youku.com/v_show/id_XMTU2MjIzODAwOA==.... 
正在阅读这篇文章的朋友们你们好，我是Hakob，今年18岁，来自亚美尼亚。我现在正在世界联合学院大西洋分校(United World College of Atlantic)读书，并拿到了全额奖学金。我通过了亚美尼亚UWC理事会的选拔，从250个候选人中脱颖而出，取得全额奖学金。除了在学校，我同时也参与了很多俱乐部，项目，会议，都由国际组织，及本地的NGO（非政府组织）组织举办。

很小的时候我就开始做志愿者，帮助本地组织，参与不同的竞赛，还帮助学校组织活动。

我同时也和亚美尼亚的一些政府官员有交流，参与国民议会，总统府，在国家的其它方面也有积极参与。

我的丰富经验帮助我成功。

下面是我的一些证书。


今天，我有一些消息要和你分享

好消息是...

我最近收到了一些来自英国（伦敦大学国王学院）和美国（森林湖学院）的大学的录取通知书，学习欧洲政治本科课程。伦敦大学国王学院是世界排名前20的大学之一，有着优异的课程设置与校友。有些校友是诺贝尔奖获得者，有些在国际组织里工作（如联合国），还有一些为国家政府工作....来自超过250个社会组织持续不断的支持和广泛的资源将能够支持我继续我的社会工作。国王学院正是我梦想的学校，我也十分希望能够在那里继续学业。

坏消息是...

...为了能够在国王学院里学习，我需要每年支付£29,072的学费

不幸的是，我的家庭并不能够支付这么大一笔钱。

我的妈妈在我八岁的时候离世，我的爸爸接起了照顾我和我的双胞胎妹妹的任务。由于我的父亲是二等残疾，他从政府收到的抚恤金仅能够维续他在亚美尼亚的日常支出。

钱现在成了最大的问题，我本人却认为钱不应该成为我和教育之间的绊脚石。


今天，我需要你帮助我继续我的教育

你给我的任何一笔捐款都将改变我的人生。请把我的募捐运动分享给你的朋友们并帮我筹集这一笔钱！我永远不会忘记你对我的帮助，并且我永远会在你需要的时候帮助你！


大学支出


为了能够申请英国的签证，我需要在7月1日前集齐几乎所有钱。2016-2017学年我需要：

学费  £16,250

住宿 £9,000

食物  £2,000

其它  £1500

签证  £322

共计  £29,072


学费信息 - http://www.kcl.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/fees-and-funding/tuition-fees.aspx

住宿 -  http://www.kcl.ac.uk/study/accommodation/residences/stamford-street-apartments.aspx 

在线上募捐的同时，我也申请了许多不同的奖学金项目，为了凑齐大学学费。我已经向Gulbenkian基金会递交了申请，也会向AGBU奖学金申请。

 

如果你能够帮助我完成我的募捐目标，我感激万分！教育就是为了改变这个世界，我也十分肯定我能够完成！你今天帮助了我，就相当于帮助了未来的世界。


直接捐款


如果你不可以在线支付，你也可以直接给我的银行帐户付款，具体细节如下：


姓名: Hakob Parsamyan

银行: Lloyds Bank

Swift/BIC: LOYDGB21699

IBAN: GB46 LOYD 3067 3480 5318 68

账户号码: 80531868


我的一些成就

参与2015罗马模拟联合国会议的证书

“Hazaran Blbul”音乐节的大奖，该音乐节由亚美尼亚共和国的文化部举办

在"The Leader in Me"英语夏令营当老师的证书

参与由AVPBritain举办的“alternatives to violence”项目的证书

成功参与“What? Where? When?”益智游戏的证书

第六届泛亚美尼亚奥林匹亚（由亚美尼亚共和国科教部组织）的历史和音乐方面的最佳参与者

在亚美尼亚写作比赛（Zoravar Andranik Museum组织）中获得第三名

亚美尼亚青年组织会组织的活动的优秀参会者

参与ReCAP项目（由Save the Children国际组织组织的）的证书
