story:
About this project

Remake – We Make and how our project came about

I’m Lucy Bullivant and I’m an architecture curator and author, and the Editor-in-chief of Urbanista.org, my webzine founded to promote liveable urbanism for the 90%. We recently received an invitation we could not refuse, to make a thematic exhibition we’ve called ‘Remake - We Make’ to be part of the 2015 Bi-City Biennale of Urbanism and Architecture (Shenzhen) – UABB (SZ)* the prestigious international cultural event taking place this winter in the city of Shenzhen, in China's Pearl River Delta. The Biennale, including our exhibition, opens to the public on 5 Dec 2015, and the last day for public viewing is 28 Feb 2016. You will be able to find 'Remake - We Make' in the collateral section of the event, at its main venue, a converted flour factory at its site in Shekou, Shenzhen.

Taking ‘Re-Living the City’ as its theme, the Biennale asks in what ways a future vision for the city and its Pearl River Delta region can be humanistic. Mindful of the perils of ignoring the consequences of fast urbanisation, the Biennale addresses issues of reduced natural resources and land, deterioration of environment and climate, industrial transformation, food safety and aging population.

*Chief Curators: Aaron Betsky, a critic and curator who directed the Venice International Architecture Biennale 2008 and is now Dean of the Frank Lloyd Wright School of Architecture; Alfredo Brillembourg and Hubert Klumpner, who are founders of Urban-Think Tank (U-TT) and together hold a Chair of the Department of Architecture and Urban Design at ETH Zurich, and Doreen Heng Liu, founder and principal of NODE Architecture and Adjunct Associate Professor at the School of Architecture at the Chinese University of Hong Kong.

At the heart of designing with and for the everyday is understanding the local challenges, assets, patterns, diversities and desires across communities. Instead of urban development plans - usually abstract in nature - the Biennale looks at how people are actually living in the city, and shows projects that ‘re-live’ the city by reinventing what exists through reuse and rethinking of existing buildings and urban spaces. The Biennale takes the Chinese concept of ‘cheng shi yuan dian’ (which means ‘thinking about change’), and shows local and international proposals actively responding to people’s lived experiences and to existing settings, inventing improvements for streets, parks, buildings and small insertions into specific public spaces.

 

What Re Make – We Make includes:

To respond to the Biennale’s theme and play a role as part of the event, we’re raising money to create ‘Remake – We Make’, our exhibition in two parts:

A collaboration with the talented young UK-Norwegian team, WORKSHOP architecture founded by Clementine Blakemore, Alexander Furunes and Ivar Tutturen who will lead a participative design-build process to make a multi-use structure in local recycled timber, together with students from University of Shenzhen with Professor Xian Guo, Professor, and Professor Yan Gao, University       of Hong Kong. The structure will be presented at the Biennale in a spacious         former flour factory, now renovated for cultural events, creating a facility where discussions and some craft work can take place. 

From 5 Dec visitors will be able to view a set of short documentary films compiled by film director Paul McHale about WORKSHOP architecture’s activities in Tachloban, the Philippines after the recent tsunamis; Chandar Nagar, India and in the UK, plus other innovative architectural practitioners working with communities to build and enrich the commons of UK cities, each of which have carved out a unique reputation for inventive and responsive solutions: the collective Assemble, nominated for the Turner Prize 2015, 00 Architecture + Studio Weave and Carl Turner Architects.  

Our films will be screened on a continuous basis within the exhibition during Biennale opening hours. From 12 Dec 2015 the space will feature reading/browsing copies of Recoded City: Co-creating urban futures, a new 320 page, extensively illustrated book on participatory placemaking with commissioned info-graphics revealing design and decision-making processes, co-authored by Lucy Bullivant and Thomas Ermacora, founder of Clear Village, the tactical urbanism non-profit, Limewharf futures gallery and Machines Room, east London. 

Advance news and updates on the design-build structure workshop, and some talks and a discussion that will be held during the Biennale up to early Feb before its closing date of 28 Feb 2016, will be posted on the wall of Remake - We Make at the Biennale, and on Lucy Bullivant's webzine on liveable urbanism, Urbanista.org. A short film about the 'Remake - We Make' collaborative design and build process in Shenzhen will be made and added to the exhibition's film presentation for viewing by visitors in Jan 2016. We welcome audience comments and feedback in the comments section of the 'Remake - We Make' essays on Urbanista.org after publication from early Dec 2015.

 

Communicating the value

‘Remake – We Make’ takes its cue from the social action focus of the Biennale.    We want not only to think about positive change through urban design, but communicate exceptional examples of it. We will therefore also feature our small (100m2) and memorable exhibition from the UK on Urbanista.org. so through a story board on its progress, a global audience can see how it develops, and also watch the short films we will show as part of the exhibition.

So ‘Remake – We Make’ will have a life after the exhibition closes on 28 Feb 2016. Not only will the films will be available for viewing on the Urbanista.org webzine and Vimeo.com, but the structure made by WORKSHOP architecture and the University of Shenzhen student team we hope to donate to a community organization in Shenzhen.

 

Following our earlier urban innovation project…

‘Remake – We Make’ comes on the heels of the hugely successful exhibition, ‘Urbanistas: women innovators in architecture, urban and landscape architecture’, curated by Lucy Bullivant commissioned by Roca London Gallery and staged there in London and at the Core, Science Central, in Newcastle with Northern Architecture, Igloo Regeneration and Creative Space Management.

Through films, models, photographs and drawings by architects Alison Brooks, Irena Bauman, Muf (Liza Fior and Katherine Clarke), Alessandra Cianchetta (of AWP) and Johanna Gibbons (J&L Gibbons), Urbanistas promoted an alternative response to the needs of the urban environment through a comprehensive, holistic approach to planning and customized design of housing at locations including London’s suburbs, Ouseburn in east Newcastle, Holbeck in Leeds, La Défense, the business district in Paris and by the river Avon in Bath. Film director Paul McHale created six short documentary films giving a wider public an insight into the priorities and challenges calling for innovative solutions, to avoid repeating the mistakes of the past.

 

The 'Remake – We Make' team

Lucy Bullivant PhD Hon FRIBA is a leading curator of exhibitions and events about innovation in architecture and urban design, the founder of the Urbanista.org website devoted to liveable urbanism, and an advisor to many international bodies and firms. She is the author of many successful books including Masterplanning Futures, on adaptive planning (2012), winner of Book of the Year at the Urban Design Group Awards, 2014, and Recoded City: Co-creating urban futures, on participatory placemaking, co-authored with Thomas Ermacora (2015). Her groundbreaking and popular exhibitions include ‘Space Invaders’, about the work of young UK architects, co-curated with Pedro Gadanho, for the British Council and ‘The near and the far, fixed and in flux’, the British Pavilion for the XIX Milan Triennale.

WORKSHOP architecture (Clementine Blakemore, Alexander Furunes and Ivar Tutturen) creates buildings that are modest, practical and meaningful, forming a team of collaborators and partners for each project, and producing associated books and exhibitions in order to open the conversation to a wider audience. WORKSHOP has worked with the local community to make new schools buildings after disaster in Tachloban, the Philippines, for example – and in other neighbourhoods such as at Chandar Nagar in India, living at subsistence level, and urban and rural contexts. Blakemore was the Visionary Processes category winner at the 2015 SustainRCA Awards.

Paul McHale, a film director and editor based in Birmingham, UK, has made documentaries, animations and short films for businesses and cultural organisations including Birmingham Museums, Fused magazine, the Soul Food Project, and Roca London Gallery.

 

Links for further information about our team:

Urbanista.org - webzine dedicated to liveable urbanism founded by Lucy Bullivant: http://www.urbanista.org

Urbanistas: women innovators in architecture, urban and landscape design - exhibition, documentary films:

http://urbanistas.roca-exhibitions.co.uk

WORKSHOP architecture (WSa): http://wrkshp.org

Paul McGrath - documentary film maker: http://olddeadeye.com

 

How our exhibition complements the Biennale:

As there is no UK pavilion at the Biennale as official national projects of this kind need much longer to set up, the films will shed light on some exceptional UK projects at the Biennale alongside more than 60 projects by leading practices committed to architecture’s social role, including Future Cities Laboratory (Switzerland), Juan Du (Hong Kong), standardarchitecture and MAD Office (China), Rural Urban Framework (Hong Kong, co-founded by Joshua Bolshover from the UK), standardarchitecture (China), Anna Heringer (Germany), Hitoshi Abe (Japan), Teddy Cruz/Fonna Forman (Mexico), Ecosistema Urbano (Spain), Crimson (NL) and Interboro (US). In line with the Biennale’s theme, our small adaptable structure by WORKSHOP architecture will show how a young UK-Norwegian team makes best use of local resources and collaborators.

 

Summing up:

'Remake – We Make’ highlights the reality that architecture is a participative process. Its focus is on interactive placemaking, overcoming the typical disconnection between the public and the customary processes by which places are being made today. Our message is that new models of resident and community-engaged placemaking represent examples of alternative ways of making the city. These foster collaborative processes and the deployment of local materials, crafts and skills to build social, educational and ecological capital in places where they are urgently needed.

The team has started work on the exhibition but we need you to help in order to enable all the aspects of this exhibition to become a reality and to reach our target goal financially. We have a short space of time in which to fully meet this unique opportunity to celebrate and document these architects. For that, we need your help. Thank you for supporting us!

 

What we need & What you will get:

The funds raised will enable two members of the team to travel from Europe to Shenzhen to work on-site, building the structure with the local students from University of Shenzhen. It will fund the costs of the affordable local materials and equipment they will use. It will enable Paul McHale, our film director, to create short documentary films using existing footage of projects. Funding will be divided between local materials, including information display vinyls, and projection equipment; travel/accommodation while on site; preparation of the film; organisational costs.

Even if you don’t have the opportunity to see the Biennale, the completed ‘Remake – We Make’ films will be accessible on the Urbanista.org website, on its Facebook page, and on Vimeo.com.

 

Perks/rewards

The main reward for backing ‘ReMake – We Make’ is that you’ll receive a copy of the Shenzhen Biennale of Architecture and Urbanism catalogue, featuring all the selected international exhibitors. An equally attractive reward is a copy of the new 320 page Recoded City: Co-creating urban futures book, co-authored by Thomas Ermacora and Lucy Bullivant, published by Routledge on 30 November, which features a chapter on WORKSHOP architecture, members of our exhibition team. For all those able to help us, your pledge will be acknowledged in the exhibition and on the Urbanista.org (with your prior agreement).

 

Pledge £150 or more

A copy of the 2015 Bi-City Biennale of Urbanism and Architecture Shenzhen exhibition catalogue. Estimated delivery: end of January 2016. Ships to: anywhere in the world.

 

Pledge £100 or more

A copy of Recoded City: Co-creating urban futures, the new book on participatory placemaking by Thomas Ermacora and Lucy Bullivant, published by Routledge on 30 November 2015 (paperback; 320 pages; retail price: £37). Estimated delivery: 15 December 2015. Ships to: anywhere in the world.

 

Pledge £20 or more

Acknowledgement of your name:

in the exhibition

on the Urbanista.org website

(with your prior agreement).

Estimated delivery: 4 December 2015.

 

A personalized tweet, Facebook post (Urbanista.org) or Instagram mention will be made in immediate response to your pledge.

 

Other ways you can help:

We realize some people can’t contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help. Please like Urbanista.org’s Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/urbanista.org/?ref=hl

 

Credits

Curator: Lucy Bullivant

Exhibition structure: WORKSHOP architecture (Clementine Blakemore, Alex Furunes, Ivar Tutturen)

Exhibition structure construction collaboration: student team, Department of Architecture, University of Hong Kong (UHE), through the kind involvement of Joshua Bolshover, Professor of Architecture, UHE

Film director: Paul McHale

Film clips: WORKSHOP architecture, Assemble, 00 Architecture + Studio Weave, Carl Turner Architecture.

 

Risks and challenges

We are a highly motivated and experienced team. Alex Furunes of WORKSHOP architecture, who leads the making of the exhibition structure, is advancing site plans. The project is fully costed and the plan for its making well conceived. So, as we move forward towards our Indiegogo target, we'll continue to pull out all the stops to complete the delivery of the project in time for the Biennale.
story_txt: About this projectRemake – We Make and how our project came aboutI’m Lucy Bullivant and I’m an architecture curator and author, and the Editor-in-chief of Urbanista.org, my webzine founded to promote liveable urbanism for the 90%. We recently received an invitation we could not refuse, to make a thematic exhibition we’ve called ‘Remake - We Make’ to be part of the 2015 Bi-City Biennale of Urbanism and Architecture (Shenzhen) – UABB (SZ)* the prestigious international cultural event taking place this winter in the city of Shenzhen, in China's Pearl River Delta. The Biennale, including our exhibition, opens to the public on 5 Dec 2015, and the last day for public viewing is 28 Feb 2016. You will be able to find 'Remake - We Make' in the collateral section of the event, at its main venue, a converted flour factory at its site in Shekou, Shenzhen.Taking ‘Re-Living the City’ as its theme, the Biennale asks in what ways a future vision for the city and its Pearl River Delta region can be humanistic. Mindful of the perils of ignoring the consequences of fast urbanisation, the Biennale addresses issues of reduced natural resources and land, deterioration of environment and climate, industrial transformation, food safety and aging population.*Chief Curators: Aaron Betsky, a critic and curator who directed the Venice International Architecture Biennale 2008 and is now Dean of the Frank Lloyd Wright School of Architecture; Alfredo Brillembourg and Hubert Klumpner, who are founders of Urban-Think Tank (U-TT) and together hold a Chair of the Department of Architecture and Urban Design at ETH Zurich, and Doreen Heng Liu, founder and principal of NODE Architecture and Adjunct Associate Professor at the School of Architecture at the Chinese University of Hong Kong.At the heart of designing with and for the everyday is understanding the local challenges, assets, patterns, diversities and desires across communities. Instead of urban development plans - usually abstract in nature - the Biennale looks at how people are actually living in the city, and shows projects that ‘re-live’ the city by reinventing what exists through reuse and rethinking of existing buildings and urban spaces. The Biennale takes the Chinese concept of ‘cheng shi yuan dian’ (which means ‘thinking about change’), and shows local and international proposals actively responding to people’s lived experiences and to existing settings, inventing improvements for streets, parks, buildings and small insertions into specific public spaces. What Re Make – We Make includes:To respond to the Biennale’s theme and play a role as part of the event, we’re raising money to create ‘Remake – We Make’, our exhibition in two parts:A collaboration with the talented young UK-Norwegian team, WORKSHOP architecture founded by Clementine Blakemore, Alexander Furunes and Ivar Tutturen who will lead a participative design-build process to make a multi-use structure in local recycled timber, together with students from University of Shenzhen with Professor Xian Guo, Professor, and Professor Yan Gao, University       of Hong Kong. The structure will be presented at the Biennale in a spacious         former flour factory, now renovated for cultural events, creating a facility where discussions and some craft work can take place. From 5 Dec visitors will be able to view a set of short documentary films compiled by film director Paul McHale about WORKSHOP architecture’s activities in Tachloban, the Philippines after the recent tsunamis; Chandar Nagar, India and in the UK, plus other innovative architectural practitioners working with communities to build and enrich the commons of UK cities, each of which have carved out a unique reputation for inventive and responsive solutions: the collective Assemble, nominated for the Turner Prize 2015, 00 Architecture + Studio Weave and Carl Turner Architects.  Our films will be screened on a continuous basis within the exhibition during Biennale opening hours. From 12 Dec 2015 the space will feature reading/browsing copies of Recoded City: Co-creating urban futures, a new 320 page, extensively illustrated book on participatory placemaking with commissioned info-graphics revealing design and decision-making processes, co-authored by Lucy Bullivant and Thomas Ermacora, founder of Clear Village, the tactical urbanism non-profit, Limewharf futures gallery and Machines Room, east London. Advance news and updates on the design-build structure workshop, and some talks and a discussion that will be held during the Biennale up to early Feb before its closing date of 28 Feb 2016, will be posted on the wall of Remake - We Make at the Biennale, and on Lucy Bullivant's webzine on liveable urbanism, Urbanista.org. A short film about the 'Remake - We Make' collaborative design and build process in Shenzhen will be made and added to the exhibition's film presentation for viewing by visitors in Jan 2016. We welcome audience comments and feedback in the comments section of the 'Remake - We Make' essays on Urbanista.org after publication from early Dec 2015. Communicating the value‘Remake – We Make’ takes its cue from the social action focus of the Biennale.    We want not only to think about positive change through urban design, but communicate exceptional examples of it. We will therefore also feature our small (100m2) and memorable exhibition from the UK on Urbanista.org. so through a story board on its progress, a global audience can see how it develops, and also watch the short films we will show as part of the exhibition.So ‘Remake – We Make’ will have a life after the exhibition closes on 28 Feb 2016. Not only will the films will be available for viewing on the Urbanista.org webzine and Vimeo.com, but the structure made by WORKSHOP architecture and the University of Shenzhen student team we hope to donate to a community organization in Shenzhen. Following our earlier urban innovation project…‘Remake – We Make’ comes on the heels of the hugely successful exhibition, ‘Urbanistas: women innovators in architecture, urban and landscape architecture’, curated by Lucy Bullivant commissioned by Roca London Gallery and staged there in London and at the Core, Science Central, in Newcastle with Northern Architecture, Igloo Regeneration and Creative Space Management.Through films, models, photographs and drawings by architects Alison Brooks, Irena Bauman, Muf (Liza Fior and Katherine Clarke), Alessandra Cianchetta (of AWP) and Johanna Gibbons (J&L Gibbons), Urbanistas promoted an alternative response to the needs of the urban environment through a comprehensive, holistic approach to planning and customized design of housing at locations including London’s suburbs, Ouseburn in east Newcastle, Holbeck in Leeds, La Défense, the business district in Paris and by the river Avon in Bath. Film director Paul McHale created six short documentary films giving a wider public an insight into the priorities and challenges calling for innovative solutions, to avoid repeating the mistakes of the past. The 'Remake – We Make' teamLucy Bullivant PhD Hon FRIBA is a leading curator of exhibitions and events about innovation in architecture and urban design, the founder of the Urbanista.org website devoted to liveable urbanism, and an advisor to many international bodies and firms. She is the author of many successful books including Masterplanning Futures, on adaptive planning (2012), winner of Book of the Year at the Urban Design Group Awards, 2014, and Recoded City: Co-creating urban futures, on participatory placemaking, co-authored with Thomas Ermacora (2015). Her groundbreaking and popular exhibitions include ‘Space Invaders’, about the work of young UK architects, co-curated with Pedro Gadanho, for the British Council and ‘The near and the far, fixed and in flux’, the British Pavilion for the XIX Milan Triennale.WORKSHOP architecture (Clementine Blakemore, Alexander Furunes and Ivar Tutturen) creates buildings that are modest, practical and meaningful, forming a team of collaborators and partners for each project, and producing associated books and exhibitions in order to open the conversation to a wider audience. WORKSHOP has worked with the local community to make new schools buildings after disaster in Tachloban, the Philippines, for example – and in other neighbourhoods such as at Chandar Nagar in India, living at subsistence level, and urban and rural contexts. Blakemore was the Visionary Processes category winner at the 2015 SustainRCA Awards.Paul McHale, a film director and editor based in Birmingham, UK, has made documentaries, animations and short films for businesses and cultural organisations including Birmingham Museums, Fused magazine, the Soul Food Project, and Roca London Gallery. Links for further information about our team:Urbanista.org - webzine dedicated to liveable urbanism founded by Lucy Bullivant: http://www.urbanista.orgUrbanistas: women innovators in architecture, urban and landscape design - exhibition, documentary films:http://urbanistas.roca-exhibitions.co.ukWORKSHOP architecture (WSa): http://wrkshp.orgPaul McGrath - documentary film maker: http://olddeadeye.com How our exhibition complements the Biennale:As there is no UK pavilion at the Biennale as official national projects of this kind need much longer to set up, the films will shed light on some exceptional UK projects at the Biennale alongside more than 60 projects by leading practices committed to architecture’s social role, including Future Cities Laboratory (Switzerland), Juan Du (Hong Kong), standardarchitecture and MAD Office (China), Rural Urban Framework (Hong Kong, co-founded by Joshua Bolshover from the UK), standardarchitecture (China), Anna Heringer (Germany), Hitoshi Abe (Japan), Teddy Cruz/Fonna Forman (Mexico), Ecosistema Urbano (Spain), Crimson (NL) and Interboro (US). In line with the Biennale’s theme, our small adaptable structure by WORKSHOP architecture will show how a young UK-Norwegian team makes best use of local resources and collaborators. Summing up:'Remake – We Make’ highlights the reality that architecture is a participative process. Its focus is on interactive placemaking, overcoming the typical disconnection between the public and the customary processes by which places are being made today. Our message is that new models of resident and community-engaged placemaking represent examples of alternative ways of making the city. These foster collaborative processes and the deployment of local materials, crafts and skills to build social, educational and ecological capital in places where they are urgently needed.The team has started work on the exhibition but we need you to help in order to enable all the aspects of this exhibition to become a reality and to reach our target goal financially. We have a short space of time in which to fully meet this unique opportunity to celebrate and document these architects. For that, we need your help. Thank you for supporting us! What we need & What you will get:The funds raised will enable two members of the team to travel from Europe to Shenzhen to work on-site, building the structure with the local students from University of Shenzhen. It will fund the costs of the affordable local materials and equipment they will use. It will enable Paul McHale, our film director, to create short documentary films using existing footage of projects. Funding will be divided between local materials, including information display vinyls, and projection equipment; travel/accommodation while on site; preparation of the film; organisational costs.Even if you don’t have the opportunity to see the Biennale, the completed ‘Remake – We Make’ films will be accessible on the Urbanista.org website, on its Facebook page, and on Vimeo.com. Perks/rewardsThe main reward for backing ‘ReMake – We Make’ is that you’ll receive a copy of the Shenzhen Biennale of Architecture and Urbanism catalogue, featuring all the selected international exhibitors. An equally attractive reward is a copy of the new 320 page Recoded City: Co-creating urban futures book, co-authored by Thomas Ermacora and Lucy Bullivant, published by Routledge on 30 November, which features a chapter on WORKSHOP architecture, members of our exhibition team. For all those able to help us, your pledge will be acknowledged in the exhibition and on the Urbanista.org (with your prior agreement). Pledge £150 or moreA copy of the 2015 Bi-City Biennale of Urbanism and Architecture Shenzhen exhibition catalogue. Estimated delivery: end of January 2016. Ships to: anywhere in the world. Pledge £100 or moreA copy of Recoded City: Co-creating urban futures, the new book on participatory placemaking by Thomas Ermacora and Lucy Bullivant, published by Routledge on 30 November 2015 (paperback; 320 pages; retail price: £37). Estimated delivery: 15 December 2015. Ships to: anywhere in the world. Pledge £20 or moreAcknowledgement of your name:in the exhibitionon the Urbanista.org website(with your prior agreement).Estimated delivery: 4 December 2015. A personalized tweet, Facebook post (Urbanista.org) or Instagram mention will be made in immediate response to your pledge. Other ways you can help:We realize some people can’t contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help. Please like Urbanista.org’s Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/urbanista.org/?ref=hl CreditsCurator: Lucy BullivantExhibition structure: WORKSHOP architecture (Clementine Blakemore, Alex Furunes, Ivar Tutturen)Exhibition structure construction collaboration: student team, Department of Architecture, University of Hong Kong (UHE), through the kind involvement of Joshua Bolshover, Professor of Architecture, UHEFilm director: Paul McHaleFilm clips: WORKSHOP architecture, Assemble, 00 Architecture + Studio Weave, Carl Turner Architecture. Risks and challengesWe are a highly motivated and experienced team. Alex Furunes of WORKSHOP architecture, who leads the making of the exhibition structure, is advancing site plans. The project is fully costed and the plan for its making well conceived. So, as we move forward towards our Indiegogo target, we'll continue to pull out all the stops to complete the delivery of the project in time for the Biennale.

story:
Short Summary


There is finally a tool that supports moms and dads with having those necessary but tough conversations with their daughters. 'I Choose to be a Lady: Basic Life Lessons for Our Daughters' is the book you need to start those conversations. 

I Choose To Be A Lady is a revolutionary guide that includes a workbook and journal, designed to help teen girls transition into adulthood. Parents can use it by:  

1. Reading it first and having open conversations with your teens

or

2. Giving the book to your teens and allowing them to read it, complete the review questions and have full confidence they are getting great information.

As a result of completing this book, your teenager will be informed and able to make great decisions regarding: Sex, Self-Esteem, Social Media, Goal-Setting, Professional Development and more! 

Kiana Shaw is a 3 time best selling author who fearlessly covers the nitty-gritty topics that young people and parents need to know, but may not always feel comfortable talking about. With almost 10 years of experience teaching life, leadership and empowerment skills, Kiana is the 'go to' person for all things related to teen girls. 

Whether you are a young woman looking for guidance, an adult looking to help, or someone who simply needs a reliable voice to look up to, these chapters are an invaluable resource for you to survive and thrive in the most formative years of your life.

Your contributions will help to publish the book, create the 6 - 10 week online course for it and distribute it to 1000 high school girls across our country. 


What We Need & What You Get

$2,050.00 Publishing and Editing 

$3,000.00 for the online course curriculum to be built, tested and delivered

$15,000 for 1000 high school girls to receive a FREE copy of the book


Bonus:

Each student who receives a FREE copy of the book and signs up for the online course within the first 6 months, will receive $50 off of their tuition ($20 for the book and $30 for taking action). 


Inside scoop:

If our funding goals are not met, we will pay for the publishing first, online course curriculum 2nd and lastly, give away as many books as we can. 

Check out our perks to see what your giving can get you. 


The Impact

This book is valuable to parents and teen girls because it is not only a manuscript but a workbook and journal as well. With almost 10 years of experience to pull from, 'I Choose to be a Lady' was put together from the questions at our workshops, seminars and conferences. 


Risks & Challenges

With every project, their are challenges. The only challenge here though is getting the funding needed to succeed. That being said, resiliency is our best asset. We WILL make this goal!! With your help, we will do it faster but we are committed no matter the date. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you find yourself unable to financially contribute regardless of your desire to and love for this project, here is what you can do:

  • Retweet out our links and tag me @coachkianashaw
  • Share our facebook posts (WITH THE LINK) and tag your friends.
  • Ask your followers to make noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • If you're a mom, join my Mothers Raising Teen Daughters facebook group

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

The World Scholar's Cup is an academic competition with over 3400+ scholars from over 40 countries competing this year. There are 3 rounds:The Regional round held in Jakarta, The Global Round held in Bangkok (http://www.scholarscup.org/global-round/) ,and the Tournament of Champions held in Yale University, New Haven (http://www.scholarscup.org/toc/) . In this competition we study 6 subjects: Science, Social Studies, History, Arts and Music, Literature, Special Area- Crime and Justice (http://www.scholarscup.org/subjects/). This years curriculum is centered around 1 theme, "An imperfect World" (http://www.scholarscup.org/themes/ ) There are 4 main events in the competition , debating, essay writing, challenge (written test) and a group quiz that focuses on lateral thinking skills (bowl) (http://www.scholarscup.org/communityevents/). This competition promotes a balance between fun and learning with many other social activities including a scavenge r hunt, a scholars ball (dance), a scholar's social, and a cultural fair that brings together culture's from all over the world.This competition has the hopes of building a large community of scholars from around the world, through fun and learning. This is my second year competing at the World Scholar’s Cup and for the second year in a row, my team and I were able to qualify for the Tournament of Champions in Yale University. Unfortunately the total fee for this round (including transportation,flight,food,hotel,competition fee,etc) is very expensive ($5000 per person) and I am unable to afford it. By contributing are helping me reach my goal of competing in Yale University. Allowing me a chance to prove that I can compete with the best scholars from around the world. 

What We Need & What You Get

The full price of this trip is around $5000 per person depending on which flight or hotel we take, but with this campaign I hope to be able to receive $4000 to help me pay for the trip. This money will help pay for the flight, hotel and the competition fee. Living in Indonesia means flying to America is very expensive.

The perks in this campaign include traditional Indonesian souvenirs,Select Indonesian coffee (roasted or green), alpaca’s (the mascot of the world scholar’s cup),proffesional picture's for both commercial and personal use, and Indonesian batik sarong.

The Impact

I hope that through this fundraising project, I will be able inspire other students to try to earn money for the trip creatively or inspire others to try out this competition for a magnificent experience! After consulting and speaking to scholar's from all over the world, I discovered that there are many who were unable to join the Global Rounds and the Tournament of Champions due to the fee and distance. Through this campaign, I would like to show scholars from around the world that they to can participate in the Global Round and the Tournament of Champions through independent funding and by finding creative ways to both make and reach a goal. 

 So far, over the past 2 years, I have done well in this competition. In this year’s Jakarta round, I was chosen to be one of the speakers in the debate showcase  (a debate among the best speakers in the competition) and in the global round I was able to be a debate showcase adjudicators and be the flag barrier of Canada! 

By contributing to this campaign, you are helping me reach my goal and helping me grow as a scholar.Below are my past achievements from the Jakarta and Global rounds 2016 and last years tournament of champions.

Jakarta Round 2016 achievements: (500 competitors)

3rd Place-Champion Debaters

16th Place-Champion Writers

4th Place-Top Debate Teams

8th Place-Champion Teams

8th Place-Champion Scholars

9th Place-Scholar's Bowl

Honor Medal-Challenge History

Honor Medal-Challenge Arts

Honor Medal-Top Challenge Teams

Top 15%-Individual Challenge

Honor Medal-Top Writing Teams

Challenge Literature-Top 25%

Challenge Science-Top 40%

Challenge Social Studies-Top 30%


Global Round Bangkok 2016 achievements: (3400+ competitors)

88th Place-Champion Scholars

56th Place-Champion Debaters

Silver Medal-Challenge History

Silver Medal-Champion Writers

Silver Medal-Challenge Special Area

Gold Medal-School Top Scholars

Top 20%-Individual Challenge

Silver Medal-Top Challenge Teams

Top 25%-Challenge Arts

Top 30%-Challenge Literature

Top 25%-Team Debate

Top 35%-Challenge Science


Tournament of Champions Yale University 2015: (700+ competitors)

8th Place-Team Writing

24th Place-Debate

Top 15%-Challenge: The Arts

Top 20%-Overall Individual

Top 20%-Individual: Writing

Top 35%-Challenge: Social Studies

Top 50%-Individual: Challenge

Top 35%-Team: Debate

Risks & Challenges

With the goal of $4000 there are some challenges and risks that will be encountered. The biggest challenge is making sure that all the contributors receive the perks they requested. Another challenge involves, the logistics of shipping the perks when requested, but this can be figured out trough discussion. Despite the challenges, I will do my best to reach my goal. Please note that all contributors from Canada can collect their perks when I am back in Canada in December unless we make other arrangments.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to contribute to this campaign, thank you so much for reading this campaign's story. Another way you can help me is by spreading the word. Tell all your friends and family about this campaign and possibly try to convince them to contribute.

PWAA!! (The sound a happy alpaca makes)

story:
The best way for this generation of college students to understand Israel is to go there. As a faculty member at UMD, I have been taking students to Israel since 2012. When they return, this is what they say:

“This trip enhanced my interest in teaching students from diverse backgrounds.” 

"The media reduces and mischaracterizes Israel into something that it is not, that bears little truth to the society I have come to know...vibrant and multicultural."

“Israel is a country of collaboration.” 

“The coexistence of Christian, Jewish, and Muslim people in one of the smallest and fought over countries is in itself something to admire and elicits strong comparisons to how different and how unaccepting other nations can be."

“Not only am I learning a lot about Israel, I am also learning about my Ethiopian culture and identity. I did not know that Ethiopian Jews even existed. It makes me emotional to learn about the hardships and struggle they had to go through to get to this point. I feel a deep connection with them.” 

While student sometimes receive some funding from the university, those funds contribute to the cost of the program but not the airfare, which many first generation college students are unable to afford.

This campaign will help cover airfare for up to 6 students.

Any amount will be appreciated, and helping us to spread the word helps a lot, also!

Thank you!

"The media reduces and mischaracterizes Israel into something that it is not, that bears little truth to the society I have come to know...vibrant and multicultural."
“Israel is a country of collaboration.” 
“The coexistence of Christian, Jewish, and Muslim people in one of the smallest and fought over countries is in itself something to admire and elicits strong comparisons to how different and how unaccepting other nations can be."
“Not only am I learning a lot about Israel, I am also learning about my Ethiopian culture and identity. I did not know that Ethiopian Jews even existed. It makes me emotional to learn about the hardships and struggle they had to go through to get to this point. I feel a deep connection with them.” 
While student sometimes receive some funding from the university, those funds contribute to the cost of the program but not the airfare, which many first generation college students are unable to afford.
This campaign will help cover airfare for up to 6 students.
Any amount will be appreciated, and helping us to spread the word helps a lot, also!
Thank you!

story:
Introduce yourself and your background.

Hello! My name is I-Soo Jeon. I am in the second grade at alternative school called Treasure Island. This year, my brother, Woo-Tae, is going to enter the same school. But, as you know, alternative school’s tuition fee is expensive. Besides, I have two more younger sisters, so my daddy’s income is not enough to pay our tuition fee. Woo-Tae and I want to go to the school together. Even though I am young, I want to help my parents to pay our tuition fee. I hope I can help them my own way.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Even though I am young, I don't want you to donate without any reward. This year, I exhibited my art work two times and published a fairy tale book. If you support me and my brother, I would like to send you my fairy tale book or a postcard that my art work is on it. I published my fairy tale book with my daddy's help, so I could not print on a large scale. Besides, on my last summer vacation, I sold my fairy tale book at flea market called "Bel-Long". So, I only have two hundred of book in stock. But, I have a stock of my fairy tale book which is written in Korean, I will register those books for who are interested in Korean. Since we have not made the postcards yet, we will send it out following the quantity of your donation by the end of January. 

  • All postcards images are at the gallery tab on top page.
  • Sample images of my book.

  • The painting included in 'For an art lover' perk.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make donations right now, I would like you to share my story with your friends and family through Facebook or any blogs. Would you please let me know if there are kids who want to read my books?

 

Finishing the article

Please, give me a lot of attention. Then my dearest brother can share school life with me happily. With your interest and encouragement, my brother and I promise to grow up as a helpful adult for the world. Thank you.

story:
Flex is a unique form of dance that originated on the streets of Brooklyn in the 90s.

The Flex Program(Founded in 2014) is an arts education initiative that fosters positive growth among young people in difficult circumstances through mindful movement, creative storytelling, and improvisational dance. The Flex Program employs renowned dancers from local communities to develop dance routines with our students, promoting self-esteem, cooperation, and communication. We seek to transform physical energy into positive, non-verbal self-expression that offers an alternative to conflict. We have worked with about 250 youth so far, and reach approximately 120 youth with our program every year.

Studies show that 70% of youth held in secure detention were arrested or returned to secure detention within one year of release.

We feel it is important to introduce an outside-option to the young students we work with on the inside. Our teachers are getting a lot of requests from youth where to go for FLEX sessions in the community, and how to be involved with the program when they are released.

We believe that in an inclusive and creative community based setting, the students can find a secure base in order to create and express themselves. The Flex Program promotes creativity, keeps youth socially engaged and mindful, provides them with a sense of pride and fosters success. By providing a positive outlet through recreation for self-expression, the FLEX program help participants find healthy solutions to conflict, and curb recidivism.

If we reach the goal of this campaign with your help, the money you give will go towards developing a community-based "FlexOUT" outreach dance-program aligned with our already established on-site "FlexIN" program provided in Secure Detention Centers in New York.

FlexOUT will provide free FLEX sessions and workshops for youth that have been released from detention, but we will also recruit other interested youth in the community. We want to develop the FlexOUT-Initiative by also including youth-Interns to work with our team to promote cooperation and support across generations. These youths are students that have been participating in our FlexIN dance-sessions before, but also other young individuals that have been reaching out with interest to get involved with our program. The FLEX Program has already identified strong candidates for potential youth internships to work on our team.

The Flex Program is currently under an ACS (Administration of Children’s Services) contract to provide our Flex Dance Sessions to youth  in Crossroads and Horizons Detention Centers in New York. The Flex Program is administered by voluntary efforts entirely, and calls on the talents of a diverse team of professional artists who split their time between instructing and performing.  The artists are instrumental in our mentoring sessions, and are the main focal point of the organization, attracting awareness at performances and providing stability during teaching sessions.

Teaching in detention centers can be challenging, We are at a point in our organizational development where we want to provide additional support to our teaching staff through trainings and workshops. This will also enhance the quality of our programming by giving the teachers new inspiration and insights in pedagogy. Of the $15000: 10% will go towards renting space for workshops, 50% towards salary for teaching artists, 20% towards training and professional development, 20% towards internship development.

Why FLEX?

Flexing is distinguished by its contortionist body movements, and its “no rules”, narrative story-telling capabilities. Because of the reactive nature of Flex, the dancer is often inspired by his immediate environment and is free to tell his or her own story, making for a very emotional performance. At its core, Flex is a deeply personal art form, and has been shown to help the individuals cope psychologically with his or her circumstances.

The Flex Program was founded two years ago by Ragnhild Ragz Bruland. She started the program with her savings and a dream: To start a program that would benefit artists and youth at promise for years to come. The Flex Program is still a small organization, but it is growing every day. There is a huge need for youth to connect with eachother through the arts. The Flex Program depends on donors like you to help realize our vision, and to help us in our efforts to bring our program to the next level. Unite to allow artists continue the meaningful work they do with the youth - FlexIN and FlexOUT. Every amount counts and is highly appreciated.

Please also help us share this campaign. You can use the Indigogo share tools to spread the word about what we do.

Thanks for your generous support!

Sincerely,

FLEX Program Team

www.flexdanceprogram.com

Upcoming Events:

FLEX-Hyperborealis- Apollo’s Journey:

FLEX-Hyperborealis is a sisterproject of the Flex Program. The project includes stage-performances and workshops where the main focus is to inspire youth to dance and explore other cultures. Seemore info here: https://flexdanceprogram.com/flex-hyperborealis/

Save the date: 09.20.2016, 7 pm Kumble Theater Brooklyn

Get your tickets here: http://www.beatbrooklyn.com/flex-hyperborealis-...

"Don't miss out on the amazing once in a lifetime premiere: FLEX-Hyperborealis- Apollo's Journey. The Norwegian composer Kenneth Sivertsen, who died 10 years ago, would have been proud to see this unique manifestation of his work. This is a rare opportunity to witness, and experience the talented FLEX Dancers interpret Apollo's journey to the land beyond the Nothern Wind. The Performance will be followed by a round table discussion on our program, and our journey so far teaching, and mentoring youth in detention centers." 

Save the date: 09.24.2016 - FLEX Program Fundraiser 

More info coming soon!

The Flex Program is a sponsored artist with The Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for The Flex Program are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or for our national charities registration. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Or Simply Put

A learning platform that actually trains you for your dream job...

I focus on the Job first! Other platforms don't.

What is wrong with other platforms?

  • They focus on technicalities
  • They use artificial and unrealistic problems
  • They train lots of syntax
  • They ignore the mindset
  • They don't train for the job
  • Success is measured by people completing modules
  • Courses are organised by topic, not by jobs

Why am I better?

  • If it's in the course it's because it will be used
  • I don't bog people down with what they don't need
  • I focus on the outcome
  • I use realistic examples that exist in industry (usually from my own experience in industry)
  • Each module builds on the previous module
  • I cover typical workplace problems and scenarios
  • Completing the Junior Software Developer course means that people can apply for Junior Software Developer jobs with a strong chance of being successful
  • I measure success by the number of lives I've helped improve and the number of careers I've helped start
  • Courses are organised by the Job roles and cover enough of each topic to enable a person to do that job

Why?

  1. Having a degree doesn't mean anything these days
  2. Contemporary education is stale
  3. Modern learning platforms lack focus

What's an Immersive Learning Experience?

  1. Completely focused on what is required to start a new career or profession
  2. Practice within the platform while you learn
  3. Get intelligent feedback and suggestions when you start to struggle
  4. Small steps that get you building something tangible fast
  5. Learning assistance bots to guide you each step of the way

Who's it for?

  • People who want more from life
  • People who want a chance to show their worth
  • People who just really want to be developers
  • People who care about themselves

Short Summary

I want to help anyone who is stuck in a job they hate or on an income that's too low find a new life and new career in a job that pays well and is immensely satisfying. I have been training people for over 7 years, literally starting 100's of careers. I have been building applications and software for over 10 years in a variety of industries and environments. I have truly been learning ever since I left university and figured out who I am and what I am about. Ultimately, I am completely passionate about people living the life they dream of having with the career they love, rather than settling for anything less than that.

I'm building a one of a kind immersive learning experience that will support and guide anyone who wants to in the art of Software Development.

This is for people who:

  • finished school early
  • were let down by boring lectures at university
  • got a degree and ended up working behind a checkout, in a call centre, or anywhere else where their skills are wasted
  • never got on with education at school because, to be frank, it was stale and boring
  • quite simply, want to change their lives and improve their lot in the world

The application I'm building puts the individual and their goals at the absolute centre stage.

It will:

  • deliver completely industry relevant learning
  • provide real time feedback based upon what a person is doing
  • give them an immersive experience where they feel supported at all times
  • provide a platform to build their portfolio of evidence that will wow employers and interviewers
  • provide structured and progressive learning with regular checkpoints for support and guidance

If you support this, you will have given a helping hand that will actually achieve something, you will have helped improve the lot of your fellow human and provided a platform for tapping into all that hidden and lost talent in the world. Who knows what the future holds where everyone is at their happiest and strongest. I know something though, I want to do everything I can to find out what that future looks like and, right now, this is the best way I can think of to add my own contribution to that.

What I Need & What You Get

Quite simply, I need time. I have the vision, I have the plan of what the first set of modules need to look like and I know how to build the material. The thing I don't have is time. By supporting this campaign you will allow me to devote all of my time to building this. I think I can get the first release done quickly, it's already halfway there at least, and then I think that I can start building out the app further in short iterations thereafter.

The perks I am offering range from a simple heartfelt thank you, various lengths of free subscriptions for varying numbers of people (great if you work for a company looking for the best way to train your apprentices or graduates), right through to having a direct impact on the direction, prioritisation and scope of this product. And for those of you who really want it, you will get my time probably over skype or something similar (in person if you are near me). I will give you the opportunity for direct 1-2-1 training that you will get no where else (this is completely transferable to friends and relatives). Some of these perks will include a variety of different catch ups ranging from every couple of months right through to monthly, if you so wish. I should mention that these kind of perks will be a premium on the site and so are definitely worth hooking into here.

If I don't reach my goal, then any funds I do raise will continue to support my time on this (I just won't have as much time). This project is incredibly close to my heart and I work on it whenever I can in the evenings and at weekends when I'm not working to pay the bills, that will not change.

The Impact

By supporting this project you are directly helping improve the lives of people around you in a real and tangible way. Improving peoples lives has a direct impact on their loved ones and their family. You will be providing the current/future families of the people using this with more opportunities to thrive in the world. I wonder what amazing things they will then achieve and contribute back to society in the process.

Training is in my blood, and education is the life force of innovation and advancement of our world. I've been helping people start careers for years, and now I want to take this mainstream and open up these opportunities to everyone.

Risks & Challenges

There are a series of challenges around finding people to use this application. However I've already found several people who are waiting patiently for me to finish the first version so they can get started on this. I have a plan of trying a variety of different experiments to find the best way of reaching people who will benefit from this. This plan includes building the right network, creating guest articles for different sites, blogs and potentially magazines. This plan also includes a variety of low cost in-person training sessions to help get people started and build their confidence that they can do this

Other Ways You Can Help

If you love the idea of this but can't provide a financial contribution then there are still things you can do to help make this a success. You can:

  • Share this campaign with people you know and love
  • Help me in other ways by being part of a beta test (TBA)
  • Provide me with feedback about what you think works and what you think doesn't work
  • When the first version is released, you can sign up, change your life, cheer yourself on and let people know how you did it!

Thanks for reading this and I wish you all the very best for you and your life.

story:
Short Summary

I created Young at Arts with the hope of recreating what I learned at my childhood arts school, that art brings people together and the more we learn to express ourselves, the more we see that we are all beautiful and worthy of doing wonderful things for our world and for each other.  Won't you help me bring 24 of our students, picked from our student body of 500, who have worked hard and shown perseverance and leadership, to see and go behind the scenes of a Beyoncé concert, as special guests. 

My schooling in the arts taught me to overcome people's differences, to respect others and to see the world and its diversity as an opportunity to learn and experience all the beauty that we can take in while we are on this earth. I know it works. I've already transformed many lives in the 13 years since Young at Arts opened its doors.  Art has the potential to heal the world.

story:
I am currently a high school senior, graduating in December 2016, who is trying to raise money to go to India for three months in the Spring of 2017.

I will be traveling with Carpe Diem, a gap year program, but will be taking university classes in Cultural Anthropology with Portland State University as I am in India. 

While in India I will be traveling with approximately eight other university students throughout the country, backpacking, volunteering at Mother Theresa's Home for the Destitute, learning Hindi, and experiencing Indian culture for three months, from mid February to early May. I am asking for your help because I have struggled with finding scholarships that work to finance this trip. I would truly appreciate any form of donations or any information on scholarships for study abroad trips. Thank you and peace be with you!
story_txt: I am currently a high school senior, graduating in December 2016, who is trying to raise money to go to India for three months in the Spring of 2017.I will be traveling with Carpe Diem, a gap year program, but will be taking university classes in Cultural Anthropology with Portland State University as I am in India. While in India I will be traveling with approximately eight other university students throughout the country, backpacking, volunteering at Mother Theresa's Home for the Destitute, learning Hindi, and experiencing Indian culture for three months, from mid February to early May. I am asking for your help because I have struggled with finding scholarships that work to finance this trip. I would truly appreciate any form of donations or any information on scholarships for study abroad trips. Thank you and peace be with you!

story:
Ask a seasoned world traveler to name their favorite place, and few would probably choose the place closest to my heart: Liberia.

Unfortunately, the little that many people know about Liberia usually involves blood diamonds, Charles Taylor and Ebola. My name is Janel Galvanek and I have worked for a peacebuilding institute for the last 8 years, which has given me the incredible opportunity to travel around the world and to see a side of Liberia which doesn’t make headlines. Liberia is a place where people come together to care for each another despite the most difficult conditions and where citizens work for peace on a daily basis.

My love of Liberia started in 2008 when I went to do research on the reintegration of child soldiers. I fell in love with the place, the music, the people, the feel. And I met U-Jay, whom immediately became my brother, my best friend, my bodyguard and someone who drops everything to hang out with me and help me with my research when I am in the country. For me, U-Jay represents the best of Liberia - that in spite of the daily struggles that people have to endure, they can still be honest and kind and do what they can to help other people who are worse off than they are.

On the road to Gbarnga last September 2015 I asked U-Jay what he would do if he had the means to do anything in the world. He l said, ‘If I could do anything in the world, I would buy a piece of land outside Monrovia and build an orphanage and give some of the street kids a home and someone to love them’.  And in that very moment, I knew that we would make his dream a reality together.

Over this past year, I founded a non-profit organization in Germany called ‘Growing Tree Liberia’ (GTL) that I work for on a volunteer basis, and U-Jay and his friend and partner, Melvin, have founded the Liberian partner organization, Growing Tree Child Care Program’ (GTCCP). The office in Monrovia has been been set up with all of its logistical needs, and the process of receiving accreditation as an orphanage is almost complete.

And just in the past few weeks, a perfect 10-acre piece of land has been found in Bomi County, just north of the city.  Extensive consultations have been carried out with the community that is selling the land, including meetings with the chief and the elders, as well as with the women and youth of the community. I was in Liberia the first week of December to visit the national office and see the progress my partners have made and I had the opportunity to visit the land and meet with some of the community members themselves.  They are thrilled about our project  - not only about having a buyer for the land who is dedicated to improving the lives of vulnerable children, but also who will help give back to the community.

The community is selling the land at a very reasonable price, but we need to raise $45,000 as quickly as possible to make the purchase. The sooner we can buy the land, the sooner we can begin with the construction of the buildings and the sooner we can open our doors to 50 children who desperately need a home. Any donation over $150 ensures that your name and where you live will be documented on a large plaque on the main building of the orphanage site. If for some reason our campaign doesn't reach $45,000, the money that was raised will nevertheless go solely toward the purchase of the land and I will continue to look for funds in other ways. 

No one knows for sure how many orphans there are in the country of Liberia, but with extreme levels of poverty, the recent Ebola crisis, and only a bare minimum of health care in the country, thousands of children are greatly suffering on a daily basis. We want to relieve suffering to whatever extent we can by offering a home, an education and somewhere that children can feel safe, before hopefully finding a more permanent, loving home for them. Your contribution will help us be able to reach out our hands to others who so desperately need our help. 

 

Building and maintaining an orphanage in Liberia is certainly not going to be easy.  But nothing in life that really makes you proud comes easy. For me, challenges inspire me to think more, solve problems, find good partners and work harder. Those who know me know that I have never shied away from a challenge and in this case, carrying out this project will actually have a direct and very significant impact on vulnerable children who are now living without any hope for a future. Therefore, meeting this challenge is essential. And most importantly, I have two very competent and very trustworthy partners in Liberia who are building this dream with me.

If you are unable to donate right now, that's ok!  I would just love for you to pass on this message to anyone and everyone you know who you think may be interested.  Spread the word and help us reach the funds we need!

story:
Who we are: 

  • We are a small family company. 
  • Our focus is on Education and Travel
  • College Essay Writing and Community Service are part of the program
  • College / life readiness and preparation go hand in hand with international travel

Benefits

Traveling to another country can be beneficial in a few different ways.  The experience will stay with you forever, and what you learn about others and yourself will be priceless.

1) You will gain a more serious sense of self-awareness.  Gathering first hand experience about another area of the world – seeing different landscapes, watching the difficulties of other cultures, listening to the opinions of non-Americans, provides a permanent sense of worldliness.  Values and priorities will take on new meaning.

2) You will gain leadership skills.  A person who has ‘been there and done that’ has more credibility.  To put it simply – that person has more clout.  Instead of relying on others opinions, those who have traveled gain perspective, confidence and conviction that makes it easier to gain the respect of others.  Whether you have worked with a child teaching him English, painted a church, done physical labor on the farm – you will have completed a section of life that many never begin.

ALSO:

 You will make contacts around the globe.  In this age of web communication, you will know someone in another country, and be able to foster that contact for as long as you see fit.  Gone are the days of letter writing and wait times.  Via whatsapp and other like programs, you can text / chat / facetime someone and gain a reciprocally beneficial contact for future business / friendship needs.

Why travel with us?

  • College Essay Creation
  • Spanish Fluency
  • Home cooked meals
  • Organized & Insured
  • Individualized Writing Instruction
  • Community Service
  • More intimate experience via a small company
  • Familiarity with the terrain
  • Educational focus.

story:
What is my campaign about?

Millions of people around the world are waking up to an expanded level of consciousness.
For many of these people the journey of awakening is a turbulent roller- coaster ride into the abyss of a misunderstood Universe, and as such, it can also be a fast admission ticket into the world of psychiatry.

My campaign is to initiate an International '#Emerging Proud' day to launch on 17th March 2017, and hopefully continue every year on the same date after that to raise awareness and end the stigma of spiritual experiences. The launch event will feature a live stream premiere of a film the campaign aims to produce; '#Coming out of the Spiritual Closet' 

WHAT and HOW? 

The campaign will consist of three main things:

A collection of photos on a regular blog that depict experiencers of spiritual phenomena ‘#Emerging Proud’ in support of this campaign. This will then form the basis for a special edition book commemorating this momentous day if we raise enough funds. 

Make any pledge and YOU are invited to send in your own photo which will feature as part of the campaign; these will be shared on social media until the big launch day on 17th March 2017. They will then form an ‘#Emerging Proud!’ feature on my website, and hopefully also on a website dedicated to Coming Out of the Spiritual Closet, in addition to a special edition book commemorating the event. 

I will be collecting 2 min video clips from contributors (hopefully YOU!) telling the public why the campaign is so important to you. 

These clips will then form a montage for a full length film '#Coming out of the Spiritual Closet' to premiere internationally on 17th March 2017.  The film will then be available post- launch to watch for free via my website, ISEN's website and a few special guest collaborators in order to help the thousands of people going through the spiritual emergence process worldwide.

During the campaign I’ll be sharing exclusive interviews with special guests - experts in the field and experiencers who will talk about themselves ‘#Emerging Proud’; maybe some will even come out live during the campaign!

I don’t intend this to be just a short fix – when the campaign ends after the 17th Nov I will stay engaged with you, continuing to provide interviews, powerful stories and risqué blogs covering some of the more extreme ends of spiritual emergence experiences until the film launches on the 17th March 2017. 

This will then be recognized as International #EmergingProud Day!

Potential Impact

We only have to look at the magnitude of positive change that Gay Pride has created - well this is about doing the same, and more, for spiritual experiences! With YOUR involvement, we can expand the public perception of 'normal' all over the world. This is about creating a political transformation agenda. People who experience spiritual phenomena have Human Rights that are not being acknowledged. 

Have you experienced spiritual phenomena and share my passion to raise awareness in order to make the journey easier for others who are 'waking up'?

This is my plea to YOU to join me in making your voice heard. Together we can 'Emerge Proud.' I hope that our stories can provide a step along the bridge to ‘Mending the Gap’, and that the more of us who dare to speak out, the more ‘normalised’ and accepted these experiences will become within society in general. 

As Mahatma Ghandi said, “Be the change that you wish to see in the world.”

If you join me in being brave today, your efforts could go on to positively affect the lives of so many people going through the awakening process for years to come; we shouldn’t have to hide our reality or be ashamed to talk openly about it – WE can help reduce the stigma. Are you with me for the ride?

What I Need & What You Get

The money stuff…

I need to fund the following essentials:

Campaign branding and graphic designs (logo / certificate / marketing materials), video editing and final film creation, marketing costs, press release, distribution platform for the film premiere and hopefully a dedicated website to continue raising awareness after the campaign ends. Publishing costs to create a special edition compilation book to mark the Inaugural '#Emerging Proud' day on 17th March 2017

Finally, I need to fund myself – this is not easy to admit, but I have spent the last 4 years dedicating myself completely voluntarily to this work and I can no longer do it and sustain myself - I am struggling to survive but I have done too much to give up now. As we all know, part of integration after experiencing a spiritual awakening is juggling walking our path with earning a living, so this campaign does include funds to sustain me whilst I work on this for the next 6 months. If I raise more than my goal, I can promise you that I will continue to dedicate more of my time and focus to continuing this work for as long as I can. This is my life mission!  

Your perks:

Please see details on the Perks page, but as an overview... 

You can be involved in the project, follow all of the news, receive updates about new exciting interviews with experiencers and experts in the field and even have your story feature in the campaign from as little as £5 donation to the cause. 

If you are also struggling and cannot afford that but want to have your picture included in the campaign, please contact me. 

If you get the importance of this and feel inspired to donate more than the amounts listed in the perks - I love you! - Please contact me directly and I will gladly accept. 

What I’ll do if I don’t reach my target:

I will do all I can with the money raised. If I haven't got enough to create the film or publish the book I'll still run the campaign and show all of your video contributions on social media and create the biggest hype I can before 17th March 2017. 

What I’ll do with the extra if I reach over my target:

I pledge to continue raising awareness in any way I can with whatever the funds will allow - from writing articles for the media to organising big live events to bring together experiencers, expert speakers and researchers. I'll also donate to ISEN to enable us to continue working with people to develop Spiritual Emergence Networks in countries where they do not yet exist so people have access to free support around the world. 

Risks & Challenges

I've spent the last 4 years taking risks so I'm not going to stop here! 

Some of us know the risks of openly speaking about spiritual experiences only too well - there is the risk of losing family and friends, losing our job, being seen as completely crazy - the risks are real and they are huge. 

But we also know the risks of NOT speaking our truth; living a lie, becoming depressed and ill, feeling that life is not worth living. 

I am taking a risk because the alternative is worse... 

Ways You Can Help

In addition to making a pledge you could... 

Help to get the word out - make some noise about the campaign and show people around you that they are not alone! 

Use the Indiegogo share tools, let's spread this far and wide on social media!

Are you strapped for cash too but have a particular skill you’d like to donate to the campaign in exchange for taking part? If you can help with advertising / media strategy / Press release / Publication/ production or website creation please feel free to get in touch!

Host your own celebration party for the premiere on the 17th March 2017 – gather a group in your local area and get creative…#EmergeProud in your neighbourhood!

And that's all there is to it....Are you ready to create a new world together?

story:
Don't Just Dream It - Achieve It!

Hi, I'm Carolyn Trafford and I help other people live the life they want.

Having spent 24 yrs in the financial services industry I finally managed to break free and set up Reflections Coaching.  A business designed to help others figure out what they actually want from life and then how to go and get it.  

My personal choice has been about getting my life back into balance and changing to a career that helped others.  I know first hand from coaching others that goal setting and motivation can be difficult.  So I penned "Don't Just Dream It - Achieve It"

I could have just created a PDF and stuck it onto Amazon, but the great thing about my A5 spiral bound workbook is that it can be carried in a handbag or pocket, taken with you wherever you go and just be downright useful whenever you can spare some time.

I'm new to writing so self publishing a book means small print volumes and high costs.  I am appealing to potential investors to help me fund the printing costs.  By doing this I can afford to invest in a larger print run and drive down the cost of printing.  These costs are then passed onto the customer via a reduced retail price for the book.

So investing is NOT paying for my time over the summer writing - I did not take a summer holiday this year!

Investing will help me retail this book at an affordable and sensible price.

Investing will enable me to order a batch of approximately 100 books - rather than ten.  

Investing will enable me to retail the book at approximately £12-15 rather than £20-25.

Please take time to watch the video its not very long and filming it was a painful process for someone who prefers to be behind a camera.

hat We Need & What You Get

I've set a fund-raising goal of £3000, however this is flexible and whatever is raised will be invested directly into publishing and marketing.  I really need a minimum of £1500 to do an initial run of 200 books.  I am avoiding using any online printing companies and will be printing directly through companies that I know.

You get a choice of perks.  Your perk will be sent to you at the end of the campaign (Early December).  All perks include a copy of the book, either hard print or pdf - though I do recommend a printed version.  Optional perks include coaching support via email or over the phone, or if possible face to face.

Another optional perk is the beautiful "Don't Just Dream It" mug - great as a motivational reminder that you DO want to make your dreams a reality.

 

Challenges

My main challenge is getting the book in front of people who will buy it.  I have an extensive network both face to face and through social media so will be using my network to market together with a small marketing budget.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't financially contribute don't worry (or even if you can) - I need to reach as many people as possible - you can really help by emailing your contacts or sharing on social media. Indiegogo have some great share tools!

Thank you 

Carolyn
