Another optional perk is the beautiful "Don't Just Dream It" mug - great as a motivational reminder that you DO want to make your dreams a reality.
 
Challenges
My main challenge is getting the book in front of people who will buy it.  I have an extensive network both face to face and through social media so will be using my network to market together with a small marketing budget.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't financially contribute don't worry (or even if you can) - I need to reach as many people as possible - you can really help by emailing your contacts or sharing on social media. Indiegogo have some great share tools!
Thank you Carolyn

story:
Help us make Global Aum happen

We are a group of fun loving yoga practitioners bristling with excitement about the possibility of truly making a difference in the world. On a recent yoga event we were studying, exploring and experimenting with a very special sound vibration. The sound in itself is very simple to make and has a potent and profound power. It creates inner peace, cultivates social harmony, supports healing and can elevate us from gross mental states of conscious to more refined, subtle and elevated mental states of consciousness.

Quote from 20th Century spiritual teacher and mystique
The sound of AUM is heard only when your mind is completely silent, when you have gone beyond all language, all thinking, when there is pure silence, not even a ripple. Suddenly you hear a music but there is no instrument playing it. It is our very truth, is our very being. We are made of it.

The whole of existence vibrates, A certain vibration creates a tree, another vibration creates a bird, another vibration creates a man, but the whole existence, according to the mystics, is made of ONE sound. This sound is certainly the most sacred, the most divine, this sound is AUM

Our campaign is to get the whole world (well at least a good percentage of the whole world) to AUM at the same time, on the same day for a short period of 15 minutes followed by 5 minutes of silence, every year.  Can you imagine one single sound vibration emitted by millions of people all over the world?  

We want to get scientist and researchers to record and monitor the results of such a co-ordinated event. We cannot predict what the results will be BUT we have personal experience of the instant positive, harmonising and uplifting effects that this simple exercise can bring. On a mass scale this could be a truly historical event that not only unifies people and amplifies a sense of global community and love but also creates a subtle shift in the energy vibration of the world, healing and soothing the planet earth with an ocean of harmonious sound vibration waves filling the atmosphere.

We see this campaign as just the starting point to creating a global network of people from all nations on one database which can be used for a annual Global AUM as well as other mass community projects and information sharing.

What We Need

We need funds to 

a) create  a complex custom designed website that will be able to record and store Aum sounding video clips and all the details - name, country, age, gender etc of all the people who sign up to be a part of the  Global Aum Day. £ 2500

b) promote this project and reach as many people around the world as possible which will include social media adds etc £500

c) create and print a small simple yet informative booklet on Aum which details what Aum is, what effects chanting Aum can have... which will include scientific research on sound vibrations. £500

d) pay the project manager £1000

What You Can Receive
Unique perks

  • Global Aum 'Thank you' postcard.
  • Global Aum Booklet
  • Global Aum Fridge Magnet. 
  • Global Aum T-shirt. 
  • Become an Aum Group host and leader for this special experience. 
  • Become an official Global Aum Ambassador - Get really involved, Be on the GA committee and help decide which Global Community projects will receive support raised by the minimum 20 pence per person enrolment fee. 
  • A one week exclusive yoga retreat in the beautiful mountains of Austria with international yoga teacher. Including yoga, healthy food, sauna & spa and of course plenty of Aum chanting, Maximum 6 people in sharing accommodation 

If we dont reach our target we will seek other ways of adding funds so we can complete the Global Aum Experience. We will do our very best to actualise the Global Aum project!

What Can Aum Do?

In 1993 there was a dramatic sociological experiment that took place in  Washington, D.C. 4,000 TM practitioners 81 countries gathered together to practice transcendental meditation from June 7 to July 30.  During the 7 weeks period of time violent crime was reduced be  23 percent. The odds of this happening by chance is less than 2 in 1 billion! 

John Hagelin, lead author of the study and director of the Institute of Science, Technology  at Maharishi University said ‘meditation creates a state of deep relaxation and coherence in the individual and simultaneously produces an effect that spreads into the environment, influencing people who are not practicing the techniques and who have no knowledge of the experiments themselves."

We live in an auspicious time where the global net allows us to connect everybody on earth together in one instant like we have never been able to connect before. Repetition  of Aum is similar to the practice of TM and we feel Aum has the potential to create an extraordinary, never felt before, vibration phenomena across the entire planet. 

There are many beautiful organisations and individuals in the world who are advocates for world peace, healing and harmony. Small pockets of conscious Beings working for the greater good of this planet and humanity on the whole. BUT wouldn't it be even more beautiful if we could unite together as one global community. That time has come! NOW we can unite as one voice and just maybe our simple global gathering can be the start of something universally amazing.

Once we get the website completed we will begin to create a global network  and set the date for the first Global Aum. 
People will sign up on the site with their name, age, country etc and we hope to be able to create a function whereby each person can record their own unique Aum. At any time visitors to the site will be able to click on somebody's name and hear that persons Aum. The website will also enable visitors to get instant live statistics like:
 * how many people have signed up
 * how many people have signed up from specific countries
 * What percentage of people are female? male? under 20? etc 
 * Etc Etc Etc.

When people register on the Global on website there will be an option to also donate to the Global Aum community projects fund. All the money raised will be considered worldwide community funds and will be allocated to different global charities and projects by the founding members of Global Aum and Global Aum Ambassadors. 

Challenges

Reaching out to people in every single country and crossing language barriers will be a challenge. We will be relying on a professional promotion campaigner to give the Global Aum Experience worldwide exposure and coverage.
With a fully customised website we hope to have the website available in a number of different languages.


Other Ways You Can Help

Let everyone know. Talk about 'Global Aum' with your friends, family, co-workers, community. This is an exciting opportunity to get the WHOLE WORLD to unite and create a global sound vibration that could quite possible create a long overdue shift in global consciousness. 

We have already registered the domain name www.globalaum.com.

Keep in touch and when we officially launch Global AUM website please sign up and register to be a part of this amazing historical event for mankind and the planet earth.

 Order your Global Aum T-shirt and help to promote Global Aum.

story:
I need your help to get little kids to play!

Hi!  I am Ruth Barker - the Director of Toddler Education Services Pty Ltd.  I'm an Education Consultant and Author on all things little kids.  I write for parents and carers alike.  I help people develop amazing opportunities for little kids to play!

Play is a child's occupation - it's what they do to develop their physical body and 80% of their brain pathways by three years of age.  Without play THE BRAIN DOES NOT DEVELOP AS WELL!  

Here's the issue... we need to get kids back to play - they are not doing enough of it!
Baby Morris is their friend who encourages them - we are aiming to fund the first two books about play!  There will be more books to come and a doll to cuddle too!
Help Baby Morris and I to encourage the kids to get back to play!

$5000 AU means the first two books can be printed ready for sale!  This will then allow for the doll to be made...

For you:

EVERY DONATION OF $20 shall receive Icky Sticky (book one) and $40 shall receive a copy of each of the first two books of Baby Morris, Icky Sticky and Plop - for your little one, for a friend, for your local library...


EVERY DONATION OF $60 will receive both Baby Morris books PLUS an e-book each of Practical and Independent Little People and Sensory Motor Play for Little People - OR $80 WILL RECEIVE PRINT COPIES OF ALL FOUR BOOKS... 

...with over 2000 of my parenting books already sold they sure are a winner for every parent or carer!


It concerns me!

After working with little children under the age of five for over 25 years, I have become alarmed at the number of five year olds who are not developing well.  I see weak muscles both gross and fine, I see poor tool use - weak hands not being able to hold pencils or cut with scissors and I see very poor language skills.  I see too many parents using computers and the like,  as 'a play tool' to entertain little kids!

Now I study Occupational Therapy with an interest in Paediatrics because I am disturbed that there is such a demand right now for five year olds to be 'fixed' in the first year of school.

Guess what?  It's play that gets them ready PRIOR TO SCHOOL and we need to encourage it more!  From when babies are born they must play.  Play encourages them to move and build strong brains.

I am doing my best through my parenting books and media to educate parents but I want children to read the joy of play too and have mum and dad set up play JUST LIKE BABY MORRIS!

Check me out here at http://toddlereducationservices.com.au/ and feel free to help me spread the word about PLAY! ... and Baby Morris being a child's tool of encouragement!

story:
The Why

RENRA wants to make a positive impact by alleviating poverty around the world through sustainable means. One of the best ways to reduce poverty is by educating women in impoverished regions. 

The How

African Solar will provide MWEDO Girls Secondary School with enough solar energy to power a dorm, in turn, maximizing the education given to these students. The dorm will consist of 20 rooms with 4 girls in each room, thus providing electricity to more than 70 girls. 

The Ask

RENRA is asking for 5K to help make this come true. We have a solar panel sponsor who will ship them to Arusha, we have our team ready to go, and we have 1.5K for the power inverter. All that's left is the means of transportation to get us there, with round-trip flight tickets costing approximately $1,600 per person. We need your help to make this happen. 

The (Implementation+Financial) Plan


The Details (Background)

After being recognized by the Minister of Education of Tanzania, the school began early 2011 with over 100 students. The school accommodates ever rising demands for education amongst Maasai girls and young women offering sciences and business learning including arts and cultural studies. Almost all the students are boarders since most of them come from far to reach and underserved communities. The school enables girls to access formal education opportunity while engaging themselves in other technical skills including learning handmade products and continuing indigenous knowledge. In January 2012, MWEDO Girls Secondary School has 130 students, 10 teachers and 7other personnel. The school is in the continuous process of growing and improving. The new computer lab and library are still in need of books, tablets and computers; sports grounds, new dormitories and teachers’ housing are waiting their turn to be built.

https://www.facebook.com/pages/MWEDO-Girls-Seco...

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the means to donate, you can still help this project by sharing the campaign with your friends on social media using the hash-tag #AfricanSolar. If you know anyone who would be interested in helping us out, please direct them to this page. Every little bit helps, thank you!

story:
My name is Emily and I am a student at George Fox University studying elementary education and Spanish. I believe reading is the foundation for all things, and it is essential for all areas of life; however, not all students have the same opportunities due to many circumstances: poverty, disabilities, language barriers, etc. The SMART (Start Making a Reader Today) program helps to support these children to create more confident and fluent readers. I strongly support the SMART reading program because I believe every child should have the opportunity to read; however, the program needs more books in the Newberg School District to accommodate the growing number of students in the area. In order for this tremendously impactful program to continue serving thousands of kids, more books are needed. 

Every child should be able to read & with your help, they can.

   

DID YOU KNOW, one third of North American children who enter kindergarten are not school-ready, and lack some of the skills needed for a successful learning experience. 


AND, those who are read to at least 3 times per week are almost twice as likely to score in the top 25% in reading than children read to less than 3 times per week. 

AND, 44% of American fourth grade students cannot read fluently, even when they read grade-level stories aloud under supportive testing conditions. 

AND, a student who cannot read on grade level by third grade is 4 times less likely to graduate by age 19 than a child who does read proficiently in third grade. Add poverty to the mix, and a student is 13 times less likely to graduate on time than his or her proficient, wealthier peer.

                                     

The SMART's proven program has been aimed at addressing these issues and preparing Oregon's children for educational success.

SMART is a non-profit organization preparing thousands of children across Oregon with vital one-on-one reading support and books for those who need them most. Volunteers help students become confident and successful readers, but without enough books to read, the students are unable to grow in their literacy abilities.

Thank you so much for your support, every dollar makes a difference!

story:
Our Story...  

We are 11 students (a mix of undergraduates and graduate students) led by Georgeen Theodore at New Jersey Institute of Technology, School of Architecture and Design in Newark. Our studio was part of the Master of Infrastructure Planning (MIP) program. 

Between September of last year until January we worked on an entry for the Global Schindler Award, a design competition looking for an original design concept that would engage the specific spatial condition in Shenzhen, China "Considering the Interface between Mobility and the City". 

This was the first time in the history of the competition that it opened for North American universities. Out of the 250 total submission, only 12 were chosen. We are one of those teams! 

We are the only U.S. based team and we are traveling to Shenzhen to accept the award and see the site we became so passionate about! 

Why we need your help! 

Traveling to Shenzhen isn't cheap. Between airfare, hotel and transportation we expect each one of us to spend more then $2000.  We're all college students and lets be honest, we can't afford this on our own! 

As designers we believe that you cannot design for a place without knowing it. For months we used, maps, books, comics, journals, youtube videos and virtual street views images to learn Shenzhen and propose a design specific to the needs of the local community. We couldn't go before, but we definitely have a will and reason now! 

The $5000 that we are asking for will be spent on air-fare, trains, hotels and visa applications. 

What's so important about this? 

Our project, SEZ to EZX: Shenzhen Xrossroads, proposes that rather than starting again and remaking the site anew, SQ should build on what it already has going for it: existing agglomerations of small and mid-sized firms, clusters of urban villages, incredible road and raid infrastructure, and (a nearly lost) network of rivers. Our vision is the EZX, a next-generation economic zone that facilitates the growth of migrant  business enterprises and (MBEs) and offers a mix of housing options that will help retain the migrant population. The existing east-west and north-south transportation corridors are transformed into "stitched", high density, mixed use, green-blue development (the "X"). 

Through the process of uncovering the Buji River and preserving the existing natural system, we identify nodes which create a secondary system of pedestrian and bicycle mobility throughout the site. Second, we preserve the vibrant local [micro]entrepreneurship located in SQ. These are small scale business owned by locals who produce and sell furniture, kitchenware, toys as well as banks, food logistics centers and human resources. Third, we strengthen the local [macro]industry production by creating a new middle-scale freight within the northern part of SQ. Complemented by the system of micro entrepreneurs and new mobility systems a new middle class of migrant workers can be established. Fourthly, we intervene within the housing typologies throughout SQ. We aim to create a physical connection to the natural environment which will support a healthy equatable community. Lastly, we connect the natural environment, micro entrepreneurs, macro entrepreneurs and housing by creating fluid mobility of pedestrians, cyclists, local travel and regional travel. These mitigations take the form of small design moves meant to overcome the different barriers around SQ.

Regional connection- stretching vertically on the site, the transit spine makes SQ a destination in the Pearl River Delta. Water filtration along the rivers and urban villages cleans the once polluted water. Local connections- a new grid will promote urban movements on the ground and streets of the city. A more mobile city will develop better economy and social inclusion for all! Linear city- densely populating the center allows for total usage of the site. The lungs of the city filtrate the air near the busy highway allowing for a breathable SQ. Development patches- patches have been designated for industry, commercial, recreational, residential, and civic purposes. Patches overlap in areas to promote integration of use. Landscape-reintroduces the natural elements on the site which provide recreational spaces of urban and migrant workers. Air quality increases as space is designated for green space and remained unbuilt.

As designers we believe that you cannot design for a place without knowing it. For months we used, maps, books, comics, journals, youtube videos and virtual street views images to learn Shenzhen and propose a design specific to the needs of the local community. We couldn't go before, but we definitely have a will and reason now! 
The $5000 that we are asking for will be spent on air-fare, trains, hotels and visa applications. 
    What's so important about this?  Our project, SEZ to EZX: Shenzhen Xrossroads, proposes that rather than starting again and remaking the site anew, SQ should build on what it already has going for it: existing agglomerations of small and mid-sized firms, clusters of urban villages, incredible road and raid infrastructure, and (a nearly lost) network of rivers. Our vision is the EZX, a next-generation economic zone that facilitates the growth of migrant  business enterprises and (MBEs) and offers a mix of housing options that will help retain the migrant population. The existing east-west and north-south transportation corridors are transformed into "stitched", high density, mixed use, green-blue development (the "X"). 






Through the process of uncovering the Buji River and preserving the
existing natural system, we identify nodes which create a secondary
system of pedestrian and bicycle mobility throughout the site. Second, we
preserve the vibrant local [micro]entrepreneurship located in SQ. These
are small scale business owned by locals who produce and sell furniture,
kitchenware, toys as well as banks, food logistics centers and human
resources. Third, we strengthen the local [macro]industry production
by creating a new middle-scale freight within the northern part of SQ.
Complemented by the system of micro entrepreneurs and new mobility
systems a new middle class of migrant workers can be established.
Fourthly, we intervene within the housing typologies throughout SQ.
We aim to create a physical connection to the natural environment
which will support a healthy equatable community. Lastly, we connect
the natural environment, micro entrepreneurs, macro entrepreneurs and
housing by creating fluid mobility of pedestrians, cyclists, local travel and
regional travel. These mitigations take the form of small design moves
meant to overcome the different barriers around SQ.
Regional connection- stretching vertically on the site, the transit spine
makes SQ a destination in the Pearl River Delta. Water filtration along
the rivers and urban villages cleans the once polluted water. Local
connections- a new grid will promote urban movements on the ground
and streets of the city. A more mobile city will develop better economy
and social inclusion for all! Linear city- densely populating the center
allows for total usage of the site. The lungs of the city filtrate the air near
the busy highway allowing for a breathable SQ. Development patches-
patches have been designated for industry, commercial, recreational,
residential, and civic purposes. Patches overlap in areas to promote
integration of use. Landscape-reintroduces the natural elements on the
site which provide recreational spaces of urban and migrant workers. Air
quality increases as space is designated for green space and remained
unbuilt.

story:
The Superhero Children Project is an after-school enrichment program that uses science, philosophy and meditation to teach self-awareness and inner-voice to children ages 7-15... and it works! After 3 wildly successful semesters at HISD's Garden Oaks Elementary we are ready to expand. This means we need to train teachers and cover teaching and marketing expenses. This means we need funding and to receive proper funding we need to be an established nonprofit with a tax exempt status. 

The mission of the project is to provide the Superhero Children Program to students free of charge and then to connect the graduated students in a local social network (think of this as a life-long networking of heart-centered future decision makers.) We will start locally, then regionally, the nationally and, eventually globally to teach as many children as we possibly can to love and celebrate their truest selves, to follow their hearts and to make decisions based on what feels right for them. This is, in essence, our giving back to politics. We will teach as many of our future leaders as we can to follow their hearts and love themselves. Imagine politicians doing this? It's like a social art experiment. What will come of a generation of self-love? And what can they accomplish together? I want to know. Don't you?

Please help cover the expense of getting the Superhero Children Project established as a non-profit so we can FINALLY say YES to the funds available for expanding this incredible project. And, if you want to be an even bigger part of the creation of this project, we will soon be seeking funding to train teachers and offer these classes free of charge to as many children as we can reach! Visit our website to learn more about our 4 step plan for teaching children throughout the world!

To know more about the Superhero Children Project or Alexis Anne Moore, visit:
 www.SuperheroChildren.com
www.Soulgarden.tv.

Peace,

Alexis

story:
Why We're Here:

  • There are an estimated  1 million jobs that are projected to go unfilled in Computing fields by 2020 (Code.org foundation) while the nationwide average for high schools providing computer science courses is 1 in 10.
  • The "Do You See I.T."? Challenge is a movement to provide Community, Confidence, and Competence with Technology to K-12 students and teaching professionals in under-served [urban and rural] communities throughout the Southeastern United States. 

Who We Are:

  • We are CommunityCode, a team of Young Professionals driven by One Passion to help our Communities See I.T.! 
  • Our skill sets range from Computer Science, Education, Sociology, Law, Engineering, Mathematics, and Innovative Entrepreneurship.

What We Do:

  • CommunityCode is a Computing and Information Technology (I.T.) Accelerator:
  • We operate alongside schools to provide opportunities for students to engage in I.T.
  • In the last year-and-a-half, we have run programs at 11 independent sites throughout South Carolina and Florida, and have served more than 2,100 students.

Where It Goes:

  • Each dollar that you donate will help us bring interactive experiences in technology and life skills  to hundreds of students in underserved (urban and rural) communities throughout the Southeast.
    • $10,000 will help us purchase instructional equipment, such as laptops, tablets, and other supplies.
    • $10,000 will lower the cost for interested students to attend our Summer Camps and After-school Programs.
  • If our goal of $20,000 is not reached, all funds raised will be used to lower the cost of Summer Camp for interested students.

Perks:

  • Don’t want to make a donation? That’s okay. You can also support our cause in a number of other ways:
    • Purchase a "Do You See I.T."? T-shirt for $25, or
    • Purchase a "Do You See I.T."? Tech Sticker for $3
    • Use the Indiegogo tools to share this campaign with friends, family, and others who believe in our mission!

story:
Missouri (and the World) Needs Dinosaurs!

Who We Are

The Missouri Institute of Natural Science is a facility in Springfield, MO, dedicated to studying the natural past to help better understand the present and predict the future. We started small, grew to medium, and now we’re ready to really take off. Our fossil and mineral collection grows daily, and we want to show it to you. We want to show it to you for FREE. We’re cool like that. We have never charged admittance to the museum, and we hope we never will. Despite this generosity and seeming lack of good business sense over the last 14 years, we’ve managed to make it this far. We’ve done this without incurring any debt, and that’s pretty amazing. We’ve done this using only volunteers, dedicated volunteers. We’ve done this in the buckle of the Bible belt, where young-Earth Creationism keeps the teaching of evolution out of our schools, and that goes beyond amazing. But now we want to get bigger. We’ve got the stuff to show, we just need more room to show it. We need a bigger building. We’ve got the land, we’ve got the building design, and we’ve got a large part of our funding. But we’re not quite where we need to be financially to give the public the quality product they deserve. This is where you come in.

Where We Are Now

We have exhibits featuring some of the oldest rocks on earth. We can show you fossils from the Permian, the Carboniferous, the Cretaceous, and into the Pleistocene, but we could show you a lot more stuff if we had the room. We’ve got it tucked away in storage, we’ve got it in the process of being prepared for display, and we’re going all over the country collecting donated materials and even digging up stuff ourselves.

Right now we’re working on the restoration and mounting of Henry, a triceratops dug and retrieved by the Institute’s excavation team. Not for nothing, but restoration is expensive and time consuming. We got it handled, though. We do it for free and out of our own pockets because we love it. The problem, though, is giving Henry, who will be the largest mounted triceratops in America once complete, the quality exhibit structure and setting he deserves. In addition to being the largest mounted triceratops, Henry will also be the only mounted fossilized dinosaur in Missouri. Let me say that again: THE ONLY MOUNTED FOSSIL DINOSAUR IN MISSOURI. Come on, Missouri. You can be better than that.

“But Missouri Institute of Natural Science,” you might be saying, “there’s really not that many dinosaurs that have even been found in Missouri.” You’d be right. Henry is from Wyoming. But we have access to the site where those Missouri dinosaurs were found. And we’ll dig them up and put them on display. We’ve got some fossil specimens from that site now. We want some more. We need a place to show them to you.

Dinosaurs are cool, but some people like other things. To make those people happy, we’ve got minerals. And we have some pretty good displays of those. We can have more. If you like minerals and rocks, we’ve got ‘em and we want you to come see them. But when you come, we want to make sure we knock your socks off. We need to make our displays the best they can be for you. Maybe dinosaurs and minerals aren’t your thing. Let me take another stab at it.

Ice Age mammals. The Missouri Institute of Natural Science rocks the Ice Age hardcore. We’ve got saber tooth cats, hyaenedons, mammoth, mastodon, oreodont…the list goes on and on. The really cool part is that not only do we have displays of these animals, but we have an actual fossil site on the museum grounds. Riverbluff Cave is the oldest Ice Age fossil cave in North America. We’ve found fossils and trace fossils of the giant short-face bear, mammoths, American lion, peccaries, and more. We’re still looking and still finding more. The cave is cool, but is closed to the public because it is still a research cave. In the future, if funding is available, we can run paleontological and geological field schools out of the cave for college students and people who want to learn and get dirty. The fossils are on display, though. Most of them. We have more. We’ll find more. We want you to see them.

Where We Want to Be

Nothing succeeds like success. Given room enough, the museum could easily become a DESTINATION. In the world of museums, DESTINATION status is greatly desired. So yeah, we want to be that. We want to be the place people go to see real dinosaurs and more in the Midwest. When those people come to the museum, they will make donations, and buy some of the cool stuff from our gift shop. That will help us maintain the facility and pay the bills. But most of all, those people will tell others about us. Bringing in more people who will make donations and buy cool stuff.

Another success which will help us further succeed is through our educational outreach program. We send volunteers to schools to talk about our mission and our dinosaurs. Put a piece of fossilized dinosaur poop in a ten year old’s hand, and you’ve made a friend for life. And then those students become involved. They will bug their teachers to visit our museum on a field trip or bug their parents to bring them on a weekend. Volunteers help make the field trip a good experience. We DO charge for field trips from schools, because they get to do and see some extra stuff when they come visit us. The better facility we can offer, the more field trips we get. The more field trips, the more kids get inspired about science and the natural world.

What We’re Up Against

The Missouri Institute of Natural Science is a 501(C3) organization, or not-for-profit organization. We face the same obstacle that many not-for-profit organizations face: indifference. Other organizations advocate for babies, children, cures for diseases, and a variety of admirable goals. Those things are great, and well worth supporting. But while they may face indifference, they rarely face opposition. The mission of The Missouri Institute of Natural Science is a different story. WE think its well worth supporting, but there are people, particularly in the surrounding area, who find our mission objectionable. They prefer us to stay small and easy to ignore. We have rarely faced active opposition, but we have faced it. It’s the passive opposition that hurts. Right now, that passive opposition is winning.  It’s keeping teachers who know better from teaching evolution in the classroom. That’s right, many students in this region graduate high school knowing evolution is a thing, but they have no idea about how it works or the changes proposed since it was introduced. This passive opposition is also a factor in the greater community. Individuals and local businesses that rely on public goodwill are reluctant to be seen supporting the Institute. So we’re taking it to the streets and the internet. Springfield has a variety of views, and we are grateful for our supporters in this area, but to reach our goals, we need more.

What You Can Do

Give us money. Give us a little, or give us a lot. It’s all tax deductible. We’ll take a dollar. Every dollar helps. If you’re serious about helping us in our mission, though, give more than a dollar. We’ll give you stuff. We WANT to give you stuff. Check out our perks. If you get the chance, come visit us. We love visitors and want a whole lot more. Thank you for giving us the chance to educate the community and provide a sorely needed resource in this area.

story:
Open School Archaeology

We as students and teachers of the Open School Archaeology program need help purchasing new equipment and reducing the cost for kids to travel down to the Tsegi Canyon for an experience of a lifetime.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to purchase:

Two tents

Four new water filters

New cooking supplies 

Two Stoves

After the money for supplies is raised all additional proceeds will be dedicated to sending future trip participants in to the field

Cost:$200 per person per trip 

In turn for your support you will receive various rewards including the Photography of Chuck Haspels, a local Cortez based photographer who accompanies us on our trips. 

The Impact

You will be impacting the lives of students in the Archaeology program, helping students dive in deep to College level Research and Documentation. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share the Campaign with family and friends and on any social media sites!

Thank you for your support!

story:
We are going to Deutschland. Hilf uns, bitte!

Reagan High School in the historic Houston Heights has kicked off the first school-to-school exchange program in its 87 year history. This partnership is a really big deal for an urban HISD school - it's changing the lives of participating students and transforming our school. Most of the participating students have never traveled beyond Texas and Mexico. In October we hosted 9 fabulous German kids from Leipzig for two amazing weeks. It was a fantastic experience - but now we need to go to Germany and reunite with our partners!

Financial Need

Plane tickets to Germany in the peak season of summer are pretty expensive, and Reagan High School is 52% at-risk and 74% economically disadvantaged. The cost for each student to go to Germany to reunite with their new Leipzig friends is about $1500 per student. We still need  $500 per student to get us over the hump and make the trip financially feasible for our Houston kids.
Our donation levels and perks are named after one of the three legendary composers from Leipzig. Please give generously - donations will get us to Germany this year, and continue the program into the future, with a new group of 10 kids going every two years.

The Impact

This program has already changed the lives of our Houston students. They have made fast friends with their Leipzig counterparts, and in some cases they even feel like family. We need your help to take the next step of going to Leipzig, where we can continue the bonding process and the cultural exchange. 

Since this is the first year for this exchange program, your support will help cement the program and demonstrate to future Reagan students that the whole world is within reach.

The Journey

Reagan High School has a wonderful student body, but financial and cultural insecurity prevent so many of Houston students from achieving independence and freedom. 

Your support of this program will give some great Houston kids a life-changing experience that will empower them, and introduce them to a life of unlimited options. If they can go to Europe and form international friendships, they can go anywhere, including college and global careers

The program not only changes the lives of the participants, it has inspired the entire school; when the 10 students from Germany visited us for two weeks, the world suddenly seemed so much smaller to our 2000 Reagan students.

OTHER WAYS TO HELP!

If you know someone who's life was changed by international travel or living abroad, please pass this crowd-funding link on to them! Spread the word through social media, and help send us to Germany!

story: The Panther Pride Marching Band needs to replace their 15 year old uniforms. Many of the uniforms are frayed and torn. The pants are all white and require constant cleaning to maintain a good look. The band has to spend $6300 annually cleaning the uniforms. Our new uniforms will require a lot less maintenance and also give the band a much sleeker modern look. The uniform we are raising money for is pictured above.

story:
About Textbook Collective

Right now, students’ wallets are being gouged to keep up with the cost of their text books. Right now, students are being given the run around as to why the newest edition of textbooks are “required” when we know not much really changes. The reason for all this is simple: textbooks make large profits for school book stores, online sites and publishers.  How many times have you purchased a book and used only a portion of it for a class and thought you weren't getting your money’s worth?  How many of you have been in the library at your school and wondered, "Where are the books I need?” 

Textbook Collective aims to lower the price of textbook rentals to under $150 per semester for every student.  If you have ever borrowed a book from a student who's taken the class before or loaned a book to a student in need, you know of the relief it brings. Textbook Collective runs on the same idea, but on a larger scale by borrowing books from and loaning to students across the country.  This gives you access to many more books than you can find among your friends, and gets the most value out of the books you have already purchased while guaranteeing your book's safety. Textbook Collective can streamline this process and bring the price per rental under $13 per book per semester, which includes standard shipping both ways.

By donating to Textbook Collective we can get started loaning books to students below any price on the market, freeing up resources for students and keeping big investors out of the textbook rental industry.  With every donation and book loan, students are investing in their own education and that of their peers.  There are over 21 million students in the United States. Those with a full schedule each need at least 4-5 textbooks.  The books were out there last semester, so let’s put them to work for us.


How Textbook Collective Works

  • Students sign up with Textbook Collective for free and enter the titles of the books they'd like to loan.  We'll let you know right away which books we can accept and which ones we can't (schools usually require more recent editions and those are the books other students need).
  • Students will also be able to browse and create a cart of books they would like for the upcoming semester.  This cart stays idle while we await your books arrival.
  • Next, each student ships their books to Textbook Collective's warehouse. Students will pay for initial shipping. (USPS medium and large flat rate boxes up to 70 lbs are less than $20 and shipping via media mail is even cheaper!)
  • Once we receive your book, we inspect it, place a bar code on it, scan it into our system and credit your account for the number and value of books you've loaned. This allows you to check out the same value of books from Textbook Collective's inventory. Students will receive an email of successful receipt of their books. This ensures everyone's property is treated well by only allowing other members to borrow against what they own.
  • Now your idle cart will be active and you can make any changes before we ship the books on hand you requested.  If there is a book we don't have yet but are expecting to be returned soon, you may wait to have your whole order ship together to save you shipping costs.
  • Once students receive rented books and the return shipping label, they inspect books for damage and save the shipping box. Now you can put the books to work!  
  • After the semester is over, ship the books back to us with the prepaid label and the cycle will continue.
  • Your books will be loaned every semester someone needs it, helping other students and counting as your credit to check out books you need.  
  • If your books stay on the shelf for more than 2 semesters, we know there isn't a demand for that book and we pay the shipping back to you. This is to ensure students are always provided with books they need.


What We Need & What You Get

We're looking for $100,000 in funding.  $30,000 of this is to get our first warehouse for one year.  It will be able to house 150,000 books, ensuring we have a large selection for our members.  The next $35,000 will go to software development and integration, website development, mobile apps, hardware, shipping materials and warehouse shelving.   $30,000 will go to pay for the office and warehouse staff who will receive, inspect, and shelve your books in preparation for our first shipping. And the final $5000 goes to fees for running the campaign.  

If we exceed our goal, we will be able to start with a larger warehouse, better sorting software (for lower shipping costs), more software developers (for a quicker launch), a larger customer service staff to better serve students and more promotion to get the word about Textbook Collective out quicker.

If we reach between 75 and 100% of our goal we will continue on with a smaller initial warehouse.

If we reach less than 75% of our goal we will use the funds to develop the Textbook Collective website and software development, while promoting Textbook Collective for a future launch.

Perks

For the first 100 donations we will give priority registration.  You believed in us first and we want to do everything we can to ensure you're first in line.

For the next 300 we'll give you next in line priority registration.

For study groups of 5 friends we'll give you group priority registration.

For cohort groups (people in the same pipeline or clubs) we'll give you group priority registration for 10, 20 or 30 people.


The Impact

We, as students, can do something about the high price of books: we can share. It’s an old idea used in a new way. Textbook Collective is our library of the books we use and need, owned by students and loaned to students at the lowest cost possible.  Counties, cities and institutions budget for or levy taxes to pay for libraries, but they don't have current academic textbooks.  So where are the books other students used last semester?  They're at home on the shelf, or in the garage, or back at our parents’ houses.  Some have been resold or loaned to friends and some overpriced rentals have been returned.  If we could squeeze all the value and potential learning out of our books and connect with over 21 million other college students, we could change the way textbooks are rented forever.  With your contribution and your loan we can help each other and ourselves take back some of our resources.

Textbook Collective is committed to continually lowering the price of text books as our membership grows.  More students means more textbooks and a greater selection.  It also allows us to ship in bulk and save you more.  Your books are safe with us since the only people that can check out books are members in good standing with books in Textbook Collective .  Most importantly your book always belongs to you and as demand drops, we contact you and ship your book back, read, studied and well-traveled.

Risks & Challenges

Challenges: 

Getting the website, warehousing, shipping and receiving software written and working in a timely manner so we can get books in and out as efficiently as possible.  

We have programmers who have created and integrated these types of systems before and know that thousands of libraries around the world already run similar systems.

Getting enough books in the system so there is a large selection for everyone.  

If every contributor talks to the people in their major at their school, then you are ensuring that the books you need are waiting for you and future students.

The logistics of moving all these books every semester.  

We plan to optimize our warehouse and already have people with experience in high volume shipping companies.

Attending to customers’ needs and concerns as Textbook Collective grows.  

We want your experience with Textbook Collective to be the best it can be.  Were here to serve and help you get the books you need for the smallest price.  As we get larger we will hire the customer service staff required to answer your questions in a timely manner.

Risks:

People damaging your book.  

Most people don't damage library books or rental books, and when mistakes happen, they have to pay.  Same here.  If your book is damaged or lost, the person who checked it out will be held responsible, whether it be through fees or the cost of the book. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are a recent graduate and would like to put your books into Textbook Collective even if you're not going to check out any books, GREAT!   We need all the books we can get.  If you have siblings or friends, you can let them use your books to get the books they need as well.  

If you're a parent, grandparent, teacher, counselor, or mentor you can donate in the name of you child who will someday be in college.  Just like investing in a college savings fund, donating to start Textbook Collective now will allow your student to save in the future.

Get the word out!  Everyone who knows someone in school should let them know about what we’re doing and why.  The more students we can serve the better. We'd rather have 20,000 students give $5 to meet our goal and tell all their friends, than have 5 investors give $20,000 each.  We’re here to serve students.  

 

Some press we've gotten

http://blogs.ocweekly.com/navelgazing/2015/03/t...

story:
My Story

My name is Sander. I am 21 years old. I am a friend, a law and economics student, and a young entrepreneur. I am an Estonian and I need your help.

For three years, I have been studying the field of on-demand economy by writing research papers and being in contact with many of its advocators. Lately, my team and I have been building a platform of on-demand construction workers for firms.

Two years ago, I heard about Draper University, school for young heroes. I wanted to go there, but decided to wait, as I had no real business idea to develop. Times have changed and as of now, I have been accepted to go to Draper for a 6-week entrepreneurship program, starting this June.

But there is just one problem. I still need to pay for tuition with money I have yet to collect.

What I Need & What You Get

Breakup of the total funding I need is below:

Tuition: $ 9,500
Travel: $ 1,500
Living Expenses: $ 1,500
Scholarship I have got: $ 2,500
Funding I already have: $ 1,000

Amount to be raised: $ 9,000

As gratitude for helping me, I will give You a chance to choose Yourself an unique perk. It will either be sentimental, like a personal letter from the US or I will be useful for You by giving You exposure. For the full list of perks, look to the right side and choose the one You like the most.

If I shall not reach the entire goal here, I will still use the money to fund the tuition and sell my soul for the rest.

The Impact

At first, I wanted to go to Draper University in order to meet the rockstars of the startup world, such as Elon Musk, Andy Tang and many others teaching there. I know that attending this program will help me take our team’s ventures to the next level, as I will get to meet experts from our industry and potential investors for the future.

Now, I have also been made an offer by the University of Tartu that upon my return, I will start leading the pre-accelerator in Pärnu College and give workshops in University of Tartu based on what I learn. This way, I will also give back to society, as I will be helping other young opportunists by giving them the knowledge how to build their startups.

Other than that, I will also let You follow the entire trip to Draper University and Silicon Valley by keeping a blog & vlog.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute please help me spread the word about this great opportunity!

  • Tweet about this
  • Share this message on Facebook
  • Check out Draper University website and spread their mission
  • Use the Indiegogo Share tools below!
A big THANK YOU for sharing :)

story:
Breast Cancer Survivors Club

We want to build an online community for Breast Cancer Survivors and Their Families For Support, Resources, Friendships and Outreach.

  • My Name is Douglas J. Cohon and I am the president of Amusement Digest Inc. AD Inc. I helped to create the Pink Ribbon App on Facebook Back In 2008.  If you look in the gallery at http://bit.ly/19FA98Z we have added just donations we made to Komen and have requested documents from other charities in order for you to know what we have done in the past and what we plan to do more of in the future.
  • We are building our own Social Network similar to Facebook but for Survivors and their families so that members are able to communicate with each other when they want without restrictions to each other. It will be one of the first Social Networks solely designed for Breast Cancer Survivors and their families. No dependency on third party software updates. We want a place where members can share their experiences, stories, and hope with other members as well as get the resources and tools they need on their journey.
  • You are a crucial part of our plan to achieve our goals. It is going to cost a lot of money to get everything up and running. While we have developers working on the site and some money to get the marketing started we are short on achieving our goals. 


We Need To Get The Word Out


  • We are looking to raise at least 5,000 to our marketing/development goals to get the word out to the millions of survivors and their families. We are trying to fund some of the software we will be using to develop the site as well as start an online and offline campaigns to reach new members.
  • In exchange for your help we have added perks to make you a sponsor of the site for life so that all of our members know who has helped us to build this community. 

The Impact

  • There are over 236k people diagnosed with Breast Cancer every single year and they are all looking for support. There are so many charity sites online, and we have dealt with many of them, that do not offer support and resources to those who need them. They collect donations for awareness when newly diagnosed women are already aware. 
  • In the years of running the Pink Ribbon on Facebook I was sent many awards from charities that we had donated 10's of thousands of dollars to. One thing we realized is after the women started to contact us there was no real help out there for them. Even things like wigs were not something many of the big Charities helped with. Another thing that surprised me was that there was not mammogram services by many of them. A few did offer help for that but most would just refer you to another charity. New survivors should not get the run around where they are on hold for hours just trying to find the right connections. 
  • I want this community to be for all survivors, families and newly diagnosed people. I want a community where people do not get the run around when looking for help and support. Let's face it, this is an emotional journey for so many. They need a place where they can reach out to each other for support and share their life experiences. They deserve this and with your help we can make it happen!

Risks & Challenges

Some of the biggest risks of this project is to not get enough initial signups to self sustain the community. This is a risk with any social network.

  • I have been in online marketing for many years. Many of the obstacles that I need to face I can overcome. We need to raise enough money to get the members to sign up and spread the word about the community. Creating an initial buzz over something with being a huge corporation is getting tougher online these days. 
  • My plan is to work day and night until any and all obstacles for achieving this goal are overcome. We are not afraid to work morning til night 7 days a week to reach our goals.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you cannot help financially you can help us by spreading the word about  the online community at http://breastcancersurvivorsclub.com/. We would appreciate it highly and value your support. Just go there, enter your email and hit the Share Button. Thank you for your support!
  • You can also use the IndieGOGO tools to share this campaign.

You can also use the IndieGOGO tools to share this campaign.

story:
These pieces fit together like a donut and the hole...

The First Piece-                                                                                                               An audible "Gasp!" spread through the community when a For Sale sign appeared on the side of the Sweet Shop.  As with any small town, there are places and traditions that are almost sacred -- this is one of them. 

Since 1955 the Sweet Shop has been a constant presence on River St. in the resort community of Elk Rapids, Michigan.  After 50 years as bakers, the current owners, Darlene & Dirk Renzema are looking forward to retirement and have the business up for sale.  Its valuable main street location has drawn interest from an assortment of developers -- all of whom see condos & high-end retail space as a more practical use.  That same prime location prices the property out of the reach of potential buyers focused on preserving this historic, community-supporting, award-winning, northern Michigan bakery - Best in Northern Michigan -- 11th best in the State

Anyone living in a tourist community understands the frustration as small, local businesses give way to speculators and chain stores.  Dirk & Darlene's hope is that the Sweet Shop can continue as a bakery, mirroring the hopes of the hundreds of customers who urged us to move forward with this campaign. Customers who left their fingerprints on these donut cases as children are now bringing their grandchildren to sample sweets created by Dirk, a 4th generation baker who began  his career in his grandparent's bakery in The Netherlands.  Without a sale, this will be the last season for the Sweet Shop.  Elk Rapids without the Sweet Shop is like...a donut without the hole.

The Second Piece-                                                                                             

Likewise, many girls growing up in today's world also feel less than complete. Regardless of their age, grade point, or level of affluence, teenage girls are in crisis.  Absent fathers, abusive boyfriends, family breakdowns, unhealthy role models, bullying, the sexualization of everything -- unrealistic expectations attacking their self-image from every angle.  In some cases adults are failing in their responsibility to support and protect them, requiring them to make adult decisions while they are still children, and leaving them feeling lost, inadequate, fearful, ungrounded and betrayed.

Since 2011, Right Tree, an Elk Rapids-based charity has been committed to helping girls discover their worth, their gifts, their voice, and their future.  Within a framework of outdoor recreation, camping and adventure programming we provide positive input, experiences and settings for girls to share, discuss, and address issues like relationships, bullying, social media, self-image, lies, and hope.  Our programs are available on a donations basis and our focus is to make sure every teen girl believes and lives out our theme: Every girl matters!  Check out our website


How These Pieces Fit-                                                                                               While Right Tree relies on like-minded donors, we also believe today's charities are called to develop creative, innovative and sustainable revenue sources.  Right Tree Adventure Rentals is one of those sources for us.  With equipment donated specifically for that purpose, our shop offers outdoor recreational equipment rentals (kayaks, stand up paddle boards, bikes, etc) to the community on a donation basis. The natural resources around us become accessible to everyone, regardless of their ability to pay, AND Right Tree has a constant and predictable source of income.  Donations flow directly back into Right Tree programs.  In 2014 the rental shop generated 40% of our operating revenue.  We want to expand that model by purchasing the Sweet Shop -- saving a successful historic business AND using that success to change the experiences and expectations of girls in our community.  


Here's What We Need:

Right Tree Adventure Rentals would not exist without the initial donation of equipment.  That initial gift has generated 160% of its value to date and continues to grow each year.  The shop provides visibility for our programs, new experiences to residents & visitors, free equipment use for schools & other non-profits, summer jobs for a number of teens and college students AND a substantial portion of operational funding for Right Tree.

The Sweet Shop has the potential to multiply that successful model MANY times over -- in terms of visibility, revenue, community support and job creation. Donating a bakery is expensive.  Especially one sitting on a prime piece of resort property. With your help we can kill two birds with one stone -- saving this historic business and using it to expand and sustain the business of transforming girls' lives.

Here's what a donated bakery costs:

  • $329,000 bakery property/building/business/recipes/training
  • $    8,045   perks - provided ONLY if we meet our goal
  • $  35,000  closing/licensing/upgrade/interim costs
  • $  27,854   Indiegogo and online pay service fulfillment fees
        $399,899  TOTAL 
Because of confidentiality restrictions, we cannot share specific financial information regarding the bakery.   Dirk & Darlene have operated it for 22 years and it remains a successful, healthy enterprise with a 39% profit margin prior to owner distributions.  The sale includes their agreement to continue to work with  and train our staff during the transition.  
This is an all-or-nothing project for Right Tree.  As with the rental center -- without the donation of the original equipment, it could not have happened.  Without reaching our financial goal, the purchase of the Sweet Shop  cannot happen. With the success of this campaign, Right Tree will assume ownership in the fall of 2015.  If we fall short of our goal, 100% of the moneys received will be used to further the long-range goals and objectives of Right Tree:
  • provide year-round programming
  • expand to include 6-12th grade girls
  • provide programming for middle school boys
  • provide resources for parents
  • develop tools to facilitate healthy adult/teen interactions
All gifts are tax deductible and contributors will receive an email receipt for tax purposes.

Besides purely providing funding for programs, we can:

  • provide jobs & job training for area teens
  • provide opportunities for adults to share their professional baking skills with teens
  • partner with The Great Lakes Culinary Institute as a venue for resources, support and placement of students and graduates
  • serve as an outlet and provide support for related home-based businesses
  • partner with other local non-profits in their fundraising efforts
  • improve awareness of the full spectrum of Right Tree programs
With your help, this will be a win/win for the entire community!

Risks & Challenges

Admittedly, moving into the realm of baking presents a new challenge.  Much of that is being addressed by the Renzemas' willingness to provide training in both their time-honored recipes and their techniques.  While the bakery offers tremendous opportunity for growth -- for the immediate future, mirroring their model is a reliable path to success.  Renzemas will continue to operate the bakery through this coming tourist season -- turning over the reins after the completion of their, and our, busiest season -- giving us the winter to train our team, re-open, and re-launch!

Our most pressing need will be to finalize our baking team.  A number of qualified bakers have worked with the Renzemas over the years and are looking for local employment.  The Great Lakes Culinary Institute has indicated many of their bakery students & graduates are yearning for exactly this type of challenging, socially-conscious job opportunity.   Renzemas are committed to training new staff. Success will require teamwork -- just as we are on the cutting edge of rethinking the mechanics of non-profit funding, we will be rethinking and re-examining the mechanics of running a community bakery.  Several members of our Board of Directors are entrepreneurs and business owners and have been advising us throughout this process. 

How Else Can You Help?

  • Spread the word on social media and in person. Quickly! - Use Indiegogo Share tools!
  • Include information on this campaign in newsletters, signage, and web pages
  • Encourage friends to share our campaign too -- the more people who know            about what we're trying to do the better!
  • Stop by Elk Rapids Sweet Shop and discover why it's famous!
  • Email us with your bakery ideas or specific skills you can offer.
story_txt:
These pieces fit together like a donut and the hole... The First Piece-                                                                                                               An audible "Gasp!" spread through the community when a For Sale sign appeared on the side of the Sweet Shop.  As with any small town, there are places and traditions that are almost sacred -- this is one of them. 
Since 1955 the Sweet Shop has been a constant presence on River St. in the resort community of Elk Rapids, Michigan.  After 50 years as bakers, the current owners, Darlene & Dirk Renzema are looking forward to retirement and have the business up for sale.  Its valuable main street location has drawn interest from an assortment of developers -- all of whom see condos & high-end retail space as a more practical use.  That same prime location prices the property out of the reach of potential buyers focused on preserving this historic, community-supporting, award-winning, northern Michigan bakery - Best in Northern Michigan -- 11th best in the State
Anyone living in a tourist community understands the frustration as small, local businesses give way to speculators and chain stores.  Dirk & Darlene's hope is that the Sweet Shop can continue as a bakery, mirroring the hopes of the hundreds of customers who urged us to move forward with this campaign. Customers who left their fingerprints on these donut cases as children are now bringing their grandchildren to sample sweets created by Dirk, a 4th generation baker who began  his career in his grandparent's bakery in The Netherlands.  Without a sale, this will be the last season for the Sweet Shop.  Elk Rapids without the Sweet Shop is like...a donut without the hole.
The Second Piece-

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My Name is Sahra Maxwell. I am 17 years old and attend High School in Los Angeles, California. I am a junior making my way up to senior year. I will start the college applications  process this August, I am very excited to be moving on to the next stage in my life and moving on to adulthood. I am campaigning to attend New York University's precollege program, I have already been accepted however my family cannot afford to send me due to the high cost of the program. NYU is known as a very competitive school and I am very proud that I was chosen to attend their program. The NYU Precollege is a 6 week education intensive program a number of educational programs are offered during this 6 week session. NYU is honestly my dream school and attending this program will allow me to see if this school is really the school I would like to attend in my future. This program will allow me to take college courses which I can receive credit for, they offer 30 courses. This precollege will allow me to participate in the NYU community and will allow me to get to know the New York City and explore different course options. If I am able to attend NYU's precollege it will make me a better candidate for when I apply during the college process. Taking the competitive college courses will allow me to get ahead in my education, and will ensure that I am prepared from my future in education. It is a well-known fact that me taking a college course will show how serious I am about challenging myself.  These courses will give me an advanced look into college academics and allow meet to experience college life. This program will let me advance in certain subjects that I my High School does not offer.All the money will go to paying for the program and traveling to New York. This is my first time doing a fundraiser. After I was accepted into this program I saw the price of how much it cost and I felt defeated. Being able to be accepted into a program but not pay for was one of my saddest moments. I knew this program was competitive; for the application you had  to turn in your transcript and write an essay. It was very similar to a normal college application. After feeling bad that I could not afford it a friend of mine told me to start a fundraising account so I could raise the money. I am willing to do whatever it takes to go to my dream school, I know this 6 week program is a once in a lifetime opportunity  and I am determined to experience it.However, If I am unable to reach my goal I will save the money and put it in my college application fund. I am choosing to do this with the money because I want to put this money into education. The college application process is surprisingly expensive, so I believe this would be the best way to use the money if I am not able to reach my goal.I am a dedicated hard working young african-American women trying to make a future for myself. I believe that I can change the world. I want to use education to my advantage. Education is a way to succeed in life. I attend an all girls that has taught me to value my education and has taught me that I should always be willing to learn. When I get older I plan on putting a huge amount of effort into African American communities because I know where I came from and I know how precious education is.  I would appreciate if anyone could get the word out. I will accept anything. Thank you for taking the time to read this and I would appreciate any donations to fund my education!

story:
Who We Are

Mother Miracle, a multi-faceted NGO which serves the impoverished community of Shisham Jhari, wants to better serve 216 impoverished students in Rishikesh, India by rebuilding the school facilities which were flooded 3 years in a row and eventually destroyed beyond repair. The goal is to raise the grounds to over flood level and build a school for generations to come.

Since 2002, Mother Miracle has provided free-of-cost educational and vocational opportunities to under served children, women, and young adults. Our mission is to improve the quality of life for the entire community by providing individuals with the education, tools, and training they need to improve their own lives. By giving individuals in this community an opportunity to obtain a quality education, computer skills, job training, nutritional assistance, medical care, women’s rights education, sustainability, and environmental awareness, we hope to empower them and to assist them in creating a better future for the community as a whole.


Need & Impact

In Mother Miracle Primary and Junior High School, 216 students in pre-K through 6th grade receive a free-of-cost accelerated English medium education six days a week. These children, who live in one of the poorest communities in Rishikesh, are supplied with summer and winter uniforms, books, notebooks, pencils, pens, and art materials, and they study in one of the best school facilities in Rishikesh. Their dedicated teachers offer an advanced curriculum in all subjects in an attempt to give these very poor children a competitive edge when they are old enough to enter the job market or compete for college scholarships.

Our paid teachers and volunteers struggle every day to help these children, who are limited by their background of poverty and dead-ends, to grow into confident young men and women with the right skills and knowledge to pursue successful careers.

Since the building of school was destroyed by floods, the children have been relocated to temporary facilities. There is an urgent need to rebuild the school and move the students back to their home school.

This is a critical time to start the construction and raise the ground to above flood level before the next monsoon season. Once the ground is ready, the construction of the buildings can be done in phases. The total cost of building the school which includes 8 classes, toilets, kitchen, dining hall, library, storage room, and office, is estimated to be $232,000.  The construction cost for each classroom plus its share of public areas is approximately $29000. 


More Ways to Help

Not able to donate? No problem -- there are lots of other ways you can help us to meet our goals!

Spread the Word Share our campaign on Face book, Twitter, and other social media sites. Talk to your family, friends, and professional contacts about contributing. Every little bit goes a long way toward ensuring that our children grow up well-educated and ready to pursue successful careers.

Volunteer in India We always welcome volunteers who wish to join us on the ground in India and help us develop and run our programs. If you're already planning a visit to Rishikesh and would like to spend a few days helping out by teaching, doing extracurricular projects, or helping with administrative work, get in touch so that we can set up a meaningful volunteer experience for you. No matter what your skills and interests are, we have a place for you here!

story:
What is Bethel University?

Bethel University is a unique community pop-up (temporary) university in Bethel, Vermont. For one month each year, anyone can teach a course on just about any topic under the sun. And Bethel residents and neighbors from nearby towns can take courses for free.  Our goal is to share and showcase the many talents of Bethel residents, help local entrepreneurs spread the word about their skills and offerings, and bring more residents out into the community to meet, mingle, and explore the wealth of talent in our town.

Bethel University launched in March, 2014 for our inaugural semester.  It was an incredible success, with 18 courses and over 130 registrations!  The second semester of BU is already underway with registration open for 36 diverse courses and 7 new “meet-up groups” being offered this March.

Bethel is a town of about 2,000 residents spread over 45 square miles of hills and valleys in the Green Mountains of central Vermont.  Bethel University was created by the Bethel Revitalization Initiative (BRI).  We are residents and volunteers with a desire to help our small, rural community be as vibrant, fun, and inclusive as possible, even in the middle of snowy New England winters!  By funding our campaign, you will be supporting our initiative to keep classes free and therefore accessible to everyone in our community.  


What We Need

Let's break down what we need in a bit more detail.  Bethel University is truly a community effort.  Organizers and teachers offer their time, resources, and expertise.  Teachers, local businesses, and the town generously offer venue space and supplies when possible.  Keeping costs to a minimum is a top priority, and while our costs are few, there are some.  Primarily: 

  • Class supplies:  Occasionally funds are required for supplies to make a class possible and accessible to all students.  For example, arts and crafts supplies, guidebooks and pamphlets, or general printing needs.
  • Printing Costs:  We print posters to hang around our community, as well as postcards that can be handed/mailed out, listing our class offerings and how to sign up.  We also print diplomas of participation for our graduates, especially our younger ones.  These diplomas are designed by a young community volunteer!  

  • Advertising:  We run a spot in the local newspaper as well, noting the course offerings and how to find out more.  
We're looking to raise funds for this year and, hopefully, future years to come.  This will help supplement the amazing support we have already received from local businesses and the New England Grassroots Environment Fund.

What You Get
If you are a Bethel resident or a resident of a nearby town, regardless of whether you donate or not, you have the opportunity to:
  • Register for any of the diverse classes that are being offered this year,
  • Meet new friends and neighbors, and share in our great community,
  • Teach a class next year! If you're interested, start thinking about ideas now!
  • Attend our graduation social at the end of March.
Additionally, we have had interest from some other towns about replicating this idea, and we are happy to share what we've developed and learned.  Whether you are near or far, if you are interested in trying to make this model a reality in your community, feel free to reach out to us, via our website at betheluniversityvt.wordpress.com, with your questions.

The Impact

BU is about community.  Our teachers are all volunteers from our community who are generously offering their time to teach courses.  They have a genuine interest in what they are teaching and want to share their knowledge with anyone else who is interested in learning about a particular topic.  Without them, there is no BU.  

In our first year (2014), 21 “professors” offered BU courses ranging from Zumba to vermicomposting, quilt making to BBQ.  There were 134 registrations by residents of Bethel and 10 surrounding towns. 75% of participants say they learned new information and 95% of professors say they feel more connected to the community.

This year we have 36 courses plus 7 meet-up groups planned, and we hit 100 course registrations in just the first two days after registration opened!  The response has been amazing and we're all encouraged and motivated to continue bringing the simple idea to reality for the residents and neighbors of Bethel.

We want this to be accessible to anyone in our community, regardless of age or income.  One of the keys to being accessible and inclusive is to remove any barriers that would prevent someone from signing up.  For this reason, we feel that classes at BU must be free for anyone to join.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, we understand, but that doesn't mean you can't still help out!  There are many ways you can pitch in, particularly if you are a Bethel, VT resident or neighbor:

  • Share this effort online and offline, with friends, family, and groups you participate in.  Help us get the word out about Bethel University! Feel free to share our website as well as some great press we've received too!
    • Bethel University VT
    • We're on VPR!
    • WCAX
  • Consider volunteering to teach a class with us next year.  Everyone has something to share!  No college or teaching degrees necessary.  Join our mailing list!
  • Volunteer to help organize BU and participate in our planning sessions.  Join our mailing list to receive BU news and updates.
  • Find out more at our website:  Bethel University VT!
