Knowing that he was capable of more, we enrolled him in the only program in the state of Arkansas designed to give people with intellectual disabilities a college like experience.  That program was a geographic challenge being 5 ½ hours, by car, from our home.  Virtually at the same time, I ran for a seat in the Arkansas House of Representatives, a significant part of my platform based on advocating for individuals with intellectual disabilities. Due to the desire to provide more post high school options to students with intellectual disabilities, my partner, Janet Ragland, former general counsel  for  the Arkansas Department of Higher Education and mother of an intellectually disabled daughter, and I began drafting legislation to create Building Better Futures, which designs and implements fully integrated, but modified, certificated programs in institutions higher education for intellectually disabled students.  This legislation was passed, almost unanimously, by the Arkansas General Assembly in the 2015 Legislative Session as Acts 410 and 931.




What makes Building Better Futures Different Though there are some programs in the country that provide intellectually disabled individuals a  "college like" experience, there are very few that provide specialized, marketable, transferable employment skills such as culinary/hospitality, daycare, certified nursing assistant or coding in an integrated setting.  Institutions of higher education have not typically been equipped to serve this population, because these individuals often need greater support then their typical peers.  Thus, there has been a hesitance in higher education venues to establish such programs due to the expense.  This campaign is designed to build a fund-raising platform so that the seed-money can be raised to provide the necessary tools for institutions of higher education to create and implement the above described programs.  These programs fill a tremendous void by integrating intellectually disabled individuals  first, into the higher education environment and then, into mainstream society through competitive employment, thereby providing quality, dignity and a sense of contribution to them.

(Broadaway Family)  Building Better Futures is a WIN/ WIN


Integrated programs have proven to be as beneficial to typically developing individuals as to their intellectually disabled counterparts. The typically developing peers recognize the value, abilities and contributions that their intellectually disabled peers have and this creates the essential culture change necessary to the development of society. Due to the ever increasing number of individuals on the Autism Spectrum and developments in medical technology, there is a growing segment of our society that live with the challenges of intellectual disabilities and learning differences.  We must acknowledge these differences as a society and help these individuals find their place, provide them choice and opportunity, and enable them to contribute. 




   HELP US GET STARTED Building Better Futures is a licensed internet portal which allows access to a "Turn-key" Model Tool kit to allow Institutions of Higher Education to create and implement their own unique programs.  This tool kit starts with designing   the program  and continues all the way through placing graduates in jobs related to their field of study. We anticipate it will cost close to a million dollars to create our tool kit, but we need the seed money necessary to allow us to conduct an intelligent, thorough fundraising campaign.   We are seeking to raise $25,000.00 to assess interest in what we are doing and for the following purposes: 


$5,000.00 for grant writing/research 


$5,000.00 for creation of a website

$5000.00 for professional fees

$2,500.00 for public relations and marketing

$2,500.00 for technical and consulting expenses regarding expense of creation and valuation of product

$2000.00 for rental of dedicated office/meeting space

$2000.00 for branding, design, and print materials

$1000.00 for registration fees
  Other Ways You Can Help 
For parents and family members of a future student, send us your interest and comments.  We want to hear from you. Tell us your story and let us know how to contact you so we can follow up with you.For educators and Higher Ed organizations.  If you want to be a pioneer location that helps us get a program started, we want to hear from you.  Maybe you have a culinary program or work study program or you've been contemplating one of these, contact us.  Let's work together and build a better future for our communities.For donors and sponsors.  We need your support.  Your assistance can be through funding, but also through donating a building, endowing a faculty members annual salary, providing operational tools, providing operating capital, providing your expertise, providing student scholarships, or other means that will help us build a better future for our communities.  We need to hear from you.For business and future employers, we would love to partner with you.  We need your financial support, but we also we want to know about the communities in which you are located and your employment needs.  We want to help you enhance your business and build a better future for your community.Finally if you want to participate in some way or just want to encourage us to continue.  We want to hear from you too.  We know we are on track to good things and knowing that you are behind us will keep us moving forward.

story:
Wateachu™ is a digital tool for working with non-digital exercises in the classroom

Today's schools are the most modern and high-tech schools we have ever seen. Despite this, student achievements leaves a lot to be desired, especially in mathematics. 

Different companies have come up with different products to improve education and some even offer digital workbooks with automatic correction of exercises. These can all be good and useful products but many schools don't have the resources, like one computer per student in the classroom, to fully implement such solutions.

With Wateachu we try to create a bridge between the digital and the non-digital. You and your students can continue working with the printed workbooks you already have without having to replace them with expensive software. At the same time we add a digital component with the Wateachu web app to enhance the way you already work. Wateachu is coded responsively, meaning that it will work well on both computers, tablets and smart phones. If your school can't afford a 1:1 device distrubution in the classroom but your students have their own smartphones with Internet access, then you're good to go!

What does Wateachu do?

There are some things Wateachu doesn't do and there are some things it does.

First, Wateachu doesn't contain exercises, it just refers to exercises by listing the different task numbers that are to be done, just like an ordinary plan on paper. However, being digital enables Wateachu to do things that a paper plan cannot. Here is what we try to do:

Motivate students by visualizing progress

Wateachu presents the list of exercises students are assigned to do as a chain of coloured circles, making the workload very visual and very concrete for the student. This is something that our student test users have given us positive feedback on and it looks like this: 

Perhaps more importantly this visual layout also enables us to make it very clear to students whenever they have achieved or finished something. And that is motivating. Black circles are tasks to be done, once checked off as finished they turn green. It is almost like a game and both students and grown-ups know that checking off your to-do-lists feels good! 

In addition to all this, at the top of the screen we have included a statistics field where the student can see how many tasks have been completed, how many remains, how many percentages of the work plan is completed, how many times the student has asked for help and how many times the student has given help. Again to visualize progress and process with the aim of motivating the student.


Give teachers better insight into how their students are doing by digitally logging non-digital student activity

While students will hopefully get motivated by their user interface we hope teachers will gain a better understanding of their class by using their special teachers' interface.

This overview gives detailed information about how your students are working. Who have finished the most exercises? Who have needed help? What exercises are they working at right now? This is information that you can get almost at a glance. And if you hover your mouse marker above the symbols you will even get more information. Such as how long time has been spent on a specific exercise or who helped who with the exercise!

This is valuable information for you as a teacher. Not as a replacement for interacting with your students, but as a help in being efficient and precise in your interactions. If, for example, you discover that John in the screenshot above is working on exercise no. 3 while everyone else is at no. 14 it would be wise to walk over to John first to check if he is doing ok, before walking over to all the other students that may perhaps be more active and outgoing in seeking your help. In this way Wateachu may help to level the playing field for all those students out there that may perhaps not be as extrovert as their peers.

(If on the other hand you see that John is 14 exercises in front of everyone else it would be wise to pay him a visit and see it he is cheating with what exercises he is checking off in Wateachu. Since Wateachu is a hybrid digital-non-digital system, students are able of cheating if they want to. However, we believe that an alert teacher and the system's built-in self-discipline will help keep your students on track. More on that later.)

Logging student activity and presenting it for teacher analysis is nothing new. However very few products offer this for non-digital student activity. With Wateachu you can use digital technology to enhance the way you and your students work non-digitally. We believe in advancing education by the use of technology. But we also believe in the unique abilities of human beings to interact and help each other face to face. With Wateachu we try to bring together the best of both worlds.


Create an ecosystem of students turned teaching assistants where "all for one, one for all" is the team motto

With Wateachu we want to create an improved social enviroment in the classroom. More than that, we want to change the way students look at their own performance and that of their peers and hopefully make this result in more and better learning.

In some classes, and even in some classes with a good social milieu, students see themselves and their performances as very seperate from that of their fellow students. This may perhaps be especially the case with mathematics where some students seem to always struggle while others seem to always excel. This is a challenge to the teacher since some students could need all the time available for getting help while at the same time others need more challenges. And all this often happens in a class of 20-30 students and often no more than one teacher.

With Wateachu we try to activate the resources of strong students to help the weaker students so that the class as a whole can benefit. On each task to be completed the student has the choice to either check it off as finished or to press an "ask for help"-button. Asking for help will cause Wateachu's algorithms to find a fellow student who has previously completed the same task, and send a message to this student to come over and provide help face to face.**

By making students teaching assistants in this way we believe that Wateachu has the potential to contribute to a number of positive changes in your classroom:

  • Strong students are challenged by having to help teach weaker students. This is something that all parties will most likely learn quite a bit from, both when it comes to getting a deeper understanding of the subject but also when it comes to training valuable cooperation skills.

  • Intermediate students can help weaker students and even weak students can help other students who have not gotten as far as themselves. Since exercises can belong to various difficulty levels and students work at different paces and also receive differing numbers of exercises according to differentiated work plans, a weak student may finish off an exercise before an intermediate student. Thus making it possible for weaker students to even help stronger students.


  • Since many students are receiving adequate help from fellow students, the teacher can get (a lot) more time to help those students that really need a teacher to help them.

  • Chances are that mocking someone in the break is a bit harder if that someone just helped you complete your math task in the past lesson five minutes ago. In this way we hope that Wateachu will contribute to a greater sense of team spirit and a better social environment in your class in addition to helping with learning subjects.

What is the history of Wateachu?

Wateachu was created by Kristoffer Løset Øpstad, a Norwegian professional teacher and the founder of Creation Creates AS™, the company behind Wateachu. After having taught mathematics at different schools and using different methodologies over the last years, he felt that the time students spent solving exercises were not used as efficiently as it ought to be. 

When using a traditional "teacher in front" approach, the students spent much of the time listening to the teacher and looking at the blackboard. The remaining time was spent doing exercises, but often there was too little time and too many students to help for one teacher to handle.

When using a "flipped classroom" approach, the students spent their time at home watching videos explaining theory and most of the time in class was spent doing exercises. This gave the teacher more time to help individual students but still time could be scarce and often students found the time sitting solving exercises monotonous and not very motivating, again impairing efficiency and learning. 


To improve the situation Løset Øpstad teamed up with three* computer engineers to create Wateachu, a digital tool for non-digital work. Originally the main goal was to make students interact more and help each other with tasks and exercises when needed, with the purpose of creating more learning and a more cooperative class culture. 

After having several teachers test an early prototype in their respective high schools and after also having tested it in his own class at a junior high school, feedback suggested that the teachers really liked having a logging feature and that the students really liked the visual overview of the exercises and the ability to check them off and see their own progress.

As a result of this Wateachu has evolved into its current beta release where we try to motivate students, give teachers more insight in their classes, and help students help each other out, facilitating cooperation skills, team spirit and learning by both giving and receiving help.

What's in it for me?

Wateachu was created by a professional teacher, not mainly to create a lot of money but to create a lot of learning and positive social change. This means that although we plan on offering Wateachu for a fee when we are ready to launch commercially at a later stage, we desire to keep the price reasonably low so that most schools, teachers and students can try it out and hopefully reap positive benefits from it.

We want you and your students to be able to test it out and see for yourself what you think about Wateachu. Our featured perk comes at only $ 35 USD and gives you a teacher-level access to the application for the remainer of the calendar year of 2016! For $ 35 you and all of your students can test out Wateachu and hopefully see positive and encouraging benefits from it. 


Also, whatever amount you chose to contribute to the product, and regardless of whether you are a teacher or not, you can be confident that by supporting Wateachu you are supporting a social entrepreneurial company that have their eyes more on serving people  than just earning money. 

Where will my money go if I support Wateachu?

To create Wateachu we have had to ask private investors for help and we would like to give them back what they have initially given us. This is a "boring" thing to ask for support for, but being able to give back these funds will give us the freedom we need to go on developing Wateachu without having to wait for income from Wateachu license fees, etc.. For this reason we need approx. $ 25,000 USD.

Secondly, to be able to give support to you and other test users throughout the remainder of year 2016, and at the same time to be able to develop Wateachu further both in terms of marketing the product so that more people can try it out, but also in terms of adding new features and improving existing features, we need approx. $ 30,000 USD.***

If we get enough support we would like to consider adding the following features, among others:

  • Support for more languages and countries. 

  • Native apps for iPhone, Android phones and Windows phones. This will enable us to message student helpers by the use of sound and vibration in addition to the visual signalling we are currently using. If will also enable the students' devices' screens to stay awake automatically, along with other features we have not currently been able of implementing.

  • A new work plan creation feature making it possible to mass import exercises from existing work plans in Word and other text documents.

  • The possibility to export results to Excel, PDF, etc.

  • The possibility to automatically deliver reports to parents of student progress, for example by e-mail once a week or once a plan has expired.

  • Integration with learning management platforms.

Wateachu already has some great features but with your support we can make it even greater. We want the most schools, teachers and students to benefit from Wateachu and we need your help to make this happen.

Want to contribute but don't have the money for it?

Any support helps and we would love it if you would like, share and follow us on social media. Check out or channels below our logo.

Think Wateachu sounds like a great idea and also think you have some skills we could use, like computer programming, designing, teaching, marketing, etc.? Let us know!

We thank you for your support!

The Wateachu team

Our Social Media channels:

Home page: https://wateachu.com/
Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/wateachu.international/
Twitter profile: https://twitter.com/wateachu_int


*Originally Wateachu was developed together with a team of three computer engineers. As the beta version was nearing completion and our funds were nearing depletion we chose to continue with one computer engineer. With your support we hope to create a sustainable business and grow both our team and a positive impact on education and society.

**Since the Wateachu teaching experience is part digital, part non-digital, there is a possibility that some students will try to cheat. Running random surprise checks on your students workbooks to see if they correspond with your teacher overview in Wateachu should help prevent this. In addition students should know that checking an exercise off as done automatically makes them eligible for Wateachu's algorithms which finds students that can help other students. Being asked by Wateachu to help someone with something the student really didn't do can become both a revealing and an unpleasant experience. We call this "the built-in self-discipline system" of Wateachu.


***Since we are a Norwegian-based and not US-based company, a portion of your contributions will go to Indiegogo-/Stripe-/PayPal-fees along with fees related to currency conversion and similar actions. For more information about this, read Indiegogo's article about the matter here. The costs of these fees are hard to calculate as they depend on a number of variables, like how many people will contribute to the campaign, what payment method they will use, what currencies they contribute with, etc.

story:
About Us

My name is Kielah Harbert, a first generation college sophomore at Washington University in St. Louis. I am Wilglory Tanjong, a first generation college sophomore at Princeton University. Together, we are the authors of the book, #ADMITTED.




We wrote #ADMITTED for every student who has ever dreamed of thriving in life by becoming successful. The student that wants to provide for their family by doing what they love for a living. This book is for every student who wants to live their best life. Each student who has dreams of going to college and is willing to do whatever it takes to succeed. We want to do our part to help students reach higher. Your support will help students just like us, to successfully navigate the process.


The Need & How You Can Help

  • It is our goal to raise $20,000. This will help us get #Admitted into the hands of the first 1,000 high school students who need this information.
  • We’re offering many ways in which you can invest in this project. Have a look and thanks in advance for taking part!


The Impact: College Access For All Students

For some first generation, low income or under-resourced students, the simple act of daring to dream and setting a goal to go to college is revolutionary. All too often, student's families do not have access to resources they need to make sure their children are properly prepared for high school and the college application process. Sometimes even if they are prepared, they may not have the money, time at their disposal to make sure their child can succeed in the way he or she could if the odds were in their favor. This guide serves as an important tool bridge the gap to success. All of the important steps a student needs to take, myths they can overcome, habits they need to develop, and relationships they need to foster are all included in #ADMITTED.

"Let us think of education as the means of developing our greatest abilities, because in each of us there is a private hope and dream which, fulfilled, can be translated into benefit for everyone and greater strength for our nation." 

- John F. Kennedy

When Will You Receive your Book(s)?

The planned release date for the book is March 2016. As an Indiegogo contributor, your books will ship first. 

Note: Sponsor level provides books for students in need. Books will not be shipped to you directly. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand some that people are unable to contribute. Here are a few other opportunities to help!

  • If you want to help more students continue their education, please help us spread the word and make some noise about our campaign!
  • You can send out emails to your contacts, tweet, make a Facebook post, make a phone call for us, or do all of them!
  • Please also use to use the Indiegogo share tools.
  • If you want to contact us directly with ideas or referrals. We want to hear from you! Email us at nhopson@ever-appropriate.com

Simple! Right?  We thank you in advance!
story_txt:
About UsMy name is Kielah Harbert, a first generation college sophomore at Washington University in St. Louis. I am Wilglory Tanjong, a first generation college sophomore at Princeton University. Together, we are the authors of the book, #ADMITTED.





We wrote #ADMITTED for every student who has ever dreamed of thriving in life by becoming successful. The student that wants to provide for their family by doing what they love for a living. This book is for every student who wants to live their best life. Each student who has dreams of going to college and is willing to do whatever it takes to succeed. We want to do our part to help students reach higher. Your support will help students just like us, to successfully navigate the process.   

The Need & How You Can Help
  It is our goal to raise $20,000. This will help us get #Admitted into the hands of the first 1,000 high school students who need this information.


We’re offering many ways in which you can invest in this project. Have a look and thanks in advance for taking part! 
   

The Impact: College Access For All Students For some first generation, low income or under-resourced students, the simple act of daring to dream and setting a goal to go to college is revolutionary. All too often, student's families do not have access to resources they need to make sure their children are properly prepared for high school and the college application process. Sometimes even if they are prepared, they may not have the money, time at their disposal to make sure their child can succeed in the way he or she could if the odds were in their favor. This guide serves as an important tool bridge the gap to success. All of the important steps a student needs to take, myths they can overcome, habits they need to develop, and relationships they need to foster are all included in #ADMITTED.
"Let us think of education as the means of developing our greatest abilities, because in each of us there is a private hope and dream which, fulfilled, can be translated into benefit for everyone and greater strength for our nation." 
- John F. Kennedy
    
When Will You Receive your Book(s)?
The planned release date for the book is March 2016. As an Indiegogo contributor, your books will ship first. 
Note: Sponsor level provides books for students in need. Books will not be shipped to you directly.    Other Ways You Can Help We understand some that people are unable to contribute. Here are a few other opportunities to help!  If you want to help more students continue their education, please help us spread the word and make some noise about our campaign! You can send out emails to your contacts, tweet, make a Facebook post, make a phone call for us, or do all of them!
Please also use to use the Indiegogo share tools.
If you want to contact us directly with ideas or referrals. We want to hear from you! Email us at nhopson@ever-appropriate.com   Simple! Right?  We thank you in advance!

story:
Early Bird.....Best wishes for a Joyous Holiday Season

One month's results: 30 children learned to communicate with basic sentences. 2 schools + one more school providing free space for a learning center. Syllabus, text book and 2 teachers recruited and trained. Hand worn device development progressing.

Sharon Systems ( https://youtu.be/TuIU_mEvRVo ) have been working on this system for four years now and have successfully launched and tested it in a School in Chennai, India. 

Rhema - Speech to Tactile System for the Hearing Impaired consists of :

  • A tactile device mounted on desk top to train learners on the linguistic patterns to recognize speech in any language.
  • A 3 month course with text book and speech modulation software to provide speech therapy.
  • A portable device wrist worn and a smart phone to replicate the class room system for day to day use and near normal conversation.
  • Online Training for distance learners in any language
  • Learning Center courtesy CSI Hr. Sec. School for the hearing Impaired, Chennai, India. to train teachers.
  • App modules for specialized environments such as higher learning classes in maths, physics, chemistry etc
  • Economically priced open source system to help the disabled world wide.

Your Generosity Counts! Support us through Indiegogo crowdfunding.

Two months training at the 150 year old CSI Hr Sec School for the Deaf, Santhome, Chennai 600004 has enabled us to see it work for 30 students of all ages and classes with just 15 minute duration training each day for an individual.  The school is so impressed that they have provided us with a 1000sq.ft space free of cost to establish a learning/training center at their premises to continue with our efforts for all children in their school.

Your contribution through the funds we raise in this effort will help us to furnish and equip the space that has been provided, and also set up tactile class rooms in two other schools who have commissioned us to start teaching their children, complete the design of the hand worn mobile unit and distribute free samples to 100 pupils and complete the process of development, training and ready to distribute world wide this system.

    Rhema is phonetics based system and can be easily adapted to any language by developing a language corpus for that particular language. 

    Our Need and Offer

    We require $200,000 to establish a fully equipped Development, Training and 2 Tactile class rooms in three schools. We need to train more than 600 students of all ages and classes in Tamil to identify words spoken to them and answer appropriately in normal speech.  The technology, hardware and software are ready and tested and proven.

    We will also spend money to finalize design of the mobile device that could fit in the wrist and work similar to the desk mounted version.  We will produce 100 sample units and distribute it free of cost to children and evaluate the system before taking it to others.  We have invested our own funds and time to design, develop, and test this system until now.  As it has been proven we need the additional funds to move on so that it will provide relief to every one with this disability world over.  For this reason we intend to publish this as an Open Source Application.

    Donors who donate $100 will be provided with a free unit in 6 - 9 months which can be used for one of their own or sponsored candidate.  We will provide online training for free with the system.  Those who want to be long terms partners in this system can obtain common shares in  Rhema on par value when issued by contributing $1000.

    If we receive less than 50% percent of the amount requested we will establish the classes and equip the training center with the funds.

    If we receive more than 50% we will complete the above and go ahead with product development.

    The balance will be used to distribute samples free of cost.

      The Impact

      WHO has determined that there are 300 million people are affected with this disability world wide. The objective of us delving into this project is to provide a constructive and cognitive relief to those who are affected. The relief should also be consistent, affordable and reliable. Given the numerous linguistic and dialect differences, a system that would easily subscribe to any chosen language or dialect was considered vital.

      Rhema offers all and has more room to improve with one going product development.  It has been tested and proved and schools are requesting us from near and far to bring it to their locations. 

      Your contribution would not only change lives of hitherto left out compatriots, it can help on one your own or known persons through our offer for a free device for every $100 dollar donation and free training.

      Risks & Challenges

      We have overcome enormous challenges in developing the hardware that would precisely react to the audio and create the appropriate pattern for the person to understand.  There is no risk for the user as the device uses low voltage and small push force (>5gm)  They will never be exposed to electric or magnetic force injury.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      “Four things come not back. The spoken word, the sped arrow, the past life, and the neglected opportunity” – Arabic Proverb.

      Here is an opportunity for us to make life better for 360 million of our fellow humans.

      Other Ways You Can Help “If your real desire is to be good, there is no need to wait for the money before you do it; you can do it now, this very moment, and just where you are. And that’s all there is to it”. – James Allen
      Making people aware, connecting us with Institutions for the Hearing Disabled, Teachers who specialize in teaching them, persons with the disability will be very helpful.

story:
Why a nature based programme for teenage girls?

Adolescence is an exciting stage of development for girls – full of new possibilities, great promises and potential. It’s a time for exploring and gaining an understanding of who we really are and who we want to be - a kind of stepping stone, from childhood to young adulthood.

As exciting as this transition can be, many girls experience it as a time of uneasy disconnection – from their childhood self, from their own transforming body and from others. And there's increasing evidence that in our current environment – with so much pressure to perform and conform coming from school, the media and online social platforms – it can be a time of anxiety and insecurity.

We have seen the enormous benefits that come from giving teenage girls some time out together in nature - away from all of those pressures. Time to have fun, learn new skills, renew their self-confidence and share experiences in a space where they feel supported by each other and by older female mentors.

What We Need 

The cost per person for this program is £950.

We very much would like to be able to offer bursary places to enable those on lower incomes a chance to take part. This campaign seeks funds to make this possible.

We're hoping to have a bursary fund of £2000, to be awarded on application by those who can not afford to pay the full price. Any funds raised will be used for bursaries.

Please give some money towards making this program more accessible and help young women to step forward in life on steady, supported ground.

The Impact

Wild Time returns for 2016 - after an incredible first year. 

After an amazing adventure with six girls and some inspiring feedback - we are launching again for this year!

"A fantastic experience that makes these young women proud to be them – happy in their bodies and minds."

WildTime parent 2015

“It is so personal, special and in the moment. I would say that it was the best experience of my life. You make amazing friends and you learn so much about so many different things. It brings all these different parts of you - the whole thing. Makes you realise parts of yourself you didn't know before."

WildTime participant 2015

Thank you:

Check back here soon, we'll be adding more interesting perks!

We've got some exciting perks to give in return, including a glamping holiday stay in a yurt, bushcraft sessions, discounts on WIldWise courses, woodland jewellery and some unique nature-inspired poetry and photos of WildTime!! 

Please spread the word:

We realise that not everyone can give money. Perhaps you could help by spreading the word on this exciting new program by circulating information between your friends, family and networks. 

Please consider sending this appeal to 5-10 friends. That would be a massive help! 

Also, please "like" and share our facebook page , follow us on Twitter and use the Indiegogo share tools.


Many thanks from Israh, Chloe and Emily

Facebook: www.facebook.com/wildtimeforgirls

Website: www.wildwise.co.uk

Twitter: https://twitter.com/WildWiseDevon

story:
We at Tahltan Language Conservation Initiative Project  believe that every child should have access to literature in their Native language - literature that stimulate their imagination and open their minds to new possibilities.


Tahltan Language Conservation Initiative Project

Tahltan Language Conservation Initiative Project (Hereon TLCIP) is a grassroots conservation effort that will focus on the preservation of the severely endangered Tahltan language. There are only 17 fluent native Tahltan speakers alive today and all but two are over the age of seventy. The project will work with the remaining speakers in an effort to digitally archive the language in both audio and printed formats and in the process develop an online and hard-copy complete dictionary in the Tahltan Language.

The Tahltan language is at risk of extinction within the next few years unless vigorous preservation measures are taken. We have the local technical capacity to save our dying language, all that's needed is your financial contribution - your contribution will keep our language from disappearing from the face of humanity.


How Will Your Money Be Used

The Tahltan Language Conservation Initiative Project is seeking to raise $100,000 to work on the preservation of the Tahltan Language over a 2 year period. The net proceeds from this campaign will enable us to launch a successful pilot project in the Tahltan Communities and allow us to archive the language and develop literature resources in the Tahltan Language.

The project will purchase digital recording devices, computers, cameras, digital tablets and miscellaneous items (External drives, discs etc.), but the majority of the funds would go towards:

  • fieldwork and technical support (digital recordings)
  • archiving the language (audio and printed versions)
  • digital resources (literature/dictionary) development.

The project will consist of three phases:

First Phase: will continue recording the last remaining native speakers of the Tahltan language and archive the digital data.

Second Phase: will develop and publish an online and hard-copy dictionary in Tahltan and English that would be available to anyone interested in studying the language. (We will archive our language in print and digital formats).

Third Phases: will make available through retail the hard-copy dictionary and all proceeds will go back to the development of resource material in the Tahltan Language.

The first and second phase will overlap and the development of a hard-copy and digital dictionary will commence as soon as the funds are raised to begin the field and technical work. The dictionary will be a major part of the conservation or archiving process and the dictionary layout design can be used as a template for other endangered Dene Languages.


The Impact

Language is an essential component in the development of an individuals identity and ethnicity, but many Tahltan Children do not have access to the Tahltan language or material that inspires a lifelong opportunity to learn to speak Tahltan. The first 11 years of a child’s life are the most important for language development, but there are no language literature resources available for the children apart from the recently published interactive digital eBook; Talkin' Tahltan: The Pedagogical Structure Of The Tāłtān Dene Language (Oscar Dennis 2015). The only other material available is an incomplete very limited unpublished children’s Illustrated Dictionary, developed in 1991, that is very difficult for the average family (especially in urban areas) to obtain. TLCIP will use modern technology to preserve the language and in the process develop a digital interactive resource(s) that would enable the Tahltan people to attain the most essential of life experiences – the magic and blessing of speaking their Indigenous language.


Why Support The Concept

Our resident local First Nations tech team, i.e., researchers and resource developers, speak the language and have deep experience in qualitative research methodologies and digital resource development, as well as close relationships with two of the last high-level speakers of the Tahltan language in the Iskut community. Our tech team also has extensive experience in the language revitalization, interactive eBook development and the online publishing realm. We have the human resource capacity to save the Tahltan language all that’s needed are the funds to make this a reality.


Our Research & Resource Development Team

    Oscar James Dennis Sr

Team Leader Oscar Dennis Sr has a Masters Degree in First Nations Studies and a BA In Anthropology. Oscar has been working on the conservation of the Tahltan Language For over 5 Years. As a result he is one of the few who has learned to speak the language as a second language. Along with father James Dennis, Oscar Dennis has published a book on the Pedagogical Structure of the Tahltan Language. Oscar has advanced language and computer technical research skills that he will be bringing to the project. Oscar also has direct access to a fluent high-level Tahltan native speaker in his home 24/7.


    Robert Leon Dennis

Team member Robert Dennis is the youngest fluent native Tahltan language speaker left in the Tahltan Nation. Robert was the last to learn to speak Tahltan as a child. Robert will bring his expertise of the language and his computer skills to the project. Robert has been studying the Korean Language for over 3 years and has developed some mad language skills. Robert also has direct access to a high-level native Tahltan speaker in his home 24/7.


    James William Dennis

James Dennis is the 81 Year old Elder on the Team. James grew-up on Tahltan land as a nomadic hunter and spoke Tahltan as a child. Although he learned English as a child he only spoke English when it was required of him. James will be bringing his extensive knowledge of the Tahltan language to the project. James is the eldest living male Wolf Clan-member alive today in the Tahltan Nation and he speaks the language fluently.


What Have We Done So Far?

The interactive eBook, Talkin' Tahltan was written over a 4 yr period in which team leader Oscar Dennis Sr studied the Tahltan Language in the Tahltan community of Iskut with his father James Dennis - James is one of the last fluent native speakers left in the Tahltan Nation. The interactive eBook, 'Talkin' Tahltan' can be viewed on iTunes: https://itunes.apple.com/ca/book/talkin-tahltan...

We have an interactive website dedicated to teaching the Tahltan Language: http://didenekeh.com

We have a Facebook Page dedicated to teaching the language through social media: https://www.facebook.com/groups/348038428639638/


Risks & Challenges

The greatest challenge to the conservation of the endangered Tahltan Language is the continuous direct access to the high level fluent native speakers in the Tahltan communities. However, the team is made up of two fluent native speakers and a second language speaker. Also, two of the team-members have direct-access (24/7) to elderly parents who learned the language as children. There is no challenge that we cannot over come. The only challenge we face is financial - we need financial support to make this conservation initiative project a reality. Your contribution will help us over-come the challenge of our dying language.

So please donate what you can $5, $10, $50, $100, $500, $1000, $10,000, $20,000 or more.

Our language is worth saving!


What Is The Legacy

The dictionary will make the language readily available to the children on mobile devices that can be accessed in the classroom, at home and in the field.

The written and digital audio data will be digitally archived and readily available for use in other creative ways to develop reading resources that will be suitable for children of all ages.

Once we get this project off the ground we can apply the knowledge gained (model) to other endangered Dene languages (Kaska and Tagish etc.,).


Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Those of you who can not contribute financially you can help by getting the word out and make some noise about our campaign to save our endangered language. SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN

However, the team is made up of two fluent native speakers and a second language speaker. Also, two of the team-members have direct-access (24/7) to elderly parents who learned the language as children. There is no challenge that we cannot over come. The only challenge we face is financial - we need financial support to make this conservation initiative project a reality. Your contribution will help us over-come the challenge of our dying language.
So please donate what you can $5, $10, $50, $100, $500, $1000, $10,000, $20,000 or more.
Our language is worth saving!


What Is The Legacy



The
dictionary will make the language readily available to the children on mobile
devices that can be accessed in the classroom, at home and in the field.
The written
and digital audio data will be digitally archived and readily available for
use in other creative ways to develop reading resources that will be suitable
for children of all ages.
Once we
get this project off the ground we can apply the knowledge gained (model) to other
endangered Dene languages (Kaska and Tagish etc.,).

  Other Ways You Can Help Some of you just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help:  Those of you who can not contribute financially you can help by getting the word out and make some noise about our campaign to save our endangered language. SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN

story:
Synopsis

Are you raising a little skeptic?  Maybe your family are the only non-believers on the block? Experiencing difficulty locating reading material for your young atheist? Want to teach your kids about religion from a secular perspective? Or give them a head start on science?

If you answered YES to any of these questions, then this is the campaign to support!

My name is Bryce and I live in a small town tucked away in the Sierra Nevada Mountains of California.  My degrees are in Cellular/Molecular Biology and Education. In early November 2015, I had an epiphany to write educational books and create an ambassador for children of atheist/agnostic parents. Since then, I have been busy outlining and writing the first book and locating talented illustrators.

The working title for the first book is titled "Who is God?". The story covers a broad range of topics, from the Origins of the Abrahamic God to The Big Bang. 

Doctor Dude is the central figure, a professor-like character and conceptual expert. He is a mellow and amusing fellow with a well-rounded educated background. Dawnie is Doctor Dude’s dog and sidekick, complementing Doctor Dude’s personality. 

Book Objectives

  • Alleviate the fear young freethinkers may experience coming out of the proverbial closet.

  • Supply tools for young non-believers so they are comfortable among their theist and deist peers.

  • Provide the fundamentals of the scientific theories critical in understanding our world. 

  • Plant the seeds of skepticism and critical thinking skills.

What We Need & What You Get

Budget

To fund the project successfully, we are soliciting donations for a total of $12000. 

  • $4000 - Author's Expenses
  • $4000 - Illustrator's Expenses
  • $2000 - Self-Publishing Costs. Includes Softcover and eBook Formats
  • $2000 - Marketing and Promotion Costs
You may wonder, why does it cost so much to publish a book?  If you are not an already established author with an agent and successful track record, you would be surprised how difficult and expensive endeavor it is. This is especially true for a picture book with color illustrations.  

Contribution funds will also be used for the development of a website and smartphone/tablet application. 

Perks

  • Everyone - Personal "Thank You" note from the author. 
  • $20 - Doctor Dude Coffee Mug or Pint Glass
  • $25 - Digital / Kindle Version of First Edition
  • $50 - Softcover Copy of First Edition
  • $100 - Signed Softcover Copy of First Edition
  • $500 - Author to travel to your local bookstore and sign copies (US Only)

The Market

Atheism and Agnosticism are the fastest growing demographic blocks in the US. According to the Pew Research survey results (Published in May 2015), the percentage of those self-identified with Atheism has almost doubled, from 1.6% in 2007 to 3.1% in 2014.  Similarly, those self-identified as Agnostics have increased from 2.4% to 4.0% in the same time span. In large part, millennials (born 1981 to 1996) are propelling the transformation of the religious landscape. To read more, visit http://www.pewforum.org/2015/05/12/americas-changing-religious-landscape/

With this dramatic shift in religious affiliation, atheist/agnostic parents will be in need of teaching material for their children, with a focus on discussing religion from a secular perspective.  Doctor Dude fits the bill perfectly.  Aimed at elementary and junior high school students, the objective of Doctor Dude series will introduce the subject matter in a light-hearted and fun, but in an upfront manner. Answering basic questions children may have regarding monotheistic faiths and scientific theories, those questions parents may not know the exact words to use. 

Other than their parents, young atheists and agnostics are missing an ambassador or hero-figure. Doctor Dude would fill a void, a role model for preteen non-believers to ask questions regarding religion and science, and stimulate critical thinking in young readers’ minds.  

Based on my research of books in the same genre, the Doctor Dude series will be distinct in its approach. The semantics used in Doctor Dude are fun and creates an atmosphere for the reader to contemplate. Still in the development stage, the illustrations are planned to be compelling and beautifully artistic, providing an additional unique trait for the books. 

Challenges

My primary concern is marketing and creating a buzz for the release of the first book. Major obstacles, such as finding talented illustrators and signing with a small publishing company are already resolved. To minimize the marketing hurdle, the publishing company offers promotional services which I will be taking full advantage of. 

Other Ways You Can Help

For those who do not have the economic means to contribute to this campaign, please spread the word out and create noise! Tell your friends and family, share with your fellow freethinkers and skeptics. Please use the convenient Indiegogo share tools.

story:
We're moving our glass studio...

After two successful years of classes, consulting, and custom fabrication, we’ve found a great new location where we can focus on larger scale fabrication projects. We're excited to expand our offerings to include cold working (cutting, grinding, and polishing glass) and hot glass (ladle casting, blow molds, and glass blowing), as well as new equipment for creating architectural components and printmaking.

Your support will help us put in important new infrastructure – a casting furnace, kiln controller, and portable press – and make our studio transition happen more efficiently! 

 

 

....And creating the "IV fab lab"!

Our goal as teachers and collaborators is to help find the most compelling form for an idea – ​whether it’s our own, our students, or our clients.  Expanding our repertoire of equipment will literally give us the tools to make that happen; we’ll be able to move seamlessly between cold-working, hot glass, and kiln-forming, adapting working methods to best create the project at hand. 

Why the move?

Our previous space came under new management, and we were forced to look for a new location. We've created this campaign to help us acquire important new infrastructure for our new space and make our studio transition happen more efficiently.

We’re excited to bring this multi-use facility to life for the Bay Area glass community, and to have our own venue where we can share our knowledge and enthusiasm for glass in all its forms.

Check out our NEW website at www.fourfab.com!

 

 

So, how will we use your $$?

Your contribution will enable us to build a casting furnace for ladle casting glass, buy a special controller for our kilns, buy a portable press, and assist with the costs of studio relocation. 
 
Given the recent shortages in kiln glass manufacturing, this furnace will be especially critical as it will enable us to create our own custom glass for projects.
 
 
Ladle Casting Furnace: $10,000
Ladle casting is a dynamic process where objects are pressed into sand and then removed, creating impressions of the design in the sand. Molten glass is then ladled into the impression, creating a cast glass version of the design. We will be fabricating the furnace for this process on site in the new studio. This furnace will also enable us to mix custom colors of glass for kiln casting and ladle casting. In order for us to build this furnace (which will contain 600lbs of molten glass when finished) we will need to purchase:
 
  • $2000 in refractory ( IFB, FB, fiberfrax, rammable ) 
  • $6000 in power supply, controls, and elements ( transformer, SCR package, wiring, Molybdenum elements, Hi/Lo controller, thermocouples ) 
  • $2000 in metal and hardware

 

 

GB5 Controller Setup: $5000

This controller will enable us to simultaneously run all five kilns at the same time, and make our electrical use more efficient by staggering power usage. We’ll also be able to program via computer, and easily print out precise records of our firing schedules. This is critical for our ability to undertake multi-part projects which require multiple kilns and meticulous record keeping. To accomplish this rewiring project we will need:

  • Digitry Controller with 5 sending units 
  • PC graphing & program manipulation software 
  • Advanced Power Sharing Model
  • Surge suppressor 
  • Thermocouples type K (5) 
  • Main nema enclosure 
  • Relay enclosures (5) 
  • Relays (5 mercury relay switches)  
  • Power Distribution Blocks for Kilns  (5) 
  • Power distribution block for gb & CV  
  • Unistrut & hardware 
  • soow  cable 6/3  ( 20 ft ) 
  • soow  cable  8/3 ( 20 ft )  
  • sjoow cable  18/2 (100 ft )  
  • 240v indicator lights  

​

 

Portable Printing Press and Accessories: $1000

A portable table top printing press will enable us to teach printmaking in our studio (as well as at other locations) and expand our repertoire of art and design. We've found printmaking on paper to be a wonderful accompaniment to printmaking on glass, and are excited at the prospect of incorporating print processes into our studio! (Photo from Carrie's Hauberg residency at Pilchuck Glass School!)
 
  • $650 for portable table top press
  • $50 for press blankets
  • $300 for ink and printing supplies

***All additional funds raised will go toward the cost of setting up and maintaining the studio. THANK YOU!!***

 

 

What YOU get... i.e. the "Perks!"

We've put together a fun assortment of perks – ladle cast glass tiles, handblown ornaments, handmade prints, classes, and a ladle casting PARTY – all of which will provide invaluable support for our studio! We'll be sharing more photos of the available perks throughout the campaign in the gallery at the top of the page–  please check back for more information and details! 

 

Ok, Sign me up! How can I help?

  • Choose one of the Perks! 
  • Purchase art! We've set up a special online gallery where you can purchase art directly to support the campaign. This work is offered at a discount of retail value, with all proceeds going towards studio relocation. VIEW GALLERY 
  • Just want to offer support? Choose your own donation level, and contribute here via credit card through the pink "Back it" button at the top right of the page! Each and every dollar translates directly into equipment and materials for the new studio. Thank you!
  • Spread the word!

Thank you!!! Your support is invaluable to our studio and to our efforts in keeping artisan glass alive as an art form.

_________________________

 

What's in place, OR more about us...

We've worked hard over the past few years to build our studio and have the following already in place through a combination of contributions and hustle:

  • 5 fusing kilns 
  • 2 large scale architectural/fabrication kilns
  • 1 color furnace
  • 12” wet tile saw
  • 18” reciprolap
  • 20” grit grinder
  • Glass Grinding & Polishing Lathe
  • Sandblaster 
  • 50” x 28” UV light box for exposing screens/UV sensitive materials
  • Screenprint washout setup
  • Double stainless steel sink w/instant hot water heater
  • Custom work tables
  • Wax pot and casting tools
  • Assorted ceramic and steel molds for slumping
  • Plotter for kilncarving and sandblast resist
  • 2  25 lbs pot Glass Furnaces for colored glass production 
  • HEPA vacuum system

 

 

Classes

We've taught many classes at public and private studios around the world; for the latest class information please visit our website: www.fourfab.com

Previous venues include: Blue Dog Glass (Melbourne, Australia), Art Glass Studio (Perth, Australia), Creative Glass (UK and Switzerland), Pittsburgh Glass Center (Pittsburgh, PA), Chicago Hot Glass (Chicago, IL), University of Illinois Urbana Champaign (Urbana, IL), The School of the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago, IL), Public Glass (San Francisco, CA), The Crucible (Oakland, CA), Bullseye Glass (Portland, OR and Emeryville CA), Pilchuck Glass School (Stanwood, WA), GlassForum (Averoy, Norway), Ox-bow School of Art & Residencies (Saugatuck, MI) and Northlands Creative Glass (Lybster, Scotland).

Upcoming Highlight:

Collage + Combine | Remix + Redux
Carrie Iverson and Jeremy Scidmore
Pittsburgh Glass Center
Aug 7 – 11, 2017, 9am-5pm

In this experimental class you will use multiple printmaking and painting with glass processes mixed with glass cutting techniques to assemble layered imagery in glass. We will discuss the pros and cons of each technique and how to mix and match them to best realize your ideas. Individual experimentation will be encouraged through focused research and observation of process and material. The print processes covered are lithographic image transfers and screen printing with glass powder.  We will also manipulate glass powders in a variety of mediums for painterly effects.

Previous Highlights:

Poetics of Phenomena @ Pilchuck Glass School

Working with a variety of experimental processes, students will explore the practical and conceptual possibilities of altering, reusing, and layering imagery. Through structured research, the class will focus on observing the phenomenology of materials as a means to develop new work. Processes include fusing, slumping, lithographic transfers on glass and paper, screen-printing with glass, and manipulating glass powder in assorted mediums for painterly effects. Field research will provide inspiration while daily assignments and discussions will build on and refine previous skills.

Glass Amalgamate @ OxBow School of Art

This two-week course will focus on creating glass sculpture utilizing a variety of moldmaking techniques for hot glass. We will work with multipart blow molds, lost wax processes, and hot glass ladle casting. Refinement of our hot glass products may be done in the cold shop with sawing, grinding, engraving, polishing, gluing, and surface treatments.  Students will develop an understanding of each of these techniques and how best to adapt them for their sculptural work. Group and individual discussions will fuel the development of concepts and creation of pieces. A collaborative, team-based approach to working will be encouraged.

 

Who we are...

Jeremy Scidmore earned a B.F.A. at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago (SAIC) and later returned to SAIC to study arts administration and policy. He has been working with the glass medium since 1996, employing techniques such as kilnforming, glassblowing, flameworking, glass printmaking, and neon. He has maintained studios in each of these glass practices and taught nationally and internationally in public and private studios such as Chicago Hot Glass (Chicago, IL), University of Illinois Urbana Champaign (Urbana, IL), The School of the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago, IL), Public Glass (San Francisco, CA), The Crucible (Oakland, CA), Bullseye Glass Company (Portland, OR ; Emeryville CA), Pilchuck Glass School (Stanwood, WA), Pittsburgh Glass Center (Pittsburgh, PA), and Northlands Creative Glass (Lybster, Scotland.) 
“I built my first kiln in 1998, a gas fired salt kiln for ceramics, and have continued designing, constructing, and repairing them since. As a technician and studio manager of glass studios, such as Chicago Hot Glass and Bullseye Glass, I have built gas and electric fired glass furnaces, fusing and casting kilns, as well as a plethora of hot and warm glass thermal devices for studio arts practice. In 2003, I built a 5’ by 10’ bell kiln, “The Frankenkiln,” to produce commissioned architectural kiln casting projects. Working with interior designers, architects, and engineers, we cast glass panels for wall partitions as well as bar and table tops for private residences, restaurants and commercial spaces.”

Carrie Iverson received her BA from Yale University and her MFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. Her work is in many collections including the Art Institute of Chicago, the Brooklyn Museum, the Museum of Modern Art (New York), the Museum of Contemporary Art (Chicago), the Virginia Museum of Fine Art (Richmond, VA), and the Yale University Art Gallery (New Haven, CT). 

 

“I have been working with print media since 1992, employing and teaching a wide variety of processes from etching and lithography to Xerox gum printing and artist’s books. I developed the process “Image Transfers for Kiln Glass” which uses principles from lithography to create a glass piece composed of glass sheet and glass powder. I have taught print and glass classes at studios nationally and internationally, including Blue Dog Glass (Melbourne, Australia), Art Glass Studio (Perth, Australia), Creative Glass (UK and Switzerland), Pittsburgh Glass Center (Pittsburgh, PA), Bullseye Glass (Portland, OR and Emeryville CA), Pilchuck Glass School (Stanwood, WA), GlassForum (Averoy, Norway), and Northlands Creative Glass (Lybster, Scotland).  

Additionally, I have worked as a graphic designer since 1999, often blending digital technologies with object making. As a lead designer for Paper Source and Waste Not Paper (Chicago, Illinois) I assisted in designing and prototyping products for clients such as MoMA (NY) and the Nature Company. As an independent designer I have assisted in book design, model making for public art projects, and preparing images from initial digital photography to pre-press to production.”

Personal websites:

www.jeremyscidmore.com
www.carrieiversonstudio.com

 

Prism says "thank you" for reading all the way to the end!

He has maintained studios in each of these glass practices and taught nationally and internationally in public and private studios such as Chicago Hot Glass (Chicago, IL), University of Illinois Urbana Champaign (Urbana, IL), The School of the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago, IL), Public Glass (San Francisco, CA), The Crucible (Oakland, CA), Bullseye Glass Company (Portland, OR ; Emeryville CA), Pilchuck Glass School (Stanwood, WA), Pittsburgh Glass Center (Pittsburgh, PA), and Northlands Creative Glass (Lybster, Scotland.) “I built my first kiln in 1998, a gas fired salt kiln for ceramics, and have continued designing, constructing, and repairing them since. As a technician and studio manager of glass studios, such as Chicago Hot Glass and Bullseye Glass, I have built gas and electric fired glass furnaces, fusing and casting kilns, as well as a plethora of hot and warm glass thermal devices for studio arts practice. In 2003, I built a 5’ by 10’ bell kiln, “The Frankenkiln,” to produce commissioned architectural kiln casting projects. Working with interior designers, architects, and engineers, we cast glass panels for wall partitions as well as bar and table tops for private residences, restaurants and commercial spaces.”
 Carrie Iverson received her BA from Yale University and her MFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. Her work is in many collections including the Art Institute of Chicago, the Brooklyn Museum, the Museum of Modern Art (New York), the Museum of Contemporary Art (Chicago), the Virginia Museum of Fine Art (Richmond, VA), and the Yale University Art Gallery (New Haven, CT).  

“I have been working with print media since 1992, employing and teaching a wide variety of processes from etching and lithography to Xerox gum printing and artist’s books. I developed the process “Image Transfers for Kiln Glass” which uses principles from lithography to create a glass piece composed of glass sheet and glass powder. I have taught print and glass classes at studios nationally and internationally, including Blue Dog Glass (Melbourne, Australia), Art Glass Studio (Perth, Australia), Creative Glass (UK and Switzerland), Pittsburgh Glass Center (Pittsburgh, PA), Bullseye Glass (Portland, OR and Emeryville CA), Pilchuck Glass School (Stanwood, WA), GlassForum (Averoy, Norway), and Northlands Creative Glass (Lybster, Scotland).  Additionally, I have worked as a graphic designer since 1999, often blending digital technologies with object making. As a lead designer for Paper Source and Waste Not Paper (Chicago, Illinois) I assisted in designing and prototyping products for clients such as MoMA (NY) and the Nature Company. As an independent designer I have assisted in book design, model making for public art projects, and preparing images from initial digital photography to pre-press to production.”
Personal websites:


www.jeremyscidmore.comwww.carrieiversonstudio.com
 


Prism says "thank you" for reading all the way to the end!

story:
Hello ! Je souhaite récolter des fonds pour donner à l'association Kourir le moyen d'aider les enfants atteints d'AJI ( Arthrite Juvénile Idiopathique ) et leurs parents. 

Mais tout d'abord qu'est-ce que l'AJI ?

 L’AJI est une maladie très douloureuse et souvent invalidante : les gestes les plus simples de la vie quotidienne deviennent vite très difficiles, voire impossibles. Environ 5000 enfants sont atteints en France. Elle peut apparaître à un âge très précoce et touche surtout les filles.

 Les causes de l’AJI restent encore inconnues. Cette maladie survient brutalement. Arthrite signifie inflammation d’une articulation, le terme chronique implique une durée prolongée et juvénile indique que la maladie débute avant l’âge de 16 ans. Il en existe trois formes principales : 

La forme systémique

Elle concerne 20% des cas. Elle apparaît souvent chez les jeunes enfants. Elle se caractérise au début par une fièvre très élevée, une éruption, parfois une péricardite. Sa gravité est liée à l’importance de l’atteinte articulaire, qui peut être invalidante dans certains cas. 

La forme polyarticulaire

Elle s’observe dans 30% des cas, chez les enfants plus âgés, souvent des filles. Elle atteint de nombreuses articulations. 

La forme oligoarticulaire 

Elle touche peu d’articulations. Elle concerne 50% des cas. Elle survient souvent chez les petites filles. Le risque d’atteinte oculaire est important. 

Les autres formes avoisinantes sont : les lupus érythémateux disséminés, les spondylartropathies et le rhumatisme articulaire aigu.

Quels sont les traitements ?

Il n’existe aucun traitement curatif, c’est à dire supprimant radicalement la maladie. 

Les médicaments sont nombreux, ce sont surtout l’aspirine, les anti-inflammatoires et les corticoïdes, mais leurs effets sont souvent incomplets. Certains traitements comportent des risques qu’il convient d’apprécier en fonction de leurs avantages. 

La rééducation articulaire est parfois indispensable, ainsi que la pose d’attelles ou d’appareillages.

La chirurgie comporte des infiltrations locales, en général des corticoïdes. Des opérations sont parfois nécessaires.

Si vous avez lu tout ce bla bla, je vous félicite car il est très difficile pour les malades eux-même de comprendre ce qu'ils ont.

Kourir donne des conseils aux parents et aux enfants malades dans le quotidien de leurs vies. Elle organise des rencontres avec des professeurs, des médecins et aussi des rencontres entre enfants malades ( souvent des weekends ) pour leurs permettre d'échanger et de se lier d'amitié. Les weekends et autres rencontres sont possibles grâce aux dons. Tout cela permet de donner du courage aux enfants et avec Kourir ils se sentent moins seuls et perdus face à la maladie.

J'ai mis un objectif de 500€ mais sincèrement la moindre pièce me ferait déjà énormément plaisir. 

Si vous le souhaitez, vous pouvez faire des dons directement à l'association Kourir ( vous pourrez éventuellement bénéficier d'une réduction d'impôt pour le don) .

Je compte sur vous et je vous remercie d'avance. Donnez le sourire à ces enfants !

story:
Donate to support a new espresso bar, specializing in single origin coffee & offering the homeless a Second Shot

My Story:

Hello, and thank you for taking the time to read about my crowdfund campaign! My name is Julian Corbett, and I am here to introduce to you my campaign to fund not just a new business venture but also a social enterprise project. 

To give you some background on my experience, I am most well-known for creating the name Cheesecake Charlie, and successfully taking a small artisan home-based idea specializing in cheesecakes, and turning it into a successful enterprise that supplied small beautiful cheesecake creations to wholesale markets and individual food outlets.  I then found love and decided to start a new life here with my Australian Wife.

I am a classically trained chef, catering manager, Barista and more!

Since writing and self-publishing the first in my “Cheesecakeology” series, I have decided to expand on my passion for delicious food and one-of-a-kind single origin coffee beverages. I want to take my experiences in building my own dessert business and transfer the knowledge and creativity to running an espresso bar that makes its own single origin coffee blend, which is difficult to find our area.
 

The Project:

This project has taken on a much deeper meaning and serious nature, from being just another coffee shop or espresso bar idea, to also wanting to make a difference to homelessness in Perth and perhaps extending this out to other cities in Australia. This project is due to the experiences that my wife has shared with me and many conversations with some beautiful Australian people that I’ve met since arriving in Australia.

Homelessness is a problem that could effect us all and unemployment is one of the biggest causes, so we would like to do our part in giving people a second shot.

What makes us a little different from your regular coffee shop or espresso bar is that we are a social enterprise, set up not only to develop a coffee brand through flavour profiling but also to help local homeless people in our community get a second shot. Our goal is to provide expert training, offer a job in the business for up to 6 months and help with housing all of which will hopefully be a stepping stone to long term employment and regaining some pride, dignity and self-confidence.



To begin this process we need to purchase a former shipping container, with the ultimate goal of converting it into a new Espresso Bar and finding a permanent home in the newly redeveloped waterfront area of Perth, Australia. This massive project has been divided up into three phases:

Phase One: Purchasing the shipping container and redesigning it so it can be ready to be made into the espresso bar.

Phase Two: Purchasing a further two shipping containers and performing another conversion to build seating modules, making the espresso bar a sit-down coffee house.  This will create both an indoor and alfresco seating area for our customers.

Phase Three: Purchasing one last shipping container, and converting this one into an in-house roasting room, profiling lab and tasting room.  This will allow us to begin creating our very own single origin coffee blend based on flavour profiling which is a new direction for coffee nerds.

As our project gathers momentum we will be looking to partner up with local organisations to better promote the project and open up further opportunities that can only benefit in the long term

Impact:


This project is not just a labor of love, but concepts like this are not just vital to the redevelopment of our area but should offer a sense of hope to those individuals whom might not have any. Perth's water front area is in the process of a massive revitalization, and needs creative businesses with new ideas to bring life back into the area. By using the unique idea of converting shipping containers into usable space, and bringing to the table flavour profiling to single origin coffee blend that we will make and sell in-house, we believe we have the right combination to make a difference in the area. 

I am also personally very emotionally invested in the idea of supporting growers of single origin coffee beans, and want to do everything I can to back them up in their efforts. By using only single origin coffee beans in our espresso bar and purchasing directly from these growers, we are financially supporting these dedicated growers and giving them the ability to sustain their own businesses, while providing a different option to coffee drinkers who may be unfamiliar with the movement supporting single origin coffee and flavour profiling. We can provide their first experience and educate them at the same time.

Your donations can help us fast-track our project and begin renovations! As soon as we reach our funding goal, we can move through Phase One and begin marketing our new location to the Perth metro area!

What We Need:

For this first crowdfund campaign, we are seeking funding in the amount of $20,000 (AUS).  We will use the money raised to help launch “Phase One” of our project. The exact usage of the funding breaks down as follows:

• Purchase of Shipping Container $2500

• Refurbishment of Container $5000

• Equipment Purchase $3500

• Branding $2500

• Stock $2000

• POS System $500

• Media/Web/FB $1500

• Licences $2500

**We will be looking to lease our Coffee Machines and Grinders.

Your Donation:

Your donation to this campaign is going directly towards the project getting started with the phase one conversion.  This helps open our doors for business and opens up the doors of life for those in need. The impact goes beyond mere finances, by donating to this campaign will allow you to become an important part in someone’s path towards new beginnings. You become a key influence on their journey and for there future, a part in their story.

Join us today and help change the community that we all live in.

If everything goes according to plan, this project should take roughly 2-3 months to complete, from the purchase of the shipping container and beginning it’s conversion, to opening the doors to customers!

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can’t make a donation at this time, there are still ways you can help support my campaign! Please take a few moments to share my campaign information with your friends and family, via social media, email, or through word of mouth!

Thank you in advance for your support and generous donations!

story:
Short Summary

  • We're Tom and Donna McAlonen, and we've been teaching elementary and middle school for the past 20 years.  Our company, BattleQuestions.com, provides a variety of activities for the Battle of the Books reading incentive program such as practice tests, on-line quizzes, flashcards, and a new Jeopardy-style game that has been particularly well received.
  • Motivating today's readers has become increasingly difficult, but the Battle of the Books program incorporates collaboration and healthy quiz-bowl type competitions that encourage kids to read a variety of genres.  Fluent and avid readers have ALWAYS proven to be more successful in all areas of academics, so it follows to encourage all students to become avid readers.
  • Since 2012, we've supported North Carolina schools and have received numerous e-mails from educators around the country who want our program for their state.  For the 2016-2017 school year, we want our service to help other schools customize their own reading program, incorporate another interactive game, and motivate readers with levels of avatars achieved with interactive play.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Developing our Jeopardy-style game was $14,000.  We project Lords and Ladies, avatars, and content questions (depicted in our video) to be even more expensive.
  • Levels of avatars can be attained through game play.
  • Schools can customize their own Battle of the Books lists by selecting books from our database of about 200 titles with more added all the time!  
  • Book questions will be in the "In which book..." format AND  content/multiple choice questions will be an added feature.
  • Perks allow supporters to spread the love of reading, literally insert themselves into our game as an avatar, and start the program at their school!  Call us TODAY at 919-623-7346 and let's old-school talk.
  • If less than the entire amount is funded, we'll implement these improvements, but will be unable to spread our services to the rest of the United States.  Our goal is to keep the program at a low cost and make it available to any and every school.

The Impact

  •  Read some testimonials and spread the love, excitement, and POWER of reading: 

    "I've never seen him read like this before!  Thank you."

         -Parent Volunteer

    "It's like Accelerated Reader on steroids!"

         -Fourth Grade Teacher

    "Eric was reading on the way home from school in the car.  He went to his room and continued reading.  He read for at least an hour this morning!  I've never seen him so motivated to read.  Thank you so much for doing Battle of the Books."

         -Fourth Grade Parent

    "We stopped doing Battle of the Books because it was just WAY TOO MUCH WORK.  But we loved it and missed it. Now it’s back, baby!  BattleQuestions.com did all the work.  Now we just have all the fun.  Thanks for bringing Battle of the Books back to our school."

         -Fifth Grade Teacher

  • Working in cooperation with other teachers and media specialists, our system is the best way to prepare Battle of the Books teams, and has proven to be a fun and exciting way to encourage voracious reading.

Risks & Challenges

  • We want our service available and affordable for ALL schools.
  • Time is a challenge, since we want all of our goals achieved by the summer of 2016; it must be ready and functioning by the start of the 2016-2017 school year.
  • Our plan for solving these challenges:
    • Hire more people to write questions. We create thousands of questions every year.  It's essential to establish realistic benchmark goals and work, work, work!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Can't contribute now?  That's okay.  Just spread the word via social networking by LIKING and SHARING.  Help us make our Indiegogo go.  Go Indiegogo, GO!
  • Spread the word.  Allow others to start a new motivational reading program at their school, and take advantage of money-saving perks.
